title: Sparse PCA: Phase Transitions in the Critical Regime

sections.text:
#### Abstract

This work studies sparse principal component analysis (PCA) in high dimensions. Given $n$ independent $p$-dimensional Gaussian samples with covariance $\boldsymbol{\Sigma}:=(\lambda-1) \boldsymbol{v} \boldsymbol{v}^{\top}+\mathbf{I}_{p}$, our goal is to estimate $\boldsymbol{v}$ under the assumption of sparsity. On the one hand, if the sparsity level $m:=\|\boldsymbol{v}\|_{0}$ satisfies $m \lesssim \sqrt{n}$, algorithms such as covariance thresholding (Krauthgamer et al., 2015) consistently outperform PCA. On the other hand, if $m \gg \sqrt{n}$, it is conjectured that no polynomial-time algorithm can recover $\boldsymbol{v}$ below the detection threshold of PCA. We investigate the "critical" high-dimensional regime, where $n, p, m \rightarrow \infty$ with $m / \sqrt{n} \rightarrow \beta$ and $p / n \rightarrow \gamma$, and study estimators based on kernel PCA, generalizing covariance thresholding.

Within this framework, we achieve a fine-grained understanding of signal detection and recovery. Our main result establishes a detection phase transition, analogous to the Baik-Ben Arous-Péché (BBP) transition for PCA: above a signal strength threshold-depending on the kernel function, $\gamma$, and $\beta$-kernel PCA is informative. Conversely, below the threshold, kernel principal components are asymptotically orthogonal to the signal. Notably, (1) above this threshold, consistent support recovery is possible with high probability, (2) for all $\beta \in(0, \infty)$, kernel PCA strictly outperforms PCA, and (3) as $\beta \rightarrow \infty$, kernel PCA and PCA coincide. We identify optimal kernel functions for detection and support recovery, and numerical calculations suggest that soft thresholding is nearly optimal. Our key technical contribution is approximation guarantees for deterministic equivalents of kernel random matrices, which enable sharp estimates of coordinate fluctuations of kernel principal components.

## 1 Introduction

From factor analysis to covariance estimation to matrix factorization, principal component analysis (PCA) is a standard tool for dimensionality reduction and low-rank signal recovery. Given data with $n$ observations and $p$ variables, the principal components are the eigenvectors of the $p \times p$ sample covariance matrix. PCA, however, has two key drawbacks: first, the principal components are generally non-sparse linear combinations of all $p$ variables. This limits interpretability, and fails to capture the fact that signal matrices are often simultaneously low-rank and sparse-such matrices arise in diverse fields, including genetics, computer vision, imaging, and neuroscience $[22,23,29,55,65]$. Second, in high dimensions (when $p$ is comparable to or greater than $n$ ), PCA is inconsistent: the principal components are inconsistent estimators of the eigenvectors of the population covariance [57].

These issues have spurred the development of numerous alternatives to classical PCA that produce sparse principal components, collectively referred to as sparse PCA methods [38, 17, 67, $22,14,61,42]$. In this literature, the assumption of a low-rank and sparse ground truth is often

[^0]
[^0]:    *Faculty of Mathematics and Computer Science, Weizmann Institute of Science
    ${ }^{\dagger}$ Department of Statistics and Data Science, Yale University
    ${ }^{\ddagger}$ Department of Statistics, Stanford University

implicit in applied and methodological papers, and explicit in theoretical analyses [45]. Whether or not there is evidence in a particular problem that the ground truth is sparse, Friedman et al. advise "betting on sparsity": "Use a procedure that does well in sparse problems, since no procedure does well in dense problems" $[29,32]$.

PCA has been extensively studied in high dimensions, revealing several phenomena that are absent in classical fixed- $p$ statistics. A prototypical model in the theoretical literature is Johnstone's spiked covariance model (henceforth referred to as the "spiked model") [35]. Under this model, $n$ independent samples are observed from a $p$-dimensional Gaussian distribution $\mathcal{N}(0, \boldsymbol{\Sigma})$, where the population covariance $\boldsymbol{\Sigma} \in \mathbb{R}^{p \times p}$ is a rank-one perturbation of identity:

$$
\boldsymbol{\Sigma}:=(\lambda-1) \boldsymbol{v} \boldsymbol{v}^{\top}+\mathbf{I}_{p}
$$

Here, $\lambda>1$ is the maximum eigenvalue of $\boldsymbol{\Sigma}$ and our goal is to estimate the corresponding eigenvector or "spike" $\boldsymbol{v} \in \mathbb{S}^{p-1}$. Let $\boldsymbol{Z} \boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{1 / 2} \in \mathbb{R}^{n \times p}$ denote the data matrix with the samples as rows, where $\boldsymbol{Z} \in \mathbb{R}^{n \times p}$ contains i.i.d. standard Gaussian elements.

PCA estimates $\boldsymbol{v}$ by the leading eigenvector $\boldsymbol{u}_{1}$ of the sample covariance $\boldsymbol{Y}:=n^{-1} \boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{1 / 2} \boldsymbol{Z}^{\top} \boldsymbol{Z} \boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{1 / 2}$ (which is a sufficient statistic for $\boldsymbol{v}$ ). In low dimensions, where $n \rightarrow \infty$ and $p / n \rightarrow 0, \boldsymbol{u}_{1}$ and $\boldsymbol{Y}$ are consistent estimators of $\boldsymbol{v}$ (in terms of cosine similarity) and $\boldsymbol{\Sigma}$ (in operator norm), respectively: $\left\langle\boldsymbol{u}_{1}, \boldsymbol{v}\right\rangle^{2} \xrightarrow{a . s} 1$ and $\|\boldsymbol{Y}-\boldsymbol{\Sigma}\|_{2} \xrightarrow{a . s} 0$. In high dimensions, however, these consistency results no longer hold. As $n, p \rightarrow \infty$ with $p / n \rightarrow \gamma \in(0, \infty)$ (and $\lambda$ fixed), the empirical spectral distribution (ESD) of $\boldsymbol{Y}$ converges weakly almost surely to the Marchenko-Pastur law, supported on $\left[(1-\sqrt{\gamma})^{2},(1+\sqrt{\gamma})^{2}\right]$. Moreover, the maximum eigenvalue $\lambda_{1}$ of $\boldsymbol{Y}$ and $\boldsymbol{u}_{1}$ satisfy

$$
\begin{gathered}
\lambda_{1} \xrightarrow{a . s} \begin{cases}\lambda+\frac{\lambda \gamma}{\lambda-1} & \lambda>1+\sqrt{\gamma} \\
(1+\sqrt{\gamma})^{2} & \lambda \leq 1+\sqrt{\gamma}\end{cases} \\
\left\langle\boldsymbol{u}_{1}, \boldsymbol{v}\right\rangle^{2} \xrightarrow{a . s} \begin{cases}\left(1-\frac{\gamma}{(\lambda-1)^{2}}\right) /\left(1+\frac{\gamma}{\lambda-1}\right) & \lambda>1+\sqrt{\gamma} \\
0 & \lambda \leq 1+\sqrt{\gamma}\end{cases}
\end{gathered}
$$

Remarkably, PCA experiences a phase transition: if $\lambda \leq 1+\sqrt{\gamma}, \lambda_{1}$ converges to the upper edge of the support of the Marchenko-Pastur law, and $\boldsymbol{u}_{1}$ is asymptotically orthogonal to $\boldsymbol{v}$. On the other hand, if $\lambda>1+\sqrt{\gamma}, \lambda_{1}$ is an outlier eigenvalue, occurring outside the Marchenko-Pastur support, and the cosine similarity between $\boldsymbol{u}_{1}$ and $\boldsymbol{v}$ is non-trivial; that is, $\boldsymbol{u}_{1}$ contains (partial) information about $\boldsymbol{v}$. Key papers in the development of (1.2) and (1.3) include works of Baik, Ben Arous, and Péché [6], Baik and Silverstein [7], and Paul [57], and the threshold $1+\sqrt{\gamma}$ is known as the Baik-Ben Arous-Péché (BBP) transition. For a full list of references, see the survey [34].

When $\boldsymbol{v}$ is uniformly distributed on $\mathbb{S}^{p-1}$, consistent detection (testing between $\lambda=1$ and $\lambda>1$ ) and non-trivial estimation are impossible for weak signal strengths below the BBP transition [58]. However, if $\boldsymbol{v}$ is sufficiently sparse, these key objectives become possible for such weak signals through alternative methods to PCA. In a seminal work, Johnstone and Lu [35] proposed the diagonal thresholding (DT) algorithm, which estimates the support of $\boldsymbol{v}$ by the indices of the largest-magnitude diagonal elements of $\boldsymbol{Y} .{ }^{1}$ Assuming knowledge of the sparsity level $m:=\|\boldsymbol{v}\|_{0}$ and that the entries of $\boldsymbol{v}$ satisfy $v_{i} \in\{0, \pm 1 / \sqrt{m})$, Amini and Wainwright [3] proved that DT recovers the support of $\boldsymbol{v}$ with high probability if $m \leq C(\lambda) \sqrt{n / \log p}$.

Building upon DT, Krauthgamer, Nadler, and Vilenchik [42] proposed covariance thresholding (CT). Informally, CT (1) hard-thresholds the entries of $\boldsymbol{Y}$, (2) computes the principal eigenvector $\boldsymbol{u}_{1}$

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{1}$ Given the support of $\boldsymbol{v}$, PCA applied to the corresponding submatrix of $\boldsymbol{Y}$ consistently estimates $\boldsymbol{v}$.

of the thresholded matrix, and (3) estimates the support of $\boldsymbol{v}$ from the largest-magnitude elements of $\boldsymbol{u}_{1}$. Deshpande and Montanari [19] subsequently suggested using soft thresholding and setting the diagonal of $\boldsymbol{Y}$ to zero in step (1). They proved that this modified algorithm (also referred to as CT) recovers the support of $\boldsymbol{v}$ with high probability if $m \leq C(\lambda) \sqrt{n}$, thereby confirming a conjecture of [42]. In particular, below the BBP transition where PCA fails, CT succeeds if $m / \sqrt{n}$ is sufficiently small. Semidefinite programming approaches were unable to improve on this result $[3,42]$ (see the discussion in [19]).

This body of research raises the following question: is the condition $m \lesssim \sqrt{n}$ necessary for computationally efficient estimation below the BBP transition? Ignoring computational considerations, a weaker condition suffices: by exhaustively searching over $m \times m$ principal submatrices of $\boldsymbol{Y}$, exponential-time algorithms can recover the support of $\boldsymbol{v}$ if $m \log p \lesssim n$ (for any fixed $\lambda>1$ ), which is information-theoretically optimal [19, 66]. Conversely, work of Berthet and Rigollet [10] and ensuing papers strongly suggest that no polynomial-time algorithm can non-trivially estimate $\boldsymbol{v}$ below the BBP transition if $m \gg \sqrt{n}$. In summary, "the sparse PCA problem demonstrates a fascinating interplay between computational and statistical barriers" [19].

This work focuses on the "critical" regime $m \asymp \sqrt{n}$; as discussed above, this is the coarsest sparsity level at which $\boldsymbol{v}$ is believed recoverable below the BBP transition in polynomial time. Accordingly, we assume $m / \sqrt{n} \rightarrow \beta \in(0, \infty)$ and, as in $[3,42]$, work under the spiked model (1.1) with $v_{i} \in\{0, \pm 1 / \sqrt{m}\}$. We consider generalized covariance thresholding (GCT), which computes the maximum eigenvalue $\lambda_{1}$ and corresponding eigenvector $\boldsymbol{u}_{1}$ of $\boldsymbol{K}(f) \in \mathbb{R}^{p \times p}$, defined as follows:

$$
(\boldsymbol{K}(f))_{i j}:= \begin{cases}\frac{1}{\sqrt{n}} f\left(\sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{Y}_{i j}\right) & i \neq j \\ 0 & i=j\end{cases} \quad i, j \in[p]
$$

where $f: \mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ is a kernel function. We estimate the support of $\boldsymbol{v}$ by hard thresholding the entries of $\boldsymbol{u}_{1}$. CT corresponds to the hard-thresholding kernel $\eta_{h}(x, t):=x \cdot \mathbf{1}_{|x| \geq t}$ in [42] and the soft-thresholding kernel $\eta_{s}(x, t):=\operatorname{sign}(x) \cdot(|x|-t)_{+}$in [19].

# 1.1 Summary of Contributions 

The objective of this paper is to develop a comprehensive theory of GCT. Specifically, we answer in the affirmative the following question: does the high-dimensional PCA theory outlined above (namely, (1.2) and (1.3)) extend to GCT? Moreover, we resolve an open question of Desphande and Montanari [19]: under what range of sparsity levels $\beta$ does CT (or GCT) (1) outperform PCA by producing a non-trivial estimate of $\boldsymbol{v}$ below the BBP transition, and (2) consistently recover the support of $\boldsymbol{v}$ ? We now summarize our contributions:
(1) For a general class of kernel functions, we establish a phase transition, analogous to the BBP transition. ${ }^{2}$ Above a signal strength threshold $\lambda_{*}(f, \gamma, \beta)$-depending on $f$, the limiting aspect ratio $\gamma$, and the limiting sparsity level $\beta$-GCT is informative: the spectrum of $\boldsymbol{K}(f)$ contains an outlier eigenvalue and the cosine similarity between $\boldsymbol{u}_{1}$ and $\boldsymbol{v}$ is non-trivial. Below $\lambda_{*}(f, \gamma, \beta), \boldsymbol{u}_{1}$ is asymptotically orthogonal to $\boldsymbol{v}$. We provide limiting formulas for eigenvalue

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{2}$ For brevity, we describe here a slightly simplified version of our results.

and eigenvector inconsistency, analogous to (1.2) and (1.3):

$$
\begin{aligned}
\lambda_{1} & \xrightarrow{a.s.} \begin{cases}\psi(f, \gamma, \beta) & \lambda>\lambda_{*}(f, \gamma, \beta) \\
\lambda_{+} & \lambda \leq \lambda_{*}(f, \gamma, \beta)\end{cases} \\
\left\langle\boldsymbol{u}_{1}, \boldsymbol{v}\right\rangle^{2} & \xrightarrow{a.s.} \begin{cases}\theta^{2}(f, \gamma, \beta) & \lambda>\lambda_{*}(f, \gamma, \beta) \\
0 & \lambda \leq \lambda_{*}(f, \gamma, \beta)\end{cases}
\end{aligned}
$$

Expressions for $\psi(f, \gamma, \beta)$ and $\theta^{2}(f, \gamma, \beta)$ are provided in Section 2.
Furthermore, above $\lambda_{*}(f, \gamma, \beta)$, the coordinates of $\boldsymbol{u}_{1}$ concentrate tightly around those of $\theta(f, \gamma, \beta) \boldsymbol{v}$. Consequently, appropriate hard-thresholding of $\boldsymbol{u}_{1}$ recovers the support of $\boldsymbol{v}$ exactly, with high probability.
(2) We prove the existence of and characterize an optimal kernel function (depending on $\beta$ ) with phase transition

$$
\lambda_{*}(\gamma, \beta):=\inf _{f \in L^{2}(\phi)} \lambda_{*}(f, \gamma, \beta)
$$

where $L^{2}(\phi)$ is the set of odd $L^{2}$ functions with respect to the Gaussian measure. With this kernel choice, GCT strictly outperforms PCA for all values of $\beta \in(0, \infty)$, and as $\beta \rightarrow \infty$, GCT and PCA coincide (see Figure 1). Numerical calculations suggest that CT is nearly optimal, and we propose to adaptively select the thresholding level to maximize the (normalized) spectral gap. That is, we select the thresholding level that empirically produces the most "clear" outlier eigenvalue.
(3) To prove (1), we develop sharp bounds on the coordinate fluctuations of kernel principal components. These bounds are based on novel approximation guarantees for deterministic equivalents of kernel matrices-Theorems 4.1 and 4.2-which achieve optimal rates of convergence and may be of independent interest. General-purpose entrywise eigenvector perturbation bounds (such as those in [1]) are insufficient for our purposes.

The paper is organized as follows: Section 2 presents our main results, Section 3 contains numerical calculations and simulations, Section 4 states deterministic equivalents for kernel matrices, and Section 5 and Appendices A-C contain proofs.

# 1.2 Related Work 

Deshpande and Montanari [19] proved that CT recovers the support of $\boldsymbol{v}$ with high probability if $m \leq C(\lambda) \sqrt{n}$, thereby confirming a conjecture of [42]. Their analysis is non-asymptotic and applies to a more general spiked model than we consider here. El Amine Seddik, Tamaazousti, and Couillet [24] study a variant of GCT in the sub-critical sparsity regime $m \ll \sqrt{n}$. They do not establish a phase transition or consider support recovery.

Recently, Novikov [54] proposed a novel sparse PCA algorithm building on ideas from the planted clique problem [2]. Given an integer $k$, the algorithm recovers $\boldsymbol{v}$ with high probability if

$$
\lambda \geq \frac{C m}{\sqrt{k n}} \sqrt{\log \left(2+k p / m^{2}\right)}
$$

and runs in time $n p^{O(k)}\left(\mathrm{GCT}\right.$ runs in time $\left.O\left(n p^{2}\right)\right)$. In the critical regime where $p / n \rightarrow \gamma$ and $m / \sqrt{n} \rightarrow \beta$, this condition reduces to $\lambda \geq C \beta \sqrt{(\log k) / k}$. Thus, for any fixed $\lambda>1$ and $\beta \in(0, \infty)$, recovery is possible in polynomial time by choosing a sufficiently large constant $k$. Novikov does

![img-0.jpeg](img-0.jpeg)

Figure 1: Stylized illustration of our results as $p / n \rightarrow \gamma$. Area (I) is the recovery region of PCA, the union of areas (I) and (II) is the recovery region of GCT, and (III) is the GCT impossibility region. The boundary between regions (II) and (III), the curve $\lambda_{*}(\gamma, \beta)$, is the phase transition location of the optimal kernel function, characterized in Section 2.3. As $\beta \rightarrow \infty, \lambda_{*}(\gamma, \beta) \rightarrow 1+\sqrt{\gamma}$ (the BBP transition).
not establish a phase transition or derive exact limits as in (1.5) and (1.6). We remark that the algorithm is highly tailored to the spiked model (1.1), making it primarily of theoretical interest.

A related body of work, including [59, 18, 47, 46, 58, 31, 51], considers estimation in the spiked model (1.1) where $v_{1}, \ldots, v_{p}$ are i.i.d. samples from a (fixed) prior distribution. By assuming a prior with a positive point mass on zero, this framework covers sparse PCA in the linear sparsity regime where $m \asymp n$. Deshpande and Montanari [18] and Perry et al. [58] considered a Bernoulli prior: $v_{1}, \ldots, v_{p} \sim \operatorname{Ber}(\rho)$. While non-trivial estimation of $\boldsymbol{v}$ is impossible below the BBP transition, PCA becomes sub-optimal above the transition when $\rho$ is sufficiently small. Specifically, there exists a critical value $\rho_{c} \leq .05$, such that if $\rho<\rho_{c}$, an efficient approximate message passing (AMP) algorithm is Bayes optimal [18]. For $\rho>\rho_{c}$, PCA is conjectured to be optimal among polynomial-time algorithms [58].

DT and CT are connected to the works of Bickel and Levina [11], Ma [49], and Cai, Ma, and Wu [15], all of which use thresholding to induce sparsity. In contrast to the spiked model, the first paper studies estimation of covariance matrices with $L^{q}$ quasi-norm sparse rows, where $q \in[0,1)$. The third paper considers minimax estimation of the principal subspace of spiked models of the form $\boldsymbol{\Sigma}=\boldsymbol{V} \boldsymbol{\Lambda} \boldsymbol{V}^{\top}+\mathbf{I}_{p}$, where $\boldsymbol{V}$ has $L^{q}$-sparse rows. They develop a data-driven algorithm based on DT which runs in polynomial time and achieves the minimax rate of convergence over a subset of the parameter space. Specializing their results to our model and $L^{0}$-sparsity, their estimator is suboptimal by a logarithmic factor: it requires $m \leq C(\lambda) \sqrt{n / \log p}$ to provably outperform PCA (see Theorem 7 and Proposition 1 of [15]).

Rather than thresholding, many sparse PCA methods induce sparsity through $L_{1}$-penalized regression. We intend to study the theoretical properties of the elastic-net-based method developed by Zou, Hastie, and Tibshirani [67] in future work.

Key studies of high-dimensional kernel matrices include the works of El Karoui [25], Cheng and Singer, [16], and Fan and Montanari [26]. El Karoui considered kernel matrices with off-diagonal

elements $f\left(\boldsymbol{Y}_{i j}\right)$ (instead of $n^{-1 / 2} f\left(\sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{Y}_{i j}\right)$ as in (1.4)), in which case the kernel matrix acts as a spiked covariance matrix, plus (1) a non-informative low-rank term and (2) a multiple of the identity. Consequently, the leading kernel principal components are asymptotically orthogonal to $\boldsymbol{v}$ below the BBP transition. The second and third papers pertain to kernel matrices of isotropic data (that is, $\boldsymbol{\Sigma}=\mathbf{I}_{p}$ ). Cheng and Singer characterized the limiting spectral distribution (LSD) of $\boldsymbol{K}(f)$ as defined in (1.4), which is the additive free convolution of the (scaled) Marchenko-Pastur and semicircle laws; see Section 1.4 for details. Subsequently, Fan and Montanari proved that the maximum eigenvalue of $\boldsymbol{K}(f)$ converges to the supremum or "upper edge" of this LSD's support.

Nonlinear transformations of spiked matrices is an active area of research not limited to sparse PCA, with recent contributions from Liao, Couillet, and Mahoney [48], Guionnet et al. [30], Feldman [27], Wang, Wu, and Fan [63], and Mergny et al. [50]. The first paper assumes delocalized (dense) spikes and investigates thresholding and quantization kernels (which reduce PCA's computational cost), finding that their application minimally impacts estimation. The second and third papers study a related model in which a transform $f$ is applied elementwise to the data $\boldsymbol{Z} \boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{1 / 2}$, rather than to the sample covariance $\boldsymbol{Y}$. Similarly to [48], spikes are delocalized. For a more detailed discussion of the technical distinctions between our work and [24, 48, 30, 27], see (2.3) and the following comments.

# 1.3 Model and Notations 

In this section, we summarize the definitions introduced above for ease of reference and state additional notations. As in $[3,42]$, let $\boldsymbol{\Sigma}:=(\lambda-1) \boldsymbol{v} \boldsymbol{v}^{\top}+\mathbf{I}_{p}$, where $\lambda \geq 1$ is constant, $m:=\|\boldsymbol{v}\|_{0}$, and $\boldsymbol{v}$ is deterministic (or independent of $\boldsymbol{Z}$ ) and of the form

$$
\sqrt{m} v_{1}, \sqrt{m} v_{2}, \ldots, \sqrt{m} v_{m} \in\{-1,1\}, \quad v_{m+1}=v_{m+2}=\cdots=v_{p}=0
$$

Let $\boldsymbol{Z} \in \mathbb{R}^{n \times p}$ have rows $\boldsymbol{z}_{1}, \ldots, \boldsymbol{z}_{n} \stackrel{i.i.d.}{\sim} \mathcal{N}\left(0, \mathbf{I}_{p}\right)$ and

$$
\boldsymbol{S}:=n^{-1} \boldsymbol{Z}^{\top} \boldsymbol{Z}, \quad \boldsymbol{Y}:=\boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{1 / 2} \boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{1 / 2}, \quad \boldsymbol{X}:=\boldsymbol{Y}-\boldsymbol{S}
$$

This model naturally extends from the first to the second moment the sparse Gaussian sequence model with a Rademacher prior [37]. The assumptions that the non-zero entries of $\boldsymbol{v}$ are the first $m$ and that $\boldsymbol{v}$ is sparse in the canonical basis are without loss of generality.

Define kernel matrices $\boldsymbol{K}(f), \boldsymbol{K}_{0}(f) \in \mathbb{R}^{p \times p}$ as follows: for $i, j \in[p]$,

$$
(\boldsymbol{K}(f))_{i j}:= \begin{cases}\frac{1}{\sqrt{n}} f\left(\sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{Y}_{i j}\right) & i \neq j \\ 0 & i=j\end{cases} \quad\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0}(f)\right)_{i j}:= \begin{cases}\frac{1}{\sqrt{n}} f\left(\sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{S}_{i j}\right) & i \neq j \\ 0 & i=j\end{cases}
$$

The kernel matrix of noise, $\boldsymbol{K}_{0}(f)$, is unobserved. We work within a standard asymptotic framework of random matrix theory, where $n, p, m \rightarrow \infty$ and

$$
\frac{p}{n} \rightarrow \gamma \in(0, \infty), \quad \frac{m}{\sqrt{n}} \rightarrow \beta \in(0, \infty)
$$

Let $\lambda_{1} \geq \lambda_{2} \geq \cdots \geq \lambda_{p}$ denote the eigenvalues of $\boldsymbol{K}(f)$ and $\boldsymbol{u}_{1}, \boldsymbol{u}_{2}, \ldots, \boldsymbol{u}_{p}$ the corresponding eigenvectors. Non-bold symbols will be used to denote the elements of certain matrices and vectors. For example, $\boldsymbol{u}_{1}=\left(u_{11}, u_{12}, \ldots, u_{1 p}\right)$ and $\boldsymbol{Z}=\left(z_{i j}: 1 \leq i \leq n, 1 \leq j \leq p\right)$. The soft- and hardthresholding operators are $\eta_{s}(x, t):=\operatorname{sign}(x) \cdot(\|x\|-t)_{+}$and $\eta_{b}(x, t):=x \cdot \mathbf{1}_{\|x\| \geq t}$. Let $\phi(z):=$

$(2 \pi)^{-1 / 2} e^{-z^{2} / 2}$ denote the Gaussian density and define the inner product on the space of realvalued functions

$$
\langle f, g\rangle_{\phi}:=\int_{\mathbb{R}} f(z) g(z) \phi(z) d z
$$

Let $\left\{h_{\ell}\right\}_{\ell \in \mathbb{N}}$ be the Hermite polynomials (normalized such that $\left.\left\langle h_{k}, h_{\ell}\right\rangle_{\phi}=\mathbf{1}_{k=\ell}\right),\|f\|_{\phi}^{2}:=\langle f, f\rangle_{\phi}$, and $a_{\ell}:=\left\langle f, h_{\ell}\right\rangle_{\phi} ;\left\{a_{\ell}\right\}_{\ell \in \mathbb{N}}$ are the Hermite coefficients of $f$. We will use $\odot$ to denote the Hadamard (elementwise) product.

Results for polynomial kernel functions will be stated using the notion of stochastic domination from [12]: for two sequences of nonnegative random variables $\xi_{n}$ and $\zeta_{n}$, we say $\xi_{n}$ is stochastically dominated by $\zeta_{n}$ and write $\xi_{n} \prec \zeta_{n}$ if for all $\varepsilon, D>0$, there exists $n_{\varepsilon, D} \in \mathbb{N}$ such that

$$
\mathbb{P}\left(\xi_{n}>n^{\varepsilon} \zeta_{n}\right) \leq n^{-D}
$$

for all $n \geq n_{\varepsilon, D}$. If $\xi_{n}$ is not assumed nonnegative and $\left|\xi_{n}\right| \prec \zeta_{n}$, we may write $\xi_{n}=O_{\prec}\left(\zeta_{n}\right)$.

# 1.4 The Spectrum of $\boldsymbol{K}_{0}(f)$ 

The following result, Theorem 3.4 of Cheng and Singer [16], characterizes the LSD of the kernel matrix of noise $\boldsymbol{K}_{0}(f) .{ }^{3}$ Recall that $a_{\ell}:=\left\langle f, h_{\ell}\right\rangle_{\phi}$ is the $\ell$-th Hermite coefficient of $f$.
Theorem 1.1. Let $a_{0}=0,\|f\|_{\phi}^{2}<\infty$, and $f$ be bounded on compact sets. The ESD of $\boldsymbol{K}_{0}(f)$ converges weakly almost surely to a continuous probability measure $\mu$ on $\mathbb{R}$. The Stieltjes transform $s(z)$ of $\mu$ solves the equation

$$
-\frac{1}{s(z)}=z+a_{1}\left(1-\frac{1}{1+a_{1} \gamma s(z)}\right)+\gamma\left(\|f\|_{\phi}^{2}-a_{1}^{2}\right) s(z)
$$

For $z \in \mathbb{C}^{+}$, equation (1.9) has a unique solution $s(z)$ with $\operatorname{Im}(s(z))>0$.
Corollary 1.2. (see Corollary 3 of [48]) In the setting of Theorem 1.1, assume $a_{1}>0$ and let $\psi(s)$ denote the functional inverse of $s(z)$ :

$$
\psi(s):=-\frac{1}{s}-a_{1}\left(1-\frac{1}{1+a_{1} \gamma s}\right)-\gamma\left(\|f\|_{\phi}^{2}-a_{1}^{2}\right) s
$$

The supremum or upper edge of $\operatorname{supp}(\mu)$ is given by

$$
\lambda_{+}:=\psi\left(s_{0}\right)
$$

where $s_{0}$ is the unique solution of $\psi^{\prime}(s)=0$ in the interval $\left(-1 /\left(a_{1} \gamma\right), 0\right)$.

## 2 Results

Our results are organized into three sections. Sections 2.1 and 2.2 present our core technical findings, with Section 2.1 covering polynomial kernels and Section 2.2 non-polynomial kernels. Section 2.3 discusses the statistical implications of these results.

Before proceeding, we define a key function:

$$
\tau(f, \beta, \lambda):=\sum_{\ell=3}^{\infty} \frac{a_{\ell}(\lambda-1)^{\ell}}{\sqrt{\ell!} \beta^{\ell-1}}
$$

We shall see that the spectral properties of $\boldsymbol{K}(f)$ are determined by $\lambda, a_{1},\|f\|_{\phi}^{2}$, and $\tau$; in particular, the performance of GCT depends on $\beta$ only through $\tau(f, \beta, \lambda)$.

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{3}$ For brevity, we do not state Theorem 3.4 of [16] in its full generality.

# 2.1 Polynomial Kernel Functions 

Throughout this section, we assume $f$ is an odd polynomial, $L:=\operatorname{deg}(f)$, and in addition to (1.8),

$$
\frac{p}{n}=\gamma+O\left(n^{-1 / 2}\right)
$$

Let $\beta_{n}:=m / \sqrt{n}=\beta+o(1)$. For brevity, we will write $\tau$ in place of $\tau\left(f, \beta_{n}, \lambda\right)$ (note that $\tau$ contains at most $L$ non-zero terms).

Our first result is that $\boldsymbol{K}(f)$ is approximately the sum of three components: a (diagonal centered) sample covariance matrix $a_{1}\left(\boldsymbol{Y}-\mathbf{I}_{p}\right)$, a rank-one signal term proportional to $\boldsymbol{v} \boldsymbol{v}^{\top}$, and a noise matrix $\boldsymbol{K}_{0}\left(f-a_{1} h_{1}\right)$. This third term acts as an (asymptotically) independent Wigner matrix with semicircular LSD.

Theorem 2.1. Let $f$ be an odd polynomial and (2.2) hold. The matrix

$$
\boldsymbol{A}(f):=a_{1}\left(\boldsymbol{Y}-\mathbf{I}_{p}\right)+\tau \cdot \boldsymbol{v} \boldsymbol{v}^{\top}+\boldsymbol{K}_{0}\left(f-a_{1} h_{1}\right)
$$

approximates $\boldsymbol{K}(f)$ in operator norm:

$$
\|\boldsymbol{K}(f)-\boldsymbol{A}(f)\|_{2} \prec n^{-1 / 4}
$$

In our view, this is a rather unexpected result. Consider the decomposition

$$
\boldsymbol{K}(f)=\sum_{\ell=0}^{L} \frac{1}{\ell!}(\sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{X})^{\odot \ell} \odot \boldsymbol{K}_{0}\left(f^{(\ell)}\right)
$$

In related studies such as $[48,30,27]$, where the signal $\boldsymbol{v}$ is dense (for example, if $\boldsymbol{v}$ is generated uniformly on $\mathbb{S}^{p-1}$ ), Hadamard powers of $\boldsymbol{X}$ have vanishing operator norm: for $\ell>1$, $\left\|(\sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{X})^{\odot \ell}\right\|_{2} \rightarrow 0$. Therefore, $\boldsymbol{K}(f)$ is well approximated by $\boldsymbol{K}_{0}(f)+\sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{X} \odot \boldsymbol{K}_{0}\left(f^{\prime}\right)$. In our setting, such powers of $\sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{X}$ are no longer negligible. Representing $f$ in the basis of Hermite polynomials and using the identity $h_{k}^{(\ell)}(z)=\sqrt{k!/(k-\ell)!} h_{k-\ell}(z),(2.3)$ becomes

$$
\boldsymbol{K}(f)=\sum_{\ell=0}^{L} \sum_{k=\ell}^{L} \frac{a_{k}}{\ell!} \sqrt{\frac{k!}{(k-\ell)!}}\left((\sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{X})^{\odot \ell} \odot \boldsymbol{K}_{0}\left(h_{k-\ell}\right)\right)
$$

Theorem 2.1 is a consequence of the convergence

$$
\left\|(\sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{X})^{\odot \ell} \odot \boldsymbol{K}_{0}\left(h_{k}\right)\right\|_{2} \xrightarrow{a.s} 0
$$

for $\ell, k>0$-in short, this occurs because $\boldsymbol{X}$ sparsifies $\boldsymbol{K}_{0}\left(h_{k}\right)$, which is an array of weakly dependent elements with means converging to zero. ${ }^{4}$

The operator-norm convergence established in Theorem 2.1 implies that the spectral properties of $\boldsymbol{K}(f)$ and $\boldsymbol{A}(f)$ are closely related (see Lemma 2.1 of [25]). In particular, (1) the ESDs of $\boldsymbol{K}(f)$ and $\boldsymbol{A}(f)$ converge weakly almost surely to a common limit by Cauchy's interlacing inequality and (2) the leading eigenvalues of $\boldsymbol{K}(f)$ and $\boldsymbol{A}(f)$ are asymptotically equal. Leveraging this relationship, we obtain the following theorem:

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{4}$ Let $i \neq j$. Since $\sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{S}_{i j} \xrightarrow{d} \mathcal{N}(0,1)$ and $h_{k}$ orthogonal to $h_{0}$, the continuous mapping theorem implies $\sqrt{n} \mathbb{E}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0}\left(h_{k}\right)\right)_{i j}=\mathbb{E} h_{k}\left(\sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{S}_{i j}\right) \rightarrow\left\langle h_{k}, h_{0}\right\rangle_{\phi}=0$.

Theorem 2.2. In the setting of Theorem 2.1, assume $a_{1}>0, \tau \neq 0$, and define

$$
\begin{aligned}
s_{+} & \left.=\frac{-a_{1}(\lambda+\gamma-1)-\tau+\sqrt{\left(a_{1}(\lambda+\gamma-1)+\tau\right)^{2}-4 a_{1} \gamma \tau}}{2 a_{1} \gamma \tau}\right), \\
\theta^{2}(x) & \left.=-\frac{1+\gamma x\left(a_{1}\left(2+a_{1} \gamma x\right)\left(1+a_{1}^{2} \gamma x^{2}\right)-x\left(1+a_{1} \gamma x\right)^{2}\|f\|_{\phi}^{2}\right)}{x\left(1+a_{1} \gamma x\right)\left(\tau+a_{1}(\lambda+\gamma+2 \tau \gamma x-1)\right)} .\right.
\end{aligned}
$$

If $\psi^{\prime}\left(s_{+}\right)>0$,

$$
\left|\lambda_{1}-\psi\left(s_{+}\right)\right| \prec n^{-1 / 2}, \quad\left\langle\boldsymbol{u}_{1}, \boldsymbol{v}\right\rangle^{2}=\theta^{2}\left(s_{+}\right)+O_{\prec}\left(n^{-1 / 2}\right)
$$

and for $i \in[p]$, assuming $\left\langle\boldsymbol{u}_{1}, \boldsymbol{v}\right\rangle \geq 0$ without loss of generality,

$$
u_{1 i}=\theta\left(s_{+}\right) v_{i}+O_{\prec}\left(n^{-1 / 2}\right)
$$

If $\psi^{\prime}\left(s_{+}\right) \leq 0$,

$$
\lambda_{1} \xrightarrow{a . s} \lambda_{+}, \quad\left\langle\boldsymbol{u}_{1}, \boldsymbol{v}\right\rangle \xrightarrow{a . s} 0
$$

We note that $\psi^{\prime}\left(s_{+}\right)>0$ implies $\psi\left(s_{+}\right)>\lambda_{+}$and $\theta^{2}\left(s_{+}\right)>0$-see the proofs of (5.10) and (5.11) in Section 5. Thus, if $\psi^{\prime}\left(s_{+}\right)>0$, GCT is informative: $\lambda_{1}$ is an outlier eigenvalue and the cosine similarity between $\boldsymbol{u}_{1}$ and $\boldsymbol{v}$ is non-trivial. Moreover, according to (2.6), the coordinates of $\boldsymbol{u}_{1}$ concentrate tightly around those of $\theta\left(s_{+}\right) \boldsymbol{v}$. Consequently, appropriate hard-thresholding of $\boldsymbol{u}_{1}$ recovers the support of $\boldsymbol{v}$ exactly-see Corollary 2.6. On the other hand, if $\psi^{\prime}\left(s_{+}\right) \leq 0$, GCT is noninformative: $\lambda_{1}$ converges to $\lambda_{+}$, the supremum of $\operatorname{supp}(\mu)$, and $\boldsymbol{u}_{1}$ is asymptotically orthogonal to $\boldsymbol{v}$. For comments on the cases $a_{1} \leq 0$ and $\tau=0$, which Theorem 2.2 excludes, see Remark 2.2.
Remark 2.1. We believe the convergence rates in Theorem 2.2 are optimal as they match results for the spiked model given in $[12,13]$ (for example, (2.5) and (2.6) compare to Theorems 2.3 and 2.16 of [13]). In contrast, relating $\lambda_{1}$ to the maximum eigenvalue of $\boldsymbol{A}(f)$ using Weyl's inequality and Theorem 2.1 yields

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|\lambda_{1}-\psi\left(s_{+}\right)\right| & \leq\left|\lambda_{1}-\lambda_{\max }(\boldsymbol{A}(f))\right|+\left|\lambda_{\max }(\boldsymbol{A}(f))-\psi\left(s_{+}\right)\right| \\
& \lesssim\|\boldsymbol{K}(f)-\boldsymbol{A}(f)\|_{2} \prec n^{-1 / 4}
\end{aligned}
$$

We will prove that $\left|\lambda_{1}-\psi\left(s_{+}\right)\right|$ is bounded by quadratic forms such as

$$
\boldsymbol{v}^{\top}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0}(f)-\boldsymbol{z} \mathbf{I}_{p}\right)^{-1}(\boldsymbol{K}(f)-\boldsymbol{A}(f))\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0}(f)-\boldsymbol{z} \mathbf{I}_{p}\right)^{-1} \boldsymbol{v}
$$

which have fluctuations of order $O_{\prec}\left(n^{-1 / 2}\right)$-see Section 4.

# 2.2 Non-polynomial Kernel Functions 

Throughout this section, we write $\tau$ in place of $\tau(f, \beta, \lambda)$. The following results are analogs of Theorems 2.1 and 2.2:

Theorem 2.3. Let $f(x)$ be odd, everywhere continuous, and twice differentiable except at finitely many points. Assume there is some $c>0$ such that $|f(x)|,\left|f^{\prime}(x)\right|,\left|f^{\prime \prime}(x)\right| \leq c e^{c|x|}$ whenever they exist. The matrix

$$
\boldsymbol{A}(f):=a_{1}\left(\boldsymbol{Y}-\mathbf{I}_{p}\right)+\tau \cdot \boldsymbol{v} \boldsymbol{v}^{\top}+\boldsymbol{K}_{0}\left(f-a_{1} h_{1}\right)
$$

approximates $\boldsymbol{K}(f)$ in operator norm:

$$
\|\boldsymbol{K}(f)-\boldsymbol{A}(f)\|_{2} \xrightarrow{a . s} 0
$$

Theorem 2.4. In the setting of Theorem 2.3, assume $a_{1}>0, \tau \neq 0$, and recall $s_{+}$and $\theta^{2}(x)$ defined in Theorem 2.2. Then,

$$
\lambda_{1} \xrightarrow{a . s} \begin{cases}\psi\left(s_{+}\right) & \psi^{\prime}\left(s_{+}\right)>0 \\ \lambda_{+} & \psi^{\prime}\left(s_{+}\right) \leq 0\end{cases} \quad\left\langle\boldsymbol{u}_{1}, \boldsymbol{v}\right\rangle^{2} \xrightarrow{a . s} \begin{cases}\theta^{2}\left(s_{+}\right) & \psi^{\prime}\left(s_{+}\right)>0 \\ 0 & \psi^{\prime}\left(s_{+}\right) \leq 0\end{cases}
$$

To prove Theorems 2.3 and 2.4 from Theorems 2.1 and 2.2, we construct in Lemma 5.4 a sequence of odd polynomials $\left\{f_{\ell}\right\}_{\ell \in \mathbb{N}}$ such that $\left\|f-f_{\ell}\right\|_{\phi} \rightarrow 0$ and

$$
\lim _{\ell \rightarrow \infty} \limsup _{n \rightarrow \infty}\left\|\boldsymbol{K}(f)-\boldsymbol{K}\left(f_{\ell}\right)\right\|_{2}=\lim _{\ell \rightarrow \infty} \limsup _{n \rightarrow \infty}\left\|\boldsymbol{K}_{0}(f)-\boldsymbol{K}_{0}\left(f_{\ell}\right)\right\|_{2} \stackrel{a . s}{=} 0
$$

This result builds upon [26] in that (1) Theorems 1.4 and 1.6 of [26] pertain only to the kernel matrix of noise $\boldsymbol{K}_{0}(f)$ and (2) Theorem 1.4 assumes $f$ is continuously differentiable. We stress that the specific conditions Theorem 2.3 places on $f$ are not the focus of this paper and are likely improvable. Rather, we developed in (2.9) a minimal extension of [26] that accommodates soft thresholding.
Remark 2.2. Theorems 2.2 and 2.4 exclude $\tau=0$ or $a_{1} \leq 0$. The former case arises under linear kernel functions (the limits of $\lambda_{1}$ and $\left\langle\boldsymbol{u}_{1}, \boldsymbol{v}\right\rangle^{2}$ are then given by [6]) or $\lambda=1$ ( $\boldsymbol{v}$ is then unidentifiable). If $a_{1}<0$, our results apply to $\boldsymbol{K}(-f)$. If $a_{1}=0, \boldsymbol{K}(f)$ is approximately a spiked Wigner matrix, and the limits of interest are derived by applying [8] to $\boldsymbol{A}(f):^{5}$

$$
\lambda_{1} \xrightarrow{a . s} \begin{cases}\tau+\frac{\gamma\|f\|_{\phi}^{2}}{\tau} & \tau>\sqrt{\gamma}\|f\|_{\phi}, \\ 2 \sqrt{\gamma}\|f\|_{\phi} & \tau \leq \sqrt{\gamma}\|f\|_{\phi},\end{cases} \quad\left\langle\boldsymbol{u}_{1}, \boldsymbol{v}\right\rangle^{2} \xrightarrow{a . s} \begin{cases}1-\frac{\gamma\|f\|_{\phi}^{2}}{\tau^{2}} & \tau>\sqrt{\gamma}\|f\|_{\phi} \\ 0 & \tau \leq \sqrt{\gamma}\|f\|_{\phi}\end{cases}
$$

These are the standard formulas (appropriate scaled) for limiting eigenvalue bias and eigenvector inconsistency under the spiked Wigner model; see Example 3.1 of [8].
Remark 2.3. We assume $f$ is odd as an even component may introduce spurious spikes into the spectrum of $\boldsymbol{K}(f)$. Specifically, if $f$ is not odd, $\boldsymbol{A}(f)$ of Corollary 2.3 becomes

$$
\boldsymbol{A}(f)=a_{1}\left(\boldsymbol{Y}-\mathbf{I}_{p}\right)+\tau_{e} \cdot \boldsymbol{w} \boldsymbol{w}^{\top}+\tau_{o} \cdot \boldsymbol{v} \boldsymbol{v}^{\top}+\boldsymbol{K}_{0}\left(f-a_{1} h_{1}\right)
$$

where $\boldsymbol{w}:=\left[\mathbf{1}_{m} / \sqrt{m}, \mathbf{0}_{p-m}\right]$ and

$$
\tau_{e}:=\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{a_{2 k}(\lambda-1)^{2 k}}{\sqrt{(2 k)!} \beta^{2 k-1}}, \quad \tau_{o}:=\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{a_{2 k+1}(\lambda-1)^{2 k+1}}{\sqrt{(2 k+1)!} \beta^{2 k}}
$$

The spectrum of $\boldsymbol{K}_{0}\left(f-a_{1} h_{1}\right)$ contains an outlier eigenvalue with eigenvector $\mathbf{1}_{p}$ if $\left|a_{2}\right|$ is sufficiently large (see [26] and [48]).

# 2.3 Detection, Support Recovery, and Optimal Kernels 

This section investigates the statistical implications of the results in Sections 2.1 and 2.2.
First, we introduce a hypothesis test based on the maximum eigenvalue $\lambda_{1}$ of $\boldsymbol{K}(f)$ to detect the presence of a low-rank component in $\boldsymbol{\Sigma}$ (testing the hypothesis $\lambda=1$ versus $\lambda>1$ ). If a spike is detected, appropriate hard-thresholding of the corresponding eigenvector $\boldsymbol{u}_{1}$ recovers the support

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{5}$ The argument of [8] requires that quadratic forms such as $\boldsymbol{v}^{\top}\left(\boldsymbol{K}(f)-z \mathbf{I}_{p}\right)^{-1} \boldsymbol{v}$ concentrate around their expectations; we prove the necessary technical conditions in Theorem 4.1.

of $\boldsymbol{v}$ exactly, with high probability. Importantly, this test is fully powerful if $\psi^{\prime}\left(s_{+}\right)>0$-as shown in Theorems 2.2 and $2.4, \psi^{\prime}\left(s_{+}\right)>0$ ensures that $\lambda_{1}$ is an outlier eigenvalue and that the cosine similarity between $\boldsymbol{u}_{1}$ and $\boldsymbol{v}$ is non-trivial. Thus, $\lambda_{1}, \boldsymbol{u}_{1}$, and support recovery undergo an identical phase transition. This support recovery phase transition was empirically observed by Krauthgamer et al. (Figure 3 of [42]), though it has not been rigorously established.

Second, we prove the existence of and characterize an optimal kernel $f^{*}(\cdot ; \gamma, \beta)$ with the broadest recovery region. Third, we demonstrate that as $\beta \rightarrow \infty$, GCT fails below the BBP transition. This supports the conjecture that if $m \gg \sqrt{n}$, the detection threshold of PCA is optimal among polynomial-time algorithms-see the discussion in Section 1. Proofs are deferred to Section 5.3.

Let $L_{o}^{2}(\phi):=\left\{f:\|f\|_{\phi}^{2}<\infty, f(x)=-f(-x)\right\}$. In light of Theorems 2.2 and 2.4, we define a region $\mathcal{R}$ in which GCT is informative,

$$
\mathcal{R}:=\left\{(f, \gamma, \beta, \lambda): \psi^{\prime}\left(s_{+}\right)>0, f \in L_{o}^{2}(\phi), \gamma \in(0, \infty), \beta \in(0, \infty), \lambda \geq 1\right\}
$$

and $\mathcal{R}(f, \gamma, \beta, \cdot):=\{\lambda:(f, \gamma, \beta, \lambda) \in \mathcal{R}\}$. Within $\mathcal{R}(f, \gamma, \beta, \cdot)$, the following test consistently detects the presence of a spike:

Corollary 2.5. Let $f \in L_{o}^{2}(\phi)$ satisfy the assumptions of Theorem 2.4 and $\lambda_{0} \in \mathcal{R}(f, \gamma, \beta, \cdot)$. Consider the test of $H_{0}: \lambda=1$ versus $H_{1}: \lambda \geq \lambda_{0}$ which rejects $H_{0}$ if

$$
\lambda_{1}>\lambda_{+}+\varepsilon
$$

where $\varepsilon \in\left(0, \psi\left(s_{+}\right)-\lambda_{+}\right)$. This test is asymptotically correct and fully powerful.
As a consequence of (2.6), which states that the coordinates of $\boldsymbol{u}_{1}$ concentrate tightly around those of $\theta\left(s_{+}\right)$when $\psi^{\prime}\left(s_{+}\right)>0$, hard thresholding of $\boldsymbol{u}_{1}$ recovers the support of $\boldsymbol{v}$ exactly. The thresholding level is independent of $\lambda$ and $\beta$, which are generally unknown:

Corollary 2.6. Let $f \in L_{o}^{2}(\phi)$ be a polynomial, $\lambda \in \mathcal{R}(f, \gamma, \beta, \cdot), \varepsilon \in(1 / 4,1 / 2)$, and define the estimator

$$
\widehat{\boldsymbol{v}}:=\frac{\operatorname{sign}\left(\left(\eta_{h}\left(\boldsymbol{u}_{1}, n^{-\varepsilon}\right)\right)\right.}{\left\|\operatorname{sign}\left(\left(\eta_{h}\left(\boldsymbol{u}_{1}, n^{-\varepsilon}\right)\right)\right]\right\|_{2}}
$$

For any $D>0$, there exists $n_{\varepsilon, D} \in \mathbb{N}$ such that

$$
\mathbb{P}(\widehat{\boldsymbol{v}}=\boldsymbol{v}) \geq 1-n^{-D}, \quad \forall n \geq n_{\varepsilon, D}
$$

Corollaries 2.5 and 2.6 follow directly from Theorems 2.2 and 2.4. In Corollary 2.6, we assume that $f$ is polynomial, since we only establish entrywise eigenvector bounds for polynomial kernels. While we believe this assumption is not strictly necessary, we leave this technicality for future work. Notwithstanding, recovery throughout $\mathcal{R}$ is formally possible by polynomial-kernel GCT:

Lemma 2.7. For $f \in L_{o}^{2}(\phi)$, let $f_{\ell}:=\sum_{k=1}^{\ell} a_{k} h_{k}$ denote its degree- $\ell$ Hermite approximation. If $\lambda \in \mathcal{R}(f, \gamma, \beta, \cdot)$, there exists $L \in \mathbb{N}$ such that $\lambda \in \mathcal{R}\left(f_{\ell}, \gamma, \beta, \cdot\right)$ for all $\ell \geq L$.

For many kernels of interest, the recovery region admits a simple form. Specifically, if $\tau(f, \beta, \lambda)$ is non-decreasing in $\lambda$, a "standard" phase transition occurs: GCT is informative for signal strengths exceeding a critical value $\lambda_{*}(f, \gamma, \beta)$.

Lemma 2.8. If $\tau(f, \beta, \lambda)$ is non-decreasing in $\lambda$, then there exists $\lambda_{*}(f, \gamma, \beta)>1$ such that

$$
\mathcal{R}(f, \gamma, \beta, \cdot)=\left(\lambda_{*}(f, \gamma, \beta), \infty\right)
$$

Lemma 2.8 applies to kernels with non-negative Hermite coefficients, as well as to the soft thresholding operator $\eta_{s}(\cdot, t)$, which has coefficients $a_{0}=0, a_{1}=1-\operatorname{erf}(t / \sqrt{2})$, and

$$
a_{k}= \begin{cases}\sqrt{\frac{2}{k(k-1) \pi}} e^{-t^{2} / 2} h_{k-2}(t) & k \text { odd } \\ 0 & k \text { even }\end{cases}
$$

We next prove there exists an optimal kernel $f^{*}(\cdot ; \gamma, \beta)$ with the broadest recovery region. For brevity, we omit the explicit dependence of $f^{*}$ on $\gamma$ and $\beta$.

Corollary 2.9. There exists a kernel function $f^{*}$ satisfying the conditions of Theorem 2.3 and a critical value $\lambda_{*}(\gamma, \beta)$ such that

$$
\bigcup_{f \in L_{0}^{p}(\phi)} \mathcal{R}(f, \gamma, \beta, \cdot)=\mathcal{R}\left(f^{*}, \gamma, \beta, \cdot\right)=\left(\lambda_{*}(\gamma, \beta), \infty\right)
$$

For $k \geq 2$, the Hermite coefficients of $f^{*}$ are of the form

$$
a_{k}^{*}= \begin{cases}\frac{\left(\lambda_{*}(\gamma, \beta)-1\right)^{k}}{\sqrt{k!} \beta^{k-1}} & k \text { odd } \\ 0 & k \text { even }\end{cases}
$$

By design, $f^{*}$ maximizes $\tau\left(f, \beta, \lambda_{*}(\gamma, \beta)\right)$ over

$$
\left\{f \in L_{o}^{2}(\phi):\left\langle f, h_{1}\right\rangle_{\phi}=a_{1}^{*},\|f\|_{\phi}=\left\|f^{*}\right\|_{\phi}\right\}
$$

In Section 3, we will numerically calculate $\lambda_{*}(\gamma, \beta)$.
Our final result demonstrates that as $\beta \rightarrow \infty$, GCT fails below the BBP transition. This supports the conjecture that if $m \gg \sqrt{n}$, the detection threshold of PCA is optimal among polynomialtime algorithms.

Corollary 2.10. For any $\gamma \in(0, \infty)$, the function $\beta \mapsto \lambda_{*}(\gamma, \beta)$ is increasing and

$$
\lim _{\beta \rightarrow \infty} \lambda_{*}(\gamma, \beta)=1+\sqrt{\gamma}
$$

# 3 Numerical Calculations and Simulations 

This section presents numerical calculations and simulations.
Figure 2 compares GCT with the kernel $\eta_{s}(\cdot, 2)$ (soft thresholding) to standard PCA in terms of cosine similarity, illustrating the phase transition of Theorem 2.4 and the BBP transition. As $\beta$ decreases, the performance gap between GCT and PCA increases. Figure 3 plots the corresponding chance of recovery using the estimator of Corollary 2.6; empirically, GCT recovers $\boldsymbol{v}$ with high probability above the detection threshold. For example, in the left plot, we recovered $\boldsymbol{v}$ in $100 \%$ of simulations with $\lambda \geq 1.7$.

Figure 4 depicts the optimal phase transitions of GCT (right) and soft thresholding (left), for $\gamma \in\{.5,1,1.5\}$ and $\beta \in[.1,2.5]$. From Corollary 2.9 , recall the optimal transition of GCT is

$$
\lambda_{*}(\gamma, \beta)=\inf \bigcup_{f \in L_{0}^{p}(\phi)} \mathcal{R}(f, \gamma, \beta, \cdot)
$$

We define the optimal transition of soft thresholding analogously:

$$
\lambda_{s, *}(\gamma, \beta):=\inf \bigcup_{t \geq 0} \mathcal{R}\left(\eta_{s}(\cdot, t), \gamma, \beta, \cdot\right)
$$

Similarly to Corollary 2.9, the infimum is achieved for a specific thresholding level $t_{*}(\gamma, \beta)$.
Surprisingly, soft thresholding is close to optimal: the left and right plots of Figure 4 are visually nearly indistinguishable, and the discrepancy between the plotted curves is less than $.05 .{ }^{6}$ Based on these calculations, we advocate soft thresholding; it is likely more robust to model misspecification than $f^{*}$, which is tailored to (1.7). Figure 4 also illustrates Corollary 2.10: as $\beta \rightarrow \infty, \lambda_{*}(\gamma, \beta)$ converges to the BBP transition.

As the optimal soft thresholding level depends on $\lambda$ and $\beta$, which are generally unknown, we propose to adaptively select the threshold to maximize the normalized spectral gap $\left(\lambda_{1}-\lambda_{2}\right) / \lambda_{2}$. This procedure is motivated by Corollaries 2.5 and 2.6: since the presence of an outlier eigenvalue indicates that $\psi^{\prime}\left(s_{+}\right)>0$, it is natural to choose the threshold that produces the most distinct outlier. This procedure compares well to optimal fixed-level thresholding, GCT with the kernel $\eta_{s}(\cdot, t_{*}(\gamma, \beta))$-see Figure 5 .

Empirically, the phenomena we uncover are not restricted to $\sqrt{m} v_{1}, \ldots, \sqrt{m} v_{m} \in\{-1,+1\}$ as in (1.7). In Figure 6, we generate $\boldsymbol{\xi} \in \mathbb{R}^{m}$ according to

$$
\xi_{1}, \ldots, \xi_{m} \stackrel{i.i.d.}{\sim} \operatorname{unif}([-2,-1] \cup[1,2])
$$

and set $\boldsymbol{v}_{[1: m]}=\boldsymbol{\xi} /\|\boldsymbol{\xi}\|_{2}$. The left plot depicts the cosine similarity of GCT with the kernel $\eta_{s}(\cdot, 2)$, which experiences a phase transition. The right plot depicts support recovery, measured as follows:

$$
\frac{1}{m}\left(\left|\operatorname{supp}(\widetilde{\boldsymbol{v}}) \cap \operatorname{supp}(\boldsymbol{v})\right|-\left|\operatorname{supp}(\widetilde{\boldsymbol{v}}) \cap([p] \backslash \operatorname{supp}(\boldsymbol{v}))\right|\right)
$$

where $\widetilde{\boldsymbol{v}}$ is defined in Corollary 2.6. That is, (3.2) counts the number of correctly identified entries minus the number of false positives, normalized by $m$. The signal detection and recovery thresholds seem aligned, as we expect from Section 2.3.
