# 4 Deterministic Equivalents 

In this section, we state our main technical contribution. Let $\boldsymbol{R}_{0}(f, z)$ denote the resolvents of $\boldsymbol{K}_{0}(f)$, defined as

$$
\boldsymbol{R}_{0}(f, z):=\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0}(f)-z \mathbf{I}_{p}\right)^{-1}
$$

The resolvent is holomorphic at all points $z \in \mathbb{C}$ not equal to an eigenvalue of $\boldsymbol{K}_{0}(f)$ (Theorem 1.5 of [41]). Recalling the Stieltjes transform $s(z)$ of $\mu$, we define the related quantities

$$
\bar{s}(z):=\frac{s(z)}{1+a_{1} \gamma s(z)}, \quad \bar{\bar{s}}(z):=\bar{s}(z)\left(1+\gamma-a_{1} \gamma \bar{s}(z)\right)
$$

Theorem 4.1. Let $f$ be an odd polynomial and (2.2) hold. For any $z \in \mathbb{C}^{+}$and deterministic vectors $\boldsymbol{u}, \boldsymbol{w} \in \mathbb{S}^{p-1}$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0}(f, z) \boldsymbol{w}-\langle\boldsymbol{u}, \boldsymbol{w}\rangle s(z)=O_{\prec}\left(n^{-1 / 2}\right) \\
& \boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{R}_{0}(f, z) \boldsymbol{w}-\langle\boldsymbol{u}, \boldsymbol{w}\rangle \hat{s}(z)=O_{\prec}\left(n^{-1 / 2}\right) \\
& \boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{R}_{0}(f, z) \boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{w}-\langle\boldsymbol{u}, \boldsymbol{w}\rangle \hat{s}(z)=O_{\prec}\left(n^{-1 / 2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Moreover, the convergence is uniform in $z$ on compact subsets $\mathcal{C} \subset \mathbb{C}$ such that $\inf _{z \in \mathcal{C}} \operatorname{Re}(z)>\lambda_{+}$.
Theorem 4.2. Let $f$ be an odd polynomial and (2.2) hold. For any $z \in \mathbb{C}^{+}$and deterministic vectors $\boldsymbol{u}, \boldsymbol{w} \in \mathbb{S}^{p-1}$ such that $\|\boldsymbol{u}\|_{0} \vee\|\boldsymbol{w}\|_{0} \lesssim m$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0}(f, z)(\boldsymbol{K}(f)-\boldsymbol{A}(f)) \boldsymbol{R}_{0}(f, z) \boldsymbol{w}=O_{\prec}\left(n^{-1 / 2}\right) \\
& \boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{R}_{0}(f, z)(\boldsymbol{K}(f)-\boldsymbol{A}(f)) \boldsymbol{R}_{0}(f, z) \boldsymbol{w}=O_{\prec}\left(n^{-1 / 2}\right) \\
& \boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{R}_{0}(f, z)(\boldsymbol{K}(f)-\boldsymbol{A}(f)) \boldsymbol{R}_{0}(f, z) \boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{w}=O_{\prec}\left(n^{-1 / 2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Moreover, the convergence is uniform in $z$ on compact subsets $\mathcal{C} \subset \mathbb{C}$ such that $\inf _{z \in \mathcal{C}} \operatorname{Re}(z)>\lambda_{+}$. The proofs of Theorems 4.1 and 4.2 are deferred to Appendix A.

# 5 Proofs
### 5.1 Proof of Theorems 2.1 and 2.2

Throughout this section, we assume $f$ is an odd polynomial, $L:=\operatorname{deg}(f)$, and (2.2) holds.
We shall show that all terms of (2.4) are vanishing in operator norm except those with indices $(\ell, k)$ of the form $(0, k)$ or $(\ell, \ell)$. In contrast, in the setting where $\boldsymbol{v}$ is distributed uniformly on $\mathbb{S}^{p-1}$, only those terms with $(\ell, k)$ equal to $(0,1)$ or $(\ell, \ell)$ are non negligible.

Proof of Theorem 2.1. Rearranging (2.4), we have the following decomposition of $\boldsymbol{K}(f)$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
\boldsymbol{K}(f)= & a_{1}(\boldsymbol{Y}-\operatorname{diag}(\boldsymbol{Y}))+\sum_{\ell=3}^{L} \frac{a_{\ell}}{\sqrt{\ell!}} n^{(\ell-1) / 2}\left(\boldsymbol{X}^{\odot \ell}-\operatorname{diag}\left(\boldsymbol{X}^{\odot \ell}\right)\right)+\boldsymbol{K}_{0}\left(f-a_{1} h_{1}\right) \\
& +\sum_{\ell=1}^{L} \sum_{k=1}^{L-\ell} \frac{a_{\ell+k}}{k!} \sqrt{\frac{(\ell+k)!}{\ell!}}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0}\left(h_{\ell}\right) \odot(\sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{X})^{\odot k}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Recalling that $\boldsymbol{A}(f):=a_{1}\left(\boldsymbol{Y}-\mathbf{I}_{p}\right)+\tau \cdot \boldsymbol{v} \boldsymbol{v}^{\top}+\boldsymbol{K}_{0}\left(f-a_{1} h_{1}\right)$, it suffices to demonstrate that
(1) $\left\|\operatorname{diag}\left(\boldsymbol{Y}\right)-\mathbf{I}_{p}\right\|_{2} \prec n^{-1 / 2}$,
(2) $\left\|n^{(\ell-1) / 2}\left(\boldsymbol{X}^{\odot \ell}-\operatorname{diag}\left(\boldsymbol{X}^{\odot \ell}\right)\right)-(\lambda-1)^{\ell} \beta_{n}^{-(\ell-1)} \boldsymbol{v} \boldsymbol{v}^{\top}\right\|_{2} \prec n^{-1 / 4}$ for $\ell \in\{3, \ldots, L\}$,
(3) $\left\|\boldsymbol{K}_{0}\left(h_{\ell}\right) \odot(\sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{X})^{\odot k}\right\|_{2} \prec n^{-1 / 4}$ for $\ell \in[L]$ and $k \in[L-\ell]$.

We shall refer to these bounds as claims (1)-(3).
Expanding $\boldsymbol{X}=\boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{1 / 2} \boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{1 / 2}-\boldsymbol{S}$ using $\boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{1 / 2}=(\sqrt{\lambda}-1) \boldsymbol{v} \boldsymbol{v}^{\top}+\mathbf{I}_{p}$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\boldsymbol{X} & =(\sqrt{\lambda}-1)^{2}\left(\boldsymbol{v}^{\top} \boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{v}\right) \cdot \boldsymbol{v} \boldsymbol{v}^{\top}+(\sqrt{\lambda}-1)\left(\boldsymbol{v} \boldsymbol{v}^{\top} \boldsymbol{S}+\boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{v} \boldsymbol{v}^{\top}\right) \\
& =c \cdot \boldsymbol{v} \boldsymbol{v}^{\top}+(\sqrt{\lambda}-1)\left(\boldsymbol{v}(\boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{v}-\boldsymbol{v})^{\top}+(\boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{v}-\boldsymbol{v}) \boldsymbol{v}^{\top}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $c:=(\sqrt{\lambda}-1)^{2}\left(\boldsymbol{v}^{\top} \boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{v}\right)+2(\sqrt{\lambda}-1)$ satisfies $|c-(\lambda-1)| \prec n^{-1 / 2}$ since $\boldsymbol{v}^{\top} \boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{v} \sim n^{-1} \chi_{n}^{2}$. Writing the coordinates of $\boldsymbol{w}:=\boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{v}-\boldsymbol{v}$ as

$$
w_{j}=\sum_{i=1}^{p} \boldsymbol{S}_{i j} v_{i}-v_{j}=\frac{v_{j}}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(z_{i j}^{2}-1\right)+\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} z_{i j}\left(\boldsymbol{z}_{i}^{\top} \boldsymbol{v}-z_{i j} v_{j}\right)
$$

the independence of $\left\{z_{i j}\right\}_{i \in[n]}$ and $\left\{\boldsymbol{z}_{i}^{\top} \boldsymbol{v}-z_{i j} v_{j}\right\}_{i \in[n]}$ implies $w_{j}$ is an average of i.i.d. sub-exponential variables. Therefore, using a Hoeffding inequality and a union bound,

$$
\sup _{j \in[\rho]}\left|w_{j}\right|=O_{\prec}\left(n^{-1 / 2}\right)
$$

Similarly bounding $\|$ diag $(\boldsymbol{S})-\mathbf{I}_{p} \|_{2}$, we obtain claim (1):

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\|\operatorname{diag}(\boldsymbol{Y})-\mathbf{I}_{p}\right\|_{2} & \leq\left\|\operatorname{diag}(\boldsymbol{S})-\mathbf{I}_{p}\right\|_{2}+\|\operatorname{diag}(\boldsymbol{X})\|_{2} \\
& \leq \sup _{j \in[p]}\left(\left|n^{-1} \boldsymbol{z}_{j}^{\top} \boldsymbol{z}_{j}-1\right|+c v_{j}^{2}+2(\sqrt{\lambda}-1)\left|v_{j} w_{j}\right|\right) \\
& \prec n^{-1 / 2}
\end{aligned}
$$

Now, consider the expansion

$$
\boldsymbol{X}^{\odot \ell}=\sum_{\substack{k_{1}, k_{2}, k_{3} \in[\ell] \\ k_{1}+k_{2}+k_{3}=\ell}}\binom{\ell}{k_{1}, k_{2}, k_{3}} c^{k_{1}}(\sqrt{\lambda}-1)^{k_{2}+k_{3}}\left(\boldsymbol{v}^{\odot\left(k_{1}+k_{2}\right)} \odot \boldsymbol{w}^{\odot k_{3}}\right)\left(\boldsymbol{v}^{\odot\left(k_{1}+k_{3}\right)} \odot \boldsymbol{w}^{\odot k_{2}}\right)^{\top}
$$

the first term of which is $c^{\ell} m^{-(\ell-1)} \boldsymbol{v} \boldsymbol{v}^{\top}$ (corresponding to $k_{1}=\ell, k_{2}=k_{3}=0$ ). Using (5.3), for $k_{1} \in[\ell]$ and $k_{2} \in\{0\} \cup[\ell]$, we have the bounds

$$
\left\|\boldsymbol{v}^{\odot k_{1}} \odot \boldsymbol{w}^{\odot k_{2}}\right\|_{2} \prec \frac{1}{m^{\left(k_{1}-1\right) / 2} n^{k_{2} / 2}}, \quad\left\|\boldsymbol{w}^{\odot k_{1}}\right\|_{2} \prec \frac{1}{n^{\left(k_{1}-1\right) / 2}}
$$

implying that terms of (5.5) with $k_{2}+k_{3}>0$ are $O_{\prec}\left(n^{-\ell / 2+1 / 4}\right)$. Thus,

$$
\left\|n^{(\ell-1) / 2} \boldsymbol{X}^{\odot \ell}-c^{\ell} \beta_{n}^{-(\ell-1)} \boldsymbol{v} \boldsymbol{v}^{\top}\right\|_{2} \prec n^{-1 / 4}
$$

Claim (2) now follows from $|c-(\lambda-1)| \prec n^{-1 / 2}$ and $\|\operatorname{diag}(\boldsymbol{X})\|_{2} \prec n^{-1 / 2}$, shown in (5.4).
Claim (3) is a consequence of Theorem 1.6 of [26], the sparsity of $\boldsymbol{v}$, and the bound

$$
\left\|\boldsymbol{K}_{0}\left(h_{\ell}\right) \odot \boldsymbol{X}^{\odot k}\right\|_{2} \lesssim \sum_{\substack{k_{1}, k_{2}, k_{3} \in[k] \\ k_{1}+k_{2}+k_{3}=k}} c^{k_{1}}\left\|\boldsymbol{K}_{0}\left(h_{\ell}\right) \odot\left(\left(\boldsymbol{v}^{\odot\left(k_{1}+k_{2}\right)} \odot \boldsymbol{w}^{\odot k_{3}}\right)\left(\boldsymbol{v}^{\odot\left(k_{1}+k_{3}\right)} \odot \boldsymbol{w}^{\odot k_{2}}\right)^{\top}\right)\right\|_{2}
$$

Since the Hadamard product satisfies $\boldsymbol{A} \odot\left(\boldsymbol{x} \boldsymbol{y}^{\top}\right)=\operatorname{diag}(\boldsymbol{x}) \boldsymbol{A} \operatorname{diag}(\boldsymbol{y})$, for $k_{2}+k_{3}>0$,

$$
n^{k / 2}\left\|\boldsymbol{K}_{0}\left(h_{\ell}\right) \odot\left(\left(\boldsymbol{v}^{\odot\left(k_{1}+k_{2}\right)} \odot \boldsymbol{w}^{\odot k_{3}}\right)\left(\boldsymbol{v}^{\odot\left(k_{1}+k_{3}\right)} \odot \boldsymbol{w}^{\odot k_{2}}\right)^{\top}\right)\right\|_{2} \prec \frac{1}{m^{\left(k_{2}+k_{3}\right) / 2}}\left\|\boldsymbol{K}_{0}\left(h_{\ell}\right)\right\|_{2}
$$

where we used (5.3), that the operator norm of a diagonal matrix is the maximum absolute entry, and $n^{k_{1} / 2} m^{-k_{1}} \asymp 1$. For $k_{2}=k_{3}=0$, we have

$$
n^{k / 2}\left\|\boldsymbol{K}_{0}\left(h_{\ell}\right) \odot\left(\boldsymbol{v}^{\odot k}\left(\boldsymbol{v}^{\odot k}\right)^{\top}\right)\right\|_{2}=n^{k / 2} m^{-k}\left\|\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0}\left(h_{\ell}\right)\right)_{[1: m, 1: m]}\right\|_{2}
$$

Theorem 1.6 of [26] yields

$$
\left\|\boldsymbol{K}_{0}\left(h_{\ell}\right)\right\|_{2} \prec 1, \quad\left\|\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0}\left(h_{\ell}\right)\right)_{[1: m, 1: m]}\right\|_{2} \prec m^{-1 / 2}
$$

Thus, $\left\|\boldsymbol{K}_{0}\left(h_{\ell}\right) \odot(\sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{X})^{\odot k}\right\|_{2} \prec n^{-1 / 4}$, completing the proof.

Let $\boldsymbol{R}(f, z)$ denote the resolvent of $\boldsymbol{K}(f)$, defined analogously to $\boldsymbol{R}_{0}(f, z)$ :

$$
\boldsymbol{R}(f, z):=\left(\boldsymbol{K}(f)-z \mathbf{I}_{p}\right)^{-1}
$$

Lemma 5.1. For any $\varepsilon, D>0$, there exists $n_{\varepsilon, D} \in \mathbb{N}$ such that

$$
\mathbb{P}\left(\left\|\boldsymbol{K}_{0}(f)\right\|_{2}>\left(1+\varepsilon\right) \lambda_{+}\right) \leq n^{-D}, \quad \forall n \geq n_{\varepsilon, D}
$$

The proof of Lemma 5.1, which is a slight extension of Section 6 of [26], is given in Appendix B.
Drawing upon $[8,12,27,48]$, we prove Theorem 2.2 in two stages: eigenvalue results,

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\left|\lambda_{1}-\psi\left(s_{+}\right)\right| \prec n^{-1 / 2}, & \psi^{\prime}\left(s_{+}\right)>0 \\
\lambda_{1} \xrightarrow{a . s} \lambda_{+}, & \psi^{\prime}\left(s_{+}\right) \leq 0
\end{array}
$$

and eigenvector results,

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\left\langle\boldsymbol{u}_{1}, \boldsymbol{v}\right\rangle^{2}=\theta^{2}\left(s_{+}\right)+O_{\prec}\left(n^{-1 / 2}\right), & \psi^{\prime}\left(s_{+}\right)>0 \\
u_{1 i}=\theta\left(s_{+}\right) v_{i}+O_{\prec}\left(n^{-1 / 2}\right), & \psi^{\prime}\left(s_{+}\right)>0 \\
\left\langle\boldsymbol{u}_{1}, \boldsymbol{v}\right\rangle \xrightarrow{a . s} 0, & \psi^{\prime}\left(s_{+}\right) \leq 0
\end{array}
$$

For brevity, we often suppress the arguments of matrices such as $\boldsymbol{K}_{0}(f)$ and $\boldsymbol{R}_{0}(f, z)$.
Proof of (5.10). Assume $\psi^{\prime}\left(s_{+}\right)>0$ and define the contours

$$
\mathcal{C}_{n}:=\left\{z \in \mathbb{C}:\left|z-\psi\left(s_{+}\right)\right|=\delta_{n}\right\}
$$

where (1) $\delta_{n} \rightarrow 0$ and (2) there exists $\varepsilon>0$ such that $\delta_{n} \geq n^{-1 / 2+\varepsilon}$. We shall prove $\psi\left(s_{+}\right)>\lambda_{+}$and $\mathcal{C}_{n}$ encircles exactly one eigenvalue of $\boldsymbol{K}$ with probability $1-n^{-D}$ (for any $D>0$ ). Furthermore, considering an arbitrary, bounded contour $\mathcal{C}$ such that $\inf _{z \in \mathcal{C}} \operatorname{Re}(z)>\lambda_{+}$and $\mathcal{C} \cap \mathcal{C}_{n}=\emptyset$, an identical argument yields $\mathcal{C}$ encircles no eigenvalues of $\boldsymbol{K}$ with probability $1-n^{-D}$. This establishes $\left|\lambda_{1}-\psi\left(s_{+}\right)\right| \prec n^{-1 / 2}$. Proof that $\psi^{\prime}\left(s_{+}\right) \leq 0$ leads to $\lambda_{1} \xrightarrow{a . s} \lambda_{+}$is similar and omitted.

From Corollary 1.2 and the discussion on page 19 of [48], we have that $\psi\left(s_{+}\right)>\lambda_{+}$if and only if $s_{+} \in\left(-1 /\left(a_{1} \gamma\right), 0\right)$ and $\psi^{\prime}\left(s_{+}\right)>0$. Noticing that $s_{+}$is negative and increasing in $\lambda$ on $[1, \infty)$, ${ }^{7}$

$$
\frac{\partial s_{+}}{\partial \lambda}=\frac{1}{2 \tau \gamma}\left(-1+\frac{a_{1}(\lambda+\gamma-1)+\tau}{\sqrt{\left(a_{1}(\lambda+\gamma-1)+\tau\right)^{2}-4 a_{1} \tau \gamma}}\right)>0
$$

we obtain the lower bound

$$
s_{+}>\frac{-a_{1} \gamma-\tau+\sqrt{\left(a_{1} \gamma+\tau\right)^{2}-4 a_{1} \tau \gamma}}{2 a_{1} \tau \gamma}=\frac{-a_{1} \gamma-\tau+\left|a_{1} \gamma-\tau\right|}{2 a_{1} \tau \gamma} \geq-\frac{1}{a_{1} \gamma}
$$

By Theorem 2.1, we may write $\boldsymbol{K}(f)=\boldsymbol{V} \boldsymbol{\Lambda} \boldsymbol{V}^{\top}+\boldsymbol{K}_{0}(f)+\boldsymbol{\Delta}$, where

$$
\boldsymbol{V}:=\left[\begin{array}{ll}
\boldsymbol{v} & \boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{v}
\end{array}\right], \quad \boldsymbol{\Lambda}:=\left[\begin{array}{cc}
a_{1}(\sqrt{\lambda}-1)^{2}+\tau & a_{1}(\sqrt{\lambda}-1) \\
a_{1}(\sqrt{\lambda}-1) & 0
\end{array}\right]
$$

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{7}$ The partial derivative (5.14) is symbolic and ignores the dependence of $\tau$ on $\lambda$.

and $\boldsymbol{\Delta}:=\boldsymbol{K}-\boldsymbol{A}+(c-(\lambda-1)) \boldsymbol{v} \boldsymbol{v}^{\top}$. Denoting $\boldsymbol{R}_{\boldsymbol{\Delta}}:=\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0}+\boldsymbol{\Delta}-z \mathbf{I}_{p}\right)^{-1}$, as $\psi\left(s_{+}\right)>\lambda_{+}$, Lemma 5.1 and the bound $\|\boldsymbol{\Delta}\|_{2} \prec n^{-1 / 4}$ imply $\boldsymbol{R}_{0}$ and $\boldsymbol{R}_{\boldsymbol{\Delta}}$ are holomorphic within $\mathcal{C}_{n}$ with probability $1-n^{-D}$ and

$$
\sup _{z \in \mathcal{C}_{n}}\left(\left\|\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right\|_{2} \vee\left\|\boldsymbol{R}_{\Delta}\right\|_{2}\right) \prec 1
$$

From these facts and the Woodbury identity, which yields

$$
\boldsymbol{R}=\boldsymbol{R}_{\Delta}-\boldsymbol{R}_{\Delta} \boldsymbol{V}\left(\boldsymbol{\Lambda}^{-1}+\boldsymbol{V}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{\Delta} \boldsymbol{V}\right)^{-1} \boldsymbol{V}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{\Delta}
$$

we have that any eigenvalue of $\boldsymbol{K}$ (equivalently, a pole of $\boldsymbol{R}$ ) encircled by $\mathcal{C}_{n}$ is a pole of $\left(\boldsymbol{\Lambda}^{-1}+\right.$ $\left.\boldsymbol{V}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{\Delta} \boldsymbol{V}\right)^{-1}$. Thus,

$$
\operatorname{det}\left(\boldsymbol{\Lambda}^{-1}+\boldsymbol{V}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{\Delta} \boldsymbol{V}\right)=0
$$

Our approach is to relate solutions of (5.17) to the roots of

$$
\xi(z):=\operatorname{det}\left(\boldsymbol{\Lambda}^{-1}+\left[\begin{array}{ll}
s(z) & \delta(z) \\
\delta(z) & \delta(z)
\end{array}\right]\right)=-\frac{1+\tau s(z)+a_{1} s(z)(\lambda+\gamma+\tau \gamma s(z)-1)}{a_{1}^{2}\left(1+a_{1} \gamma s(z)\right)(\sqrt{\lambda}-1)^{2}}
$$

(this is our master equation, in the parlance of [8]). Specifically, we will prove the following claims:
(1) $\sup _{z \in \mathcal{C}_{n}}\left|\operatorname{det}\left(\boldsymbol{\Lambda}^{-1}+\boldsymbol{V}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{\Delta} \boldsymbol{V}\right)-\xi(z)\right| \prec n^{-1 / 2}$,
(2) $\inf _{z \in \mathcal{C}_{n}}|\xi(z)| \gtrsim \delta_{n}$,
(3) Within $\mathcal{C}_{n}, \psi\left(s_{+}\right)$is the unique root of $\xi$ and has multiplicity one, and $\xi$ is holomorphic.

Then, Rouché's theorem and the bound

$$
\sup _{z \in \mathcal{C}_{n}}\left|\operatorname{det}\left(\boldsymbol{\Lambda}^{-1}+\boldsymbol{V}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{\Delta} \boldsymbol{V}\right)-\xi(z)\right|<\inf _{z \in \mathcal{C}_{n}}|\xi(z)|
$$

which holds with probability $1-n^{-D}$, imply that $\mathcal{C}_{n}$ encircles equal numbers of roots of $\xi(z)$ and $\operatorname{det}\left(\boldsymbol{\Lambda}^{-1}+\boldsymbol{V}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{\Delta} \boldsymbol{V}\right)$. This completes the proof-Rouché's theorem is applicable as $\boldsymbol{R}_{\Delta}$ is holomorphic within $\mathcal{C}_{n}$.

On $\mathcal{C}_{n}$, Theorem 4.2 implies $\left\|\boldsymbol{V}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{\Delta} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{V}\right\|_{2} \prec n^{-1 / 2}$, and (5.15), $\|\boldsymbol{S}\|_{2} \prec 1$, and $\|\boldsymbol{\Delta}\|_{2} \prec n^{-1 / 4}$ imply $\left\|\boldsymbol{V}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{\Delta} \boldsymbol{R}_{\Delta} \boldsymbol{\Delta} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{V}\right\|_{2} \prec\|\boldsymbol{\Delta}\|_{2}^{2} \prec n^{-1 / 2}$. Thus, using the relations $\boldsymbol{R}_{\Delta}^{-1}-\boldsymbol{R}_{0}^{-1}=\boldsymbol{\Delta}$ and

$$
\boldsymbol{R}_{\Delta}=\boldsymbol{R}_{0}-\boldsymbol{R}_{\Delta} \boldsymbol{\Delta} \boldsymbol{R}_{0}=\boldsymbol{R}_{0}-\boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{\Delta} \boldsymbol{R}_{0}+\boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{\Delta} \boldsymbol{R}_{\Delta} \boldsymbol{\Delta} \boldsymbol{R}_{0}
$$

we obtain

$$
\begin{gathered}
\left\|\boldsymbol{V}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{\Delta} \boldsymbol{V}-\boldsymbol{V}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{V}\right\|_{2} \prec n^{-1 / 2} \\
\sup _{z \in \mathcal{C}_{n}}\left|\operatorname{det}\left(\boldsymbol{\Lambda}^{-1}+\boldsymbol{V}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{\Delta} \boldsymbol{V}\right)-\operatorname{det}\left(\boldsymbol{\Lambda}^{-1}+\boldsymbol{V}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{V}\right)\right| \prec n^{-1 / 2}
\end{gathered}
$$

Moreover, Theorem 4.1 implies

$$
\begin{gathered}
\left\|\boldsymbol{V}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{V}-\left[\begin{array}{ll}
s(z) & \delta(z) \\
\delta(z) & \delta(z)
\end{array}\right]\right\|_{2} \prec n^{-1 / 2} \\
\sup _{z \in \mathcal{C}_{n}}\left|\operatorname{det}\left(\boldsymbol{\Lambda}^{-1}+\boldsymbol{V}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{V}\right)-\xi(z)\right| \prec n^{-1 / 2}
\end{gathered}
$$

Claim (1) follows from (5.20) and (5.21).
As the numerator of $\xi$ is quadratic in $s(z)$, the roots of $\xi$ are $\psi\left(s_{+}\right)$and $\psi\left(s_{-}\right)$, where

$$
s_{-}:=\frac{-a_{1}(\lambda+\gamma-1)-\tau-\sqrt{\left(a_{1}(\lambda+\gamma-1)+\tau\right)^{2}-4 a_{1} \tau \gamma}}{2 a_{1} \tau \gamma}
$$

Similarly to (5.14), $s_{-}$is decreasing in $\lambda$ on $[1, \infty)$, giving the upper bound

$$
s_{-}<\frac{-a_{1} \gamma-\tau-\sqrt{\left(a_{1} \gamma+\tau\right)^{2}-4 a_{1} \tau \gamma}}{2 a_{1} \tau \gamma} \leq \frac{-a_{1} \gamma-\tau}{2 a_{1} \tau \gamma} \leq-\frac{1}{a_{1} \gamma}
$$

and establishing claim (3). Now, we write $\xi$ as

$$
\xi(z)=-\frac{\left(s(z)-s_{+}\right)\left(s(z)-s_{-}\right)}{a_{1}^{2}\left(1+a_{1} \gamma s(z)\right)(\sqrt{\lambda}-1)^{2}}
$$

On $\mathcal{C}_{n}$, we have $\left|s(z)-s_{-}\right| \asymp\left|1+a_{1} \gamma s(z)\right| \asymp 1$. Furthermore,

$$
s(z)-s_{+}=\int\left(\frac{1}{\lambda-z}-\frac{1}{\lambda-\psi\left(s_{+}\right)}\right) d \mu(z)=\int \frac{z-\psi\left(s_{+}\right)}{(\lambda-z)\left(\lambda-\psi\left(s_{+}\right)\right)} d \mu(z)
$$

$\left|z-\psi\left(s_{+}\right)\right|=\delta_{n}$, and $\left|(\lambda-z)\left(\lambda-\psi\left(s_{+}\right)\right)\right| \asymp 1$ for $\lambda \in \operatorname{supp}(\mu)$, implying

$$
\inf _{z \in \mathcal{C}_{n}}\left|s(z)-s_{+}\right| \gtrsim \delta_{n}
$$

Claim (2) follows from (5.22) and (5.24).
Lemma 5.2. Define the function

$$
\begin{aligned}
\zeta(z) & :=s(z)-\left[\begin{array}{l}
s(z) \\
\hat{s}(z)
\end{array}\right]^{\top}\left(\boldsymbol{\Lambda}^{-1}+\left[\begin{array}{ll}
s(z) & \hat{s}(z) \\
\hat{s}(z) & \hat{s}(z)
\end{array}\right]\right)^{-1}\left[\begin{array}{l}
s(z) \\
\hat{s}(z)
\end{array}\right] \\
& =\frac{s(z)\left(1+a_{1} \gamma s(z)\right)}{1+\tau s(z)+a_{1} s(z)(\lambda+\gamma+\tau \gamma s(z)-1)}
\end{aligned}
$$

For any $z \in \mathbb{C}^{+}$and deterministic vector $\boldsymbol{u} \in \mathbb{S}^{p-1}$,

$$
\left|\boldsymbol{u}^{\top}\left(\boldsymbol{R}-\boldsymbol{R}_{\boldsymbol{\Delta}}\right) \boldsymbol{u}-\langle\boldsymbol{u}, \boldsymbol{v}\rangle^{2}(\zeta(z)-s(z))\right| \prec \frac{1}{\sqrt{n}}|\langle\boldsymbol{u}, \boldsymbol{v}\rangle|+\frac{1}{n}
$$

Moreover, the convergence is uniform in $z$ on compact subsets $\mathcal{C} \subset \mathbb{C}$ such that $\inf _{z \in \mathcal{C}} \operatorname{Re}(z)>\lambda_{+}$.
Proof. The claim is a consequence of the following equations, which are derived from Theorems 4.1 and 4.2, (5.16), and (5.19)-(5.21):

$$
\begin{aligned}
\boldsymbol{u}^{\top}\left(\boldsymbol{R}-\boldsymbol{R}_{\boldsymbol{\Delta}}\right) \boldsymbol{u}=-\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{\boldsymbol{\Delta}} \boldsymbol{V}\left(\boldsymbol{\Lambda}^{-1}+\boldsymbol{V}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{\boldsymbol{\Delta}} \boldsymbol{V}\right)^{-1} \boldsymbol{V}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{\boldsymbol{\Delta}} \boldsymbol{u} \\
\left\|\left(\boldsymbol{\Lambda}^{-1}+\boldsymbol{V}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{\boldsymbol{\Delta}} \boldsymbol{V}\right)^{-1}-\left(\boldsymbol{\Lambda}^{-1}+\left[\begin{array}{ll}
s(z) & \hat{s}(z) \\
\hat{s}(z) & \hat{s}(z)
\end{array}\right]\right)^{-1}\right\|_{2} \prec n^{-1 / 2} \\
\boldsymbol{V}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{\boldsymbol{\Delta}} \boldsymbol{u}=\boldsymbol{V}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{u}-\boldsymbol{V}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{\Delta} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{u}+\boldsymbol{V}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{\Delta} \boldsymbol{R}_{\boldsymbol{\Delta}} \boldsymbol{\Delta} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{u} \\
=\langle\boldsymbol{u}, \boldsymbol{v}\rangle\left[\begin{array}{l}
s(z) \\
\hat{s}(z)
\end{array}\right]+O_{\prec}\left(n^{-1 / 2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Proof of (5.11). Let $\mathcal{C}$ denote a positively-oriented contour that encircles $\psi\left(s_{+}\right)$and is bounded away from $\operatorname{supp}(\mu)$; as in the proof of (5.10), with probability $1-n^{-D}, \mathcal{C}$ encircles only the maximum eigenvalue of $\boldsymbol{K}$. Cauchy's integral formula and Lemma 5.2 therefore yield

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\langle\boldsymbol{u}_{1}, \boldsymbol{v}\right\rangle^{2} & =-\frac{1}{2 \pi i} \oint_{\mathcal{C}} \boldsymbol{v}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}(z) \boldsymbol{v} d z \\
& =-\frac{1}{2 \pi i} \oint_{\mathcal{C}} \zeta(z) d z+O_{\prec}\left(n^{-1 / 2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Here, the first equality is a particular case of (1.16) in [41] and the second uses the fact that $\boldsymbol{R}_{\boldsymbol{\Delta}}$ and $s(z)$ are holomorphic on and within $\mathcal{C}$, implying

$$
\oint_{\mathcal{C}} \boldsymbol{v}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{\Delta} \boldsymbol{v} d z=\oint_{\mathcal{C}} s(z) d z=0
$$

Since $\psi\left(s_{+}\right)$is the unique pole of $\zeta(z)$ in $\mathcal{C}$ (recall that $\left.\xi\left(\psi\left(s_{+}\right)\right)=0\right)$,

$$
\left\langle\boldsymbol{u}_{1}, \boldsymbol{v}\right\rangle^{2}=\lim _{z \rightarrow \psi\left(s_{+}\right)}\left(z-\psi\left(s_{+}\right)\right) \zeta(z)+O_{\prec}\left(n^{-1 / 2}\right)
$$

We compute the limit on the right-hand side using L'Hôpital's rule, as in Corollary 2 in [48]:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\lim _{z \rightarrow \psi\left(s_{+}\right)}\left(z-\psi\left(s_{+}\right)\right) \zeta(z) & =\lim _{z \rightarrow \psi\left(s_{+}\right)} \frac{-s(z)\left(1+a_{1} \gamma s(z)\right)-\left(z-\psi\left(s_{+}\right)\right)\left(1+2 a_{1} \gamma s(z)\right) s^{\prime}(z)}{\left(a_{1}(\lambda+\gamma-1)+\tau\right) s^{\prime}(z)+2 a_{1} \tau \gamma s(z) s^{\prime}(z)} \\
& =\lim _{z \rightarrow \psi\left(s_{+}\right)} \frac{-s(z)\left(1+a_{1} \gamma s(z)\right)}{\left(a_{1}(\lambda+\gamma-1)+\tau\right) s^{\prime}(z)+2 a_{1} \tau \gamma s(z) s^{\prime}(z)}
\end{aligned}
$$

The second equality follows from the continuity of $s(z)$ on $\left(\lambda_{+}, \infty\right)$, implying $s(z) \rightarrow s_{+}$as $z \rightarrow$ $\psi\left(s_{+}\right)$, and the observation

$$
\begin{gathered}
\lim _{z \rightarrow \psi\left(s_{+}\right)} a_{1}(\lambda+\gamma-1)+\tau+2 a_{1} \tau \gamma s(z)=a_{1}(\lambda+\gamma-1)+\tau+2 a_{1} \tau \gamma s_{+}>0 \\
\lim _{z \rightarrow \psi\left(s_{+}\right)} \frac{\left(z-\psi\left(s_{+}\right)\right)\left(1+2 a_{1} \gamma s(z)\right)}{a_{1}(\lambda+\gamma-1)+\tau+2 a_{1} \tau \gamma s(z)}=0
\end{gathered}
$$

We complete the proof using the equation

$$
\begin{aligned}
\lim _{z \rightarrow \psi\left(s_{+}\right)} s^{\prime}(z) & =\lim _{z \rightarrow \psi\left(s_{+}\right)}\left(\frac{1}{s^{2}(z)}-\frac{a_{1}^{2} \gamma}{\left(1+a_{1} \gamma s(z)\right)^{2}}-\gamma\left(\|f\|_{\phi}^{2}-a_{1}^{2}\right)\right)^{-1} \\
& =\left(\frac{1}{s_{+}^{2}}-\frac{a_{1}^{2} \gamma}{\left(1+a_{1} \gamma s_{+}\right)^{2}}-\gamma\left(\|f\|_{\phi}^{2}-a_{1}^{2}\right)\right)^{-1}
\end{aligned}
$$

which is obtained by differentiating (1.9). By (5.28) and (5.29),

$$
\lim _{z \rightarrow \psi\left(s_{+}\right)}\left(z-\psi\left(s_{+}\right)\right) \zeta(z)=\theta^{2}\left(s_{+}\right)
$$

Finally, we note that (5.28), $s_{+} \in\left(-1 /\left(a_{1} \gamma\right), 0\right)$, and $s^{\prime}\left(s_{+}\right)>0$ imply $\theta^{2}\left(s_{+}\right)>0$.
Proof of (5.12). Assume $\left\langle\boldsymbol{u}_{1}, \boldsymbol{v}\right\rangle \geq 0$ without loss of generality and let $\mathcal{C}$ denote a contour as in the proof of (5.11). Similarly to (5.26)-(5.30),

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\langle\boldsymbol{u}_{1}, \boldsymbol{v}\right\rangle u_{1 i} & =-\frac{1}{2 \pi i} \oint_{\mathcal{C}} \boldsymbol{e}_{i}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}(z) \boldsymbol{v} d z=-\frac{v_{i}}{2 \pi i} \oint_{\mathcal{C}} \zeta(z) d z+O_{\prec}\left(n^{-1 / 2}\right) \\
& =\theta^{2}\left(s_{+}\right) v_{i}+O_{\prec}\left(n^{-1 / 2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

The claim now follows from (5.11) and the fact that the limit of $\theta\left(s_{+}\right)$is strictly positive:

$$
\begin{gathered}
\left\langle\boldsymbol{u}_{1}, \boldsymbol{v}\right\rangle-\theta\left(s_{+}\right)=\frac{\left\langle\boldsymbol{u}_{1}, \boldsymbol{v}\right\rangle^{2}-\theta^{2}\left(s_{+}\right)}{\left\langle\boldsymbol{u}_{1}, \boldsymbol{v}\right\rangle+\theta\left(s_{+}\right)}=O_{\prec}\left(n^{-1 / 2}\right) \\
u_{1 i}=\frac{\theta^{2}\left(s_{+}\right) v_{i}}{\theta\left(s_{+}\right)+O_{\prec}\left(n^{-1 / 2}\right)}+O_{\prec}\left(n^{-1 / 2}\right)=\theta\left(s_{+}\right) v_{i}+O_{\prec}\left(n^{-1 / 2}\right)
\end{gathered}
$$

Lemma 5.3. Let $\boldsymbol{W} \in \mathbb{R}^{p \times(p-1)}$ be a semi-orthogonal matrix such that $\boldsymbol{W} \boldsymbol{W}^{\top}+\boldsymbol{v} \boldsymbol{v}^{\top}=\mathbf{I}_{p}$. For any $z \in \mathbb{C}^{+}$,

$$
\boldsymbol{v}^{\top} \boldsymbol{K} \boldsymbol{W}\left(z \mathbf{I}_{p-1}-\boldsymbol{W}^{\top} \boldsymbol{K} \boldsymbol{W}\right)^{-1} \boldsymbol{W}^{\top} \boldsymbol{K} \boldsymbol{v}=z+(\zeta(z))^{-1}-a_{1}(\lambda-1)-\tau+O_{\prec}\left(n^{-1 / 4}\right)
$$

Moreover, the convergence is uniform in z on compact subsets of $\mathbb{C}^{+}$.
Proof. As the proof is similar to that of Lemma 5.2, we only sketch the argument. By the Woodbury identity, we have

$$
\boldsymbol{v}^{\top} \boldsymbol{K} \boldsymbol{W}\left(z \mathbf{I}_{p-1}-\boldsymbol{W}^{\top} \boldsymbol{K} \boldsymbol{W}\right)^{-1} \boldsymbol{W}^{\top} \boldsymbol{K} \boldsymbol{v}=z+\left(\boldsymbol{v}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R} \boldsymbol{v}\right)^{-1}-\boldsymbol{v}^{\top} \boldsymbol{K} \boldsymbol{v}
$$

Theorem 2.1, Lemma 5.2, and the bound $\left|\boldsymbol{v}^{\top} \boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{v}-1\right| \prec n^{-1 / 2}$ yield $\boldsymbol{v}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R} \boldsymbol{v}=\zeta(z)+O_{\prec}\left(n^{-1 / 2}\right)$ and

$$
\begin{aligned}
\boldsymbol{v}^{\top} \boldsymbol{K} \boldsymbol{v} & =\boldsymbol{v}^{\top}\left(\boldsymbol{V} \boldsymbol{\Lambda} \boldsymbol{V}^{\top}+\boldsymbol{K}_{0}+\boldsymbol{\Delta}\right) \boldsymbol{v} \\
& =\boldsymbol{\Lambda}_{11}+2 \boldsymbol{\Lambda}_{12}+\boldsymbol{v}^{\top} \boldsymbol{K}_{0} \boldsymbol{v}+O_{\prec}\left(n^{-1 / 4}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

The claim now follows from $\left|\boldsymbol{v}^{\top} \boldsymbol{K}_{0} \boldsymbol{v}\right| \prec n^{-1 / 2}$, which is proved similarly to (4.1).

Proof of (5.13). Let $\boldsymbol{W} \in \mathbb{R}^{p \times(p-1)}$ be a semi-orthogonal matrix such that $\boldsymbol{W} \boldsymbol{W}^{\top}+\boldsymbol{v} \boldsymbol{v}^{\top}=\mathbf{I}_{p}$. Similarly to Section 2 of [52], we have

$$
\left[\begin{array}{cc}
\boldsymbol{v}^{\top} \boldsymbol{K} \boldsymbol{v} & \boldsymbol{v}^{\top} \boldsymbol{K} \boldsymbol{W} \\
\boldsymbol{W}^{\top} \boldsymbol{K} \boldsymbol{v} & \boldsymbol{W}^{\top} \boldsymbol{K} \boldsymbol{W}
\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{c}
\boldsymbol{v}^{\top} \boldsymbol{u}_{1} \\
\boldsymbol{W}^{\top} \boldsymbol{u}_{1}
\end{array}\right]=\lambda_{1}\left[\begin{array}{c}
\boldsymbol{v}^{\top} \boldsymbol{u}_{1} \\
\boldsymbol{W}^{\top} \boldsymbol{u}_{1}
\end{array}\right]
$$

yielding $\boldsymbol{W}^{\top} \boldsymbol{u}_{1}=\boldsymbol{u}_{1}^{\top} \boldsymbol{v}\left(\lambda_{1} \mathbf{I}_{p-1}-\boldsymbol{W}^{\top} \boldsymbol{K} \boldsymbol{W}\right)^{-1} \boldsymbol{W}^{\top} \boldsymbol{K} \boldsymbol{v}$ (the inverse exists almost surely). Furthermore, using the normalization condition $\left\langle\boldsymbol{u}_{1}, \boldsymbol{v}\right\rangle^{2}+\left\|\boldsymbol{W}^{\top} \boldsymbol{u}_{1}\right\|_{2}^{2}=1$, we obtain the equation

$$
\left\langle\boldsymbol{u}_{1}, \boldsymbol{v}\right\rangle^{2}\left(1+\boldsymbol{v}^{\top} \boldsymbol{K} \boldsymbol{W}\left(\lambda_{1} \mathbf{I}_{p-1}-\boldsymbol{W}^{\top} \boldsymbol{K} \boldsymbol{W}\right)^{-2} \boldsymbol{W}^{\top} \boldsymbol{K} \boldsymbol{v}\right)=1
$$

We shall prove

$$
\boldsymbol{v}^{\top} \boldsymbol{K} \boldsymbol{W}\left(\lambda_{1} \mathbf{I}_{p-1}-\boldsymbol{W}^{\top} \boldsymbol{K} \boldsymbol{W}\right)^{-2} \boldsymbol{W}^{\top} \boldsymbol{K} \boldsymbol{v} \xrightarrow{a . s} \infty
$$

implying $\left\langle\boldsymbol{u}_{1}, \boldsymbol{v}\right\rangle^{2} \xrightarrow{a . s} 0$ by (5.33).
By Lemma 5.3,

$$
\boldsymbol{v}^{\top} \boldsymbol{K} \boldsymbol{W}\left(z \mathbf{I}_{p-1}-\boldsymbol{W}^{\top} \boldsymbol{K} \boldsymbol{W}\right)^{-1} \boldsymbol{W}^{\top} \boldsymbol{K} \boldsymbol{v} \xrightarrow{a . s} z+(\zeta(z))^{-1}-a_{1}(\lambda-1)-\tau
$$

where the convergence is uniform in $z$ on compact subsets of $\mathbb{C}^{+}$. Since $\lambda_{1} \xrightarrow{a . s} \lambda_{+}$by (5.11) and uniform convergence of an analytic sequence implies uniform convergence of the derivative,

$$
\boldsymbol{v}^{\top} \boldsymbol{K} \boldsymbol{W}\left(\left(\lambda_{1}+i \eta\right) \mathbf{I}_{p-1}-\boldsymbol{W}^{\top} \boldsymbol{K} \boldsymbol{W}\right)^{-2} \boldsymbol{W}^{\top} \boldsymbol{K} \boldsymbol{v} \xrightarrow{a . s} 1-\frac{\zeta^{\prime}\left(\lambda_{+}+i \eta\right)}{\zeta^{2}\left(\lambda_{+}+i \eta\right)}
$$

for any $\eta>0$. Since $s\left(\lambda_{+}+i \eta\right) \rightarrow s_{0}$ and $\left|s^{\prime}\left(\lambda_{+}+i \eta\right)\right| \rightarrow \infty$ as $\eta \rightarrow 0$, and

$$
1-\frac{\zeta^{\prime}(z)}{\zeta^{2}(z)}=\frac{1+a_{1} \gamma s(z)\left(2+a_{1}(\lambda+\gamma-1) s(z)\right)}{s^{2}(z)\left(1+a_{1} \gamma s(z)\right)^{2}} \cdot s^{\prime}(z)
$$

we obtain the lower bound

$$
\begin{aligned}
\liminf _{n \rightarrow \infty} & \left|\boldsymbol{v}^{\top} \boldsymbol{K} \boldsymbol{W}\left(\left(\lambda_{1}+i \eta\right) \mathbf{I}_{p-1}-\boldsymbol{W}^{\top} \boldsymbol{K} \boldsymbol{W}\right)^{-2} \boldsymbol{W}^{\top} \boldsymbol{K} \boldsymbol{v}\right| \\
& \geq \liminf _{\eta \rightarrow 0} \liminf _{n \rightarrow \infty}\left|\boldsymbol{v}^{\top} \boldsymbol{K} \boldsymbol{W}\left(\left(\lambda_{+}+i \eta\right) \mathbf{I}_{p-1}-\boldsymbol{W}^{\top} \boldsymbol{K} \boldsymbol{W}\right)^{-2} \boldsymbol{W}^{\top} \boldsymbol{K} \boldsymbol{v}\right| \stackrel{a . s}{=} \infty
\end{aligned}
$$

The claim now follows from

$$
\boldsymbol{v}^{\top} \boldsymbol{K} \boldsymbol{W}\left(\lambda_{1} \mathbf{I}_{p-1}-\boldsymbol{W}^{\top} \boldsymbol{K} \boldsymbol{W}\right)^{-2} \boldsymbol{W}^{\top} \boldsymbol{K} \boldsymbol{v}>\left|\boldsymbol{v}^{\top} \boldsymbol{K} \boldsymbol{W}\left(\left(\lambda_{1}+i \eta\right) \mathbf{I}_{p-1}-\boldsymbol{W}^{\top} \boldsymbol{K} \boldsymbol{W}\right)^{-2} \boldsymbol{W}^{\top} \boldsymbol{K} \boldsymbol{v}\right|
$$

# 5.2 Proof of Theorems 2.3 and 2.4 

Throughout this section, we assume $f$ satisfies the conditions of Theorem 2.3.
Lemma 5.4. There exist odd polynomials $\left\{f_{\ell}\right\}_{\ell \in \mathbb{N}}$ such that $\left\|f-f_{\ell}\right\|_{\phi} \rightarrow 0$ and

$$
\lim _{\ell \rightarrow \infty} \limsup _{n \rightarrow \infty}\left\|\boldsymbol{K}(f)-\boldsymbol{K}\left(f_{\ell}\right)\right\|_{2}=\lim _{\ell \rightarrow \infty} \limsup _{n \rightarrow \infty}\left\|\boldsymbol{K}_{0}(f)-\boldsymbol{K}_{0}\left(f_{\ell}\right)\right\|_{2} \stackrel{a . s}{=} 0
$$

Lemma 5.4, the proof of which is deferred to Appendix C, builds on [26] in that (1) Theorems 1.4 and 1.6 of [26] pertain only to the kernel matrix of noise $\boldsymbol{K}_{0}(f)$ and (2) Theorem 1.4 assumes $f$ is continuously differentiable.

Proof of Theorem 2.3. Let $\left\{f_{\ell}\right\}_{\ell \in \mathbb{N}}$ denote the polynomials given by Lemma 5.4 and $a_{\ell, k}:=\left\langle f_{\ell}, h_{k}\right\rangle_{\phi}$. We shall bound the right-hand side of

$$
\|\boldsymbol{K}(f)-\boldsymbol{A}(f)\|_{2} \leq\|\boldsymbol{K}(f)-\boldsymbol{K}\left(f_{\ell}\right)\|_{2}+\left\|\boldsymbol{K}\left(f_{\ell}\right)-\boldsymbol{A}\left(f_{\ell}\right)\right\|_{2}+\left\|\boldsymbol{A}\left(f_{\ell}\right)-\boldsymbol{A}(f)\right\|_{2}
$$

Since Lemma 5.4 and Theorem 2.1 state that

$$
\lim _{\ell \rightarrow \infty} \limsup _{n \rightarrow \infty}\left\|\boldsymbol{K}(f)-\boldsymbol{K}\left(f_{\ell}\right)\right\|_{2} \stackrel{a . s .}{=} \lim _{n \rightarrow \infty}\left\|\boldsymbol{K}\left(f_{\ell}\right)-\boldsymbol{A}\left(f_{\ell}\right)\right\|_{2} \stackrel{a . s .}{=} 0
$$

we focus on the third term of (5.37):

$$
\left\|\boldsymbol{A}(f)-\boldsymbol{A}\left(f_{\ell}\right)\right\|_{2} \leq\left|a_{1}-a_{\ell, 1}\right| \cdot\left\|\boldsymbol{Y}-\mathbf{I}_{p}-\boldsymbol{K}_{0}\left(h_{1}\right)\right\|_{2}+\left|\tau-\tau\left(f_{\ell}\right)\right|+\left\|\boldsymbol{K}_{0}(f)-\boldsymbol{K}_{0}\left(f_{\ell}\right)\right\|_{2}
$$

where $\tau\left(f_{\ell}\right):=\sum_{k=1}^{\ell} a_{\ell, k}(\lambda-1)^{k} /\left(\sqrt{k!} \beta^{k-1}\right)$. By the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality and $\left\|f-f_{\ell}\right\|_{\phi} \rightarrow 0$, we have $\left|a_{1}-a_{\ell, 1}\right| \rightarrow 0$ and

$$
\left|\tau-\tau\left(f_{\ell}\right)\right| \leq\left(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty}\left(\frac{(\lambda-1)^{k}}{\sqrt{k!} \beta^{k-1}}\right)^{2} \cdot \sum_{k=1}^{\infty}\left(a_{k}-a_{\ell, k}\right)^{2}\right)^{1 / 2} \lesssim\left\|f-f_{\ell}\right\|_{\phi} \rightarrow 0
$$

as $\ell \rightarrow \infty$. Thus, using the almost-sure bound $\left\|\boldsymbol{Y}-\mathbf{I}_{p}-\boldsymbol{K}_{0}\left(h_{1}\right)\right\|_{2} \leq\|\boldsymbol{X}\|_{2}+\left\|\operatorname{diag}(\boldsymbol{S})-\mathbf{I}_{p}\right\|_{2} \lesssim 1$,

$$
\lim _{\ell \rightarrow \infty} \limsup _{n \rightarrow \infty}\left\|\boldsymbol{A}(f)-\boldsymbol{A}\left(f_{\ell}\right)\right\|_{2} \stackrel{a . s .}{=} 0
$$

Lemma 5.5. The operator norm of the kernel matrix of noise satisfies

$$
\left\|\boldsymbol{K}_{0}(f)\right\|_{2} \xrightarrow{a.s} \lambda_{+}
$$

Proof. Let $\left\{f_{\ell}\right\}_{\ell \in \mathbb{N}}$ denote the polynomials given by Lemma 5.4 and $\lambda_{+}\left(f_{\ell}\right)$ the supremum of the support of the LSD of $\boldsymbol{K}_{0}\left(f_{\ell}\right)$; by Theorem 1.7 of [26], $\left\|\boldsymbol{K}_{0}\left(f_{\ell}\right)\right\|_{2} \xrightarrow{a.s} \lambda_{+}\left(f_{\ell}\right)$. As $\left\|f-f_{\ell}\right\|_{\phi} \rightarrow 0$ and the solutions to $\psi^{\prime}(s)=0$ depend continuously on the coefficients of equation (1.10), we have $\lambda_{+}\left(f_{\ell}\right) \rightarrow \lambda_{+}$as $\ell \rightarrow \infty$. Thus,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \limsup _{n \rightarrow \infty}\left\|\boldsymbol{K}_{0}(f)\right\|_{2} \leq \lim _{\ell \rightarrow \infty} \limsup _{n \rightarrow \infty}\left(\left\|\boldsymbol{K}_{0}\left(f_{\ell}\right)\right\|_{2}+\left\|\boldsymbol{K}_{0}(f)-\boldsymbol{K}_{0}\left(f_{\ell}\right)\right\|_{2}\right) \stackrel{a.s}{=} \lambda_{+} \\
& \liminf _{n \rightarrow \infty} \left\|\boldsymbol{K}_{0}(f)\right\|_{2} \geq \lim _{\ell \rightarrow \infty} \liminf _{n \rightarrow \infty}\left(\left\|\boldsymbol{K}_{0}\left(f_{\ell}\right)\right\|_{2}-\left\|\boldsymbol{K}_{0}(f)-\boldsymbol{K}_{0}\left(f_{\ell}\right)\right\|_{2}\right) \stackrel{a.s}{=} \lambda_{+}
\end{aligned}
$$

Theorem 2.4 follows from Theorems 2.1 and 2.3, Lemmas 5.4 and 5.5, Weyl's inequality, and the Davis-Kahan theorem.

# 5.3 Proofs for Section 2.3 

Recall $\psi(s)$ and $s_{+}$, defined in Corollary 1.2 and Theorem 2.2, respectively. In this section, for clarity, we write $\left[\psi^{\prime}\left(s_{+}\right)\right](f, \lambda)$ to reflect that $s_{+}$and $\psi^{\prime}(s)$ each depend on $f$ and $\lambda$. Lemma 2.7 is a consequence of Corollary 2.6 and Lemma 5.6:

Lemma 5.6. If $\left[\psi^{\prime}\left(s_{+}\right)\right](f, \lambda)>0$, there exists $L \in \mathbb{N}$ such that $\left[\psi^{\prime}\left(s_{+}\right)\right]\left(f_{\ell}, \lambda\right)>0$ for all $\ell \geq L$.
This follows from $\tau\left(f_{\ell}, \beta, \lambda\right) \rightarrow \tau(f, \beta, \lambda)$ and $\left[\psi^{\prime}\left(s_{+}\right)\right]\left(f_{\ell}\right) \rightarrow\left[\psi^{\prime}\left(s_{+}\right)\right](f)$ as $\ell \rightarrow \infty$.
Proof of Lemma 2.8. In this proof, we write $s_{+}(\lambda, \tau(\lambda))$ as $f, \gamma$, and $\beta$ are fixed. Since $s_{+}(\lambda, \tau)$ is increasing in each argument (see (5.14)), $s_{+}(\lambda, \tau(\lambda))$ is increasing in $\lambda$. Recalling that $s_{+} \in$ $\left(-1 /\left(a_{1}, \gamma\right), 0\right)$ and $\psi^{\prime}(s)$ has a unique root $s_{0}$ in this interval, it follows that

$$
\mathcal{R}(f, \gamma, \beta, \cdot)=\left\{\lambda \geq 1: \psi^{\prime}\left(s_{+}(\lambda, \tau(\lambda))>0\right\}=\left(\lambda_{*}(f, \gamma, \beta), \infty\right)\right.
$$

where we define

$$
\lambda_{*}(f, \gamma, \beta):=\inf \left\{\lambda \geq 1: \psi^{\prime}\left(s_{+}(\lambda, \tau(\lambda))>0\right\}\right.
$$

Proof of Corollary 2.9. Let $f_{\lambda}$ have Hermite coefficients $\left\langle f_{\lambda}, h_{1}\right\rangle_{\phi}=0$ and

$$
\left\langle f_{\lambda}, h_{k}\right\rangle_{\phi}= \begin{cases}\frac{(\lambda-1)^{k}}{\sqrt{k!} \beta^{k-1}} & k \text { odd } \\ 0 & k \text { even }\end{cases} \quad k \neq 1
$$

Given any $f \in L_{o}^{2}(\phi)$, consider the kernel

$$
\tilde{f}_{\lambda}:=\left\langle f, h_{1}\right\rangle_{\phi} h_{1}+\frac{\sqrt{\|f\|_{\phi}^{2}-\left\langle f, h_{1}\right\rangle_{\phi}^{2}}}{\left\|f_{\lambda}\right\|_{\phi}} f_{\lambda}
$$

The orthogonality of the Hermite polynomials implies $\left\|\bar{f}_{\lambda}\right\|_{\phi}=\|f\|_{\phi}$ and $\left\langle\bar{f}_{\lambda}, h_{1}\right\rangle_{\phi}=\left\langle f, h_{1}\right\rangle_{\phi}$. Moreover, by Cauchy-Schwarz inequality,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\tau(f, \beta, \lambda) & =\sum_{k=3}^{\infty} \frac{\left\langle f, h_{k}\right\rangle_{\phi}(\lambda-1)^{k}}{\sqrt{k!} \beta^{k-1}} \\
& \leq \sqrt{\|f\|_{\phi}^{2}-\left\langle f, h_{1}\right\rangle_{\phi}^{2}}\left(\sum_{k=3}^{\infty} \frac{(\lambda-1)^{2 k}}{k!\beta^{2(k-1)}}\right)^{1 / 2} \\
& =\sqrt{\|f\|_{\phi}^{2}-\left\langle f, h_{1}\right\rangle_{\phi}^{2}}\left\|f_{\lambda}\right\|_{\phi} \\
& =\tau\left(\bar{f}_{\lambda}, \beta, \lambda\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Similarly to the proof of Lemma 2.8, these properties imply

$$
\left[\psi^{\prime}\left(s_{+}\right)\right](f, \lambda) \leq\left[\psi^{\prime}\left(s_{+}\right)\right]\left(\bar{f}_{\lambda}, \lambda\right), \quad \forall \lambda \in \mathcal{R}(f, \gamma, \beta, \cdot)
$$

Thus, since $\mathcal{R}(f, \gamma, \beta, \cdot)$ is invariant under rescalings of $f$,

$$
\bigcup_{f \in L_{0}^{2}(\phi)} \mathcal{R}(f, \gamma, \beta, \cdot)=\bigcup_{a \geq 0} \bigcup_{\lambda>1} \mathcal{R}\left(a h_{1}+f_{\lambda}, \gamma, \beta, \cdot\right)
$$

Consider $\left\{\left(a_{k}, \lambda_{k}\right)\right\}_{k \in \mathbb{N}}$ such that

$$
\lim _{k \rightarrow \infty} \inf \mathcal{R}\left(a_{k} h_{1}+f_{\lambda_{k}}, \gamma, \beta, \cdot\right)=\inf _{a \geq 0, \lambda \geq 1} \mathcal{R}\left(a h_{1}+f_{\lambda}, \gamma, \beta, \cdot\right)
$$

Assuming $\left\{\left\|a_{k} h_{1}+f_{\lambda_{k}}\right\|_{\phi}\right\}_{k \in \mathbb{N}}$ is bounded without loss of generality, there exists a convergent subsequence $\left\{\left(a_{k_{\ell}}, \lambda_{k_{\ell}}\right)\right\}_{\ell \in \mathbb{N}} ;$ let $a_{k_{\ell}} \rightarrow a_{*} \geq 0$ and $\lambda_{k_{\ell}} \rightarrow \lambda_{*}>1$ as $\ell \rightarrow \infty$, and define $f^{*}:=$ $a_{*} h_{1}+f_{\lambda_{*}}$. As $\left[\psi^{\prime}\left(s_{+}\right)\right](f, \lambda)$ is continuous in the Hermite coefficients of $f$, we conclude that

$$
\mathcal{R}\left(a_{k_{\ell}} h_{1}+f_{\lambda_{k_{\ell}}}, \gamma, \beta, \cdot\right) \rightarrow \mathcal{R}\left(f^{*}, \gamma, \beta, \cdot\right)
$$

Together with Lemma 2.8, this yields

$$
\bigcup_{f \in L_{0}^{2}(\phi)} \mathcal{R}(f, \gamma, \beta, \cdot)=\mathcal{R}\left(f^{*}, \gamma, \beta, \cdot\right)
$$

To complete the proof, we note that (5.40) implies

$$
\lambda_{*}=\inf \left\{\lambda \geq 1:\left[\psi^{\prime}\left(s_{+}\right)\right]\left(f^{*}, \lambda\right)>0\right\}
$$

Proof of Corollary 2.10. We first establish monotonicity of $\beta \mapsto \lambda_{*}(\gamma, \beta)$. Let $L_{o,+}^{2}(\phi) \subset L_{o}^{2}(\phi)$ denote the subset of kernel functions with non-negative Hermite coefficients. By Lemma 2.8 and Corollary 2.9,

$$
\left(\lambda_{*}(\gamma, \beta), \infty\right)=\bigcup_{f \in L_{0}^{2}(\phi)} \mathcal{R}(f, \gamma, \beta, \cdot)=\bigcup_{f \in L_{o,+}^{2}(\phi)} \mathcal{R}(f, \gamma, \beta, \cdot)=\bigcup_{f \in L_{o,+}^{2}(\phi)}\left(\lambda_{*}(f, \gamma, \beta), \infty\right)
$$

For all $\lambda>1$ and $f \in L_{o,+}^{2}(\phi), \tau(f, \beta, \lambda)$ is non-increasing in $\beta$, implying (similarly to the proof of Corollary 2.9) that $\beta \mapsto \lambda_{*}(f, \gamma, \beta)$ is non-decreasing. Consequently, $\beta \mapsto \lambda_{*}(\gamma, \beta)$ is nondecreasing. Since $\lambda_{*}(\gamma, \beta)$ is upper-bounded by the BBP transition (corresponding to the identity kernel), $\lim _{\beta \rightarrow \infty} \lambda_{*}(\gamma, \beta)$ exists and is at most $1+\sqrt{\gamma}$.

Fix $\lambda>\lim _{\beta \rightarrow \infty} \lambda_{*}(\gamma, \beta)$; it suffices to prove that $\lambda \geq 1+\sqrt{\gamma}$. By (5.43), there exists a sequence of sparsity levels and kernels $\left\{\left(\beta_{k}, f_{k}\right)\right\}_{k \in \mathbb{N}}$ satisfying $\beta_{k} \rightarrow \infty$ and, for all $k \in \mathbb{N}, \lambda \in \mathcal{R}\left(f_{k}, \gamma, \beta_{k}, \cdot\right)$, $f_{k} \in L_{o,+}^{2}(\phi)$, and $\left\|f_{k}\right\|_{\phi}=1$. For brevity, denote

$$
a_{1, k}:=\left\langle f_{k}, h_{1}\right\rangle_{\phi}, \quad \tau_{k}:=\tau\left(f_{k}, \beta_{k}, \lambda\right), \quad s_{k}:=s_{+}\left(f_{k}, \beta_{k}, \lambda\right)
$$

Note that (1) if there exists $k \in \mathbb{N}$ such that $\tau_{k}=0$, the claim follows from $\mathcal{R}\left(f_{k}, \gamma, \beta_{k}, \cdot\right)=$ $(1+\sqrt{\gamma}, \infty),(2) \tau_{k} \rightarrow 0$ as $k \rightarrow \infty$ since $\left\|f_{k}\right\|_{\phi}=1$, and (3) $a_{1, k}>0$ for all sufficiently large $k$. The third fact follows from Remark 2.2, which implies that if $a_{1, k}=0, \lambda \in \mathcal{R}\left(f_{k}, \gamma, \beta_{k}, \cdot\right)$ if and only if $\tau_{k}>\sqrt{\gamma}$ (which contradicts $\tau_{k} \rightarrow 0$ ). Henceforth, we assume without loss of generality that $a_{1, k}, \tau_{k}>0$. From Corollary 1.2 and Theorem 2.2, recall that $\psi^{\prime}\left(s_{k}\right)>0, s_{k} \in\left(-1 /\left(a_{1, k} \gamma\right), 0\right)$, and

$$
\begin{aligned}
s_{k} & =\frac{1}{2 a_{1, k} \gamma \tau_{k}}\left(-a_{1, k}(\lambda+\gamma-1)-\tau_{k}+\sqrt{\left(a_{1, k}(\lambda+\gamma-1)+\tau_{k}\right)^{2}-4 a_{1, k} \gamma \tau_{k}}\right) \\
\psi^{\prime}\left(s_{k}\right) & =\frac{1}{s_{k}^{2}}-\frac{a_{1, k}^{2} \gamma}{\left(1+a_{1, k} \gamma s_{k}\right)^{2}}-\gamma\left(1-a_{1, k}^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

We claim that $a_{1, k}$ is bounded away from zero. Taking a subsequence if necessary, let $a_{1, k} \rightarrow$ $a_{1} \in(0,1]$ as $k \rightarrow \infty$. Then,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\lim _{k \rightarrow \infty} s_{k} & =-\frac{1}{a_{1}(\lambda+\gamma-1)} \\
\lim _{k \rightarrow \infty} s_{k}^{2} \psi^{\prime}\left(s_{k}\right) & =1-\frac{\gamma}{(\lambda-1)^{2}}-\frac{\gamma\left(1-a_{1}^{2}\right)}{a_{1}^{2}(\lambda+\gamma-1)^{2}} \leq 1-\frac{\gamma}{(\lambda-1)^{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Since $s_{k}^{2} \psi\left(s_{k}\right) \geq 0$, this implies $\lambda \geq 1+\sqrt{\gamma}$. In fact, as the inequality is strict unless $a_{1}=1$ (corresponding to the identity kernel), we conclude that PCA is the unique optimal kernel in the limit $\beta \rightarrow \infty$.

It remains to prove $a_{1, k} \asymp 1$. Assume towards a contradiction that $a_{1, k} \rightarrow 0$. There are three cases to consider: (1) $a_{1, k} / \tau_{k} \rightarrow 0$, (2) $a_{1, k} / \tau_{k} \rightarrow \infty$, and (3) $a_{1, k} / \tau_{k} \asymp 1$. In each case, we will argue that $s_{k} \rightarrow-\infty$, implying

$$
\liminf _{k \rightarrow \infty} \psi^{\prime}\left(s_{k}\right) \leq \lim _{k \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{s_{k}^{2}}-\gamma\left(1-a_{1, k}^{2}\right)=-\gamma
$$

and contradicting $\psi^{\prime}\left(s_{k}\right)>0$.
(1) If $a_{1, k} / \tau_{k} \rightarrow 0$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
s_{k} & =\frac{1}{2 a_{1, k} \gamma}\left(-(\lambda+\gamma-1) \frac{a_{1, k}}{\tau_{k}}-1+\sqrt{1+2(\lambda+\gamma-1) \frac{a_{1, k}}{\tau_{k}}+(\lambda+\gamma-1)^{2} \frac{a_{1, k}^{2}}{\tau_{k}^{2}}-\frac{4 \gamma a_{1, k}}{\tau_{k}}}\right) \\
& =-\frac{1}{\tau_{k}}+O\left(\frac{a_{1, k}}{\tau_{k}^{2}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

This yields $s_{k} \rightarrow-\infty$ since $\tau_{k}>0$ tends to zero.
(2) If $a_{1, k} / \tau_{k} \rightarrow \infty$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
a_{1, k} s_{k} & =\frac{a_{1, k}(\lambda+\gamma-1)+\tau_{k}}{2 \gamma \tau_{k}}\left(\sqrt{1-\frac{4 a_{1, k} \gamma \tau_{k}}{\left(a_{1, k}(\lambda+\gamma-1)+\tau_{k}\right)^{2}}}-1\right) \\
& =-\frac{a_{1, k}(\lambda+\gamma-1)+\tau_{k}}{2 \gamma \tau_{k}}\left(\frac{2 \gamma \tau_{k}}{a_{1, k}(\lambda+\gamma-1)^{2}}+O\left(\frac{\tau_{k}^{2}}{a_{1, k}^{2}}\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

This yields $a_{1, k} s_{k} \rightarrow-1 /(\lambda+\gamma-1)$ and $s_{k} \rightarrow-\infty$.

(3) If $a_{1, k} / \tau_{k} \asymp 1$, similarly to the previous case, we have $a_{1, k} s_{k} \asymp 1$ and $s_{k} \rightarrow-\infty$.

# A Proof of Theorems 4.1 and 4.2 

Throughout this section, $f$ and $g$ are odd polynomials and $L:=\operatorname{deg}(f) \vee \operatorname{deg}(g)$. For simplicity, the proofs given below assume $\boldsymbol{u}=\boldsymbol{w}$ and $z \in \mathbb{C}^{+}$, implying $\left\|\boldsymbol{R}_{0}(f, z)\right\|_{2} \leq \operatorname{Im}(z)^{-1}<\infty$. Given a compact set $\mathcal{C} \subset \mathbb{C}$ such that $\inf _{z \in \mathcal{C}} \operatorname{Re}(z)>\lambda_{+}$, the extension from pointwise to uniform convergence is made by restricting calculations to the event $\left\{\left\|\boldsymbol{K}_{0}(f)\right\|_{2} \leq(1+\varepsilon) \lambda_{+}\right\}$, which occurs with probability at least $1-n^{-D}$ by Lemma 5.1. As $\varepsilon, D>0$ are arbitrary, this implies

$$
\sup _{z \in \mathcal{C}}\left\|\boldsymbol{R}_{0}(f, z)\right\|_{2} \prec 1
$$

The generalizations of (4.1) and (4.3) to the asymmetric case $\boldsymbol{u} \neq \boldsymbol{w}$ follows by applying symmetric results to $\boldsymbol{u}+\boldsymbol{w}$. For example,

$$
\begin{aligned}
(\boldsymbol{u}+\boldsymbol{w})^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0}(f, z)(\boldsymbol{u}+\boldsymbol{w}) & =\|\boldsymbol{u}+\boldsymbol{w}\|_{2}^{2} s(z)+O_{\prec}\left(n^{-1 / 2}\right) \\
& =2 s(z)+2 \boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0}(f, z) \boldsymbol{w}+O_{\prec}\left(n^{-1 / 2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

yielding $\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0}(f, z) \boldsymbol{w}=\left(\|\boldsymbol{u}+\boldsymbol{w}\|_{2}^{2} / 2-1\right) s(z)+O_{\prec}\left(n^{-1 / 2}\right)=\langle\boldsymbol{u}, \boldsymbol{w}\rangle s(z)+O_{\prec}\left(n^{-1 / 2}\right)$. The generalization of (4.2) follows from slight modifications of arguments in Sections A. 1 and A.2.

Theorem 4.1 is an immediate consequence of Lemmas A. 1 and A.2:
Lemma A.1. For any $z \in \mathbb{C}^{+}$and deterministic vectors $\boldsymbol{u}, \boldsymbol{w} \in \mathbb{S}^{p-1}$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0}(f, z) \boldsymbol{w}-\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0}(f, z) \boldsymbol{w}\right]=O_{\prec}\left(n^{-1 / 2}\right) \\
& \boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{R}_{0}(f, z) \boldsymbol{w}-\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{R}_{0}(f, z) \boldsymbol{w}\right]=O_{\prec}\left(n^{-1 / 2}\right) \\
& \boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{R}_{0}(f, z) \boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{w}-\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{R}_{0}(f, z) \boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{w}\right]=O_{\prec}\left(n^{-1 / 2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Lemma A.2. Let $p / n=\gamma+O\left(n^{-1 / 2}\right)$. For any $z \in \mathbb{C}^{+}, \varepsilon>0$, and deterministic vectors $\boldsymbol{u}, \boldsymbol{w} \in \mathbb{S}^{p-1}$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0}(f, z) \boldsymbol{w}\right]-\langle\boldsymbol{u}, \boldsymbol{w}\rangle s(z)=O\left(n^{-1 / 2+\varepsilon}\right) \\
& \mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{R}_{0}(f, z) \boldsymbol{w}\right]-\langle\boldsymbol{u}, \boldsymbol{w}\rangle \bar{s}(z)=O\left(n^{-1 / 2+\varepsilon}\right) \\
& \mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{R}_{0}(f, z) \boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{w}\right]-\langle\boldsymbol{u}, \boldsymbol{w}\rangle \bar{s}(z)=O\left(n^{-1 / 2+\varepsilon}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Theorem 4.2 is a corollary of Lemmas A.3-A. 5 and the proof of Theorem 2.1. Recalling

$$
\boldsymbol{X}=\boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{1 / 2} \boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{1 / 2}-\boldsymbol{S}=c \cdot \boldsymbol{v} \boldsymbol{v}^{\top}+(\sqrt{\lambda}-1)(\boldsymbol{v}(\boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{v}-\boldsymbol{v})^{\top}+(\boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{v}-\boldsymbol{v}) \boldsymbol{v}^{\top})
$$

with $c:=(\sqrt{\lambda}-1)^{2}\left(\boldsymbol{v}^{\top} \boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{v}\right)+2(\sqrt{\lambda}-1)$, we define $\boldsymbol{K}_{0}^{(m)}(g):=\boldsymbol{K}_{0}(g) \odot(\sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{X})$; the superscript of $\boldsymbol{K}_{0}^{(m)}(g)$ signifies that only the first $m$ rows and columns of this matrix are non-zero.

Lemma A.3. For any $z \in \mathbb{C}^{+}$and deterministic vectors $\boldsymbol{u}, \boldsymbol{w} \in \mathbb{S}^{p-1}$ such that $\|\boldsymbol{u}\|_{0} \vee\|\boldsymbol{w}\|_{0} \lesssim m$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0}(f, z) \boldsymbol{K}_{0}^{(m)}(g) \boldsymbol{R}_{0}(f, z) \boldsymbol{w}-\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0}(f, z) \boldsymbol{K}_{0}^{(m)}(g) \boldsymbol{R}_{0}(f, z) \boldsymbol{w}\right]=O_{\prec}\left(n^{-1 / 2}\right) \\
& \boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{R}_{0}(f, z) \boldsymbol{K}_{0}^{(m)}(g) \boldsymbol{R}_{0}(f, z) \boldsymbol{w}-\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{R}_{0}(f, z) \boldsymbol{K}_{0}^{(m)}(g) \boldsymbol{R}_{0}(f, z) \boldsymbol{w}\right]=O_{\prec}\left(n^{-1 / 2}\right) \\
& \boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{R}_{0}(f, z) \boldsymbol{K}_{0}^{(m)}(g) \boldsymbol{R}_{0}(f, z) \boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{w}-\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{R}_{0}(f, z) \boldsymbol{K}_{0}^{(m)}(g) \boldsymbol{R}_{0}(f, z) \boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{w}\right]=O_{\prec}\left(n^{-1 / 2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Lemma A.4. For any $z \in \mathbb{C}^{+}$and deterministic vectors $\boldsymbol{u}, \boldsymbol{w} \in \mathbb{S}^{p-1}$ such that $\|\boldsymbol{u}\|_{0} \vee\|\boldsymbol{w}\|_{0} \lesssim m$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0}(f, z) \boldsymbol{K}_{0}^{(m)}(g) \boldsymbol{R}_{0}(f, z) \boldsymbol{w}\right]=O\left(n^{-1 / 2+\varepsilon}\right) \\
& \mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{R}_{0}(f, z) \boldsymbol{K}_{0}^{(m)}(g) \boldsymbol{R}_{0}(f, z) \boldsymbol{w}\right]=O\left(n^{-1 / 2+\varepsilon}\right) \\
& \mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{R}_{0}(f, z) \boldsymbol{K}_{0}^{(m)}(g) \boldsymbol{R}_{0}(f, z) \boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{w}\right]=O\left(n^{-1 / 2+\varepsilon}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Lemma A.5. For any $z \in \mathbb{C}^{+}$and deterministic vectors $\boldsymbol{u} \in \mathbb{S}^{p-1}$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0}(f, z)(\boldsymbol{v} \odot(\boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{v}-\boldsymbol{v}))=O_{\prec}\left(n^{-1 / 2}\right) \\
& \boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{R}_{0}(f, z)(\boldsymbol{v} \odot(\boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{v}-\boldsymbol{v}))=O_{\prec}\left(n^{-1 / 2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

The proof of Lemma A. 5 is similar to that of Lemma A. 1 and is omitted.
Henceforth, for brevity, we shall often suppress the arguments of matrices such as $\boldsymbol{K}_{0}(f)$ and $\boldsymbol{R}_{0}(f, z)$.

# A. 1 Proof of Lemma A. 1 

We shall prove (A.3); the proofs of (A.1) and (A.2) are similar and omitted.
Our approach is to express $\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{u}-\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{u}\right]$ as the sum of a martingale difference sequence and then apply the Burkholder inequality (Lemma A.8); this method, applied to sample covariance matrices, is standard in random matrix theory (see Sections 8 and 10 of [4]), although the extension to kernel matrices is involved.

For $j \in[n]$, let $\boldsymbol{S}_{-j}:=\boldsymbol{S}-n^{-1} \boldsymbol{z}_{j} \boldsymbol{z}_{j}^{\top}, \boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}$ denote the kernel matrix of $\boldsymbol{S}_{-j}$ (defined analogously to $\boldsymbol{K}_{0}$ ), and $\boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j}:=\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}-z \mathbf{I}_{p}\right)^{-1}$. Define $\mathcal{F}_{0}:=\emptyset, \mathcal{F}_{j}:=\sigma\left(\left\{z_{1}, \ldots, z_{j}\right\}\right)$, the conditional expectation $\mathbb{E}_{j}(\cdot):=\mathbb{E}\left(\cdot \mid \mathcal{F}_{j}\right)$, and $\alpha_{j}:=\left(\mathbb{E}_{j}-\mathbb{E}_{j-1}\right) \boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{u}$. Then, $\left\{\alpha_{j}\right\}_{j \in[n]}$ is a martingale difference sequence with respect to $\left\{\mathcal{F}_{j}\right\}_{j \in[n]}$ and we have the decomposition

$$
\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{u}-\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{u}\right]=\sum_{j=1}^{n}\left(\mathbb{E}_{j}-\mathbb{E}_{j-1}\right) \boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{u}=\sum_{j=1}^{n} \alpha_{j}
$$

We further expand $\alpha_{j}$ into four terms:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\alpha_{j} & =\left(\mathbb{E}_{j}-\mathbb{E}_{j-1}\right)\left[\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{u}-\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{S}_{-j} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j} \boldsymbol{S}_{-j} \boldsymbol{u}\right] \\
& =\alpha_{j, 1}+2 \alpha_{j, 2}+2 \alpha_{j, 3}+\alpha_{j, 4}
\end{aligned}
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
\alpha_{j, 1} & :=\frac{1}{n^{2}}\left(\mathbb{E}_{j}-\mathbb{E}_{j-1}\right)\left[\left(\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{z}_{j}\right)^{2} \cdot \boldsymbol{z}_{j}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{z}_{j}\right] \\
\alpha_{j, 2} & :=\frac{1}{n}\left(\mathbb{E}_{j}-\mathbb{E}_{j-1}\right)\left[\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{z}_{j} \cdot \boldsymbol{z}_{j}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j} \boldsymbol{S}_{-j} \boldsymbol{u}\right] \\
\alpha_{j, 3} & :=\frac{1}{n}\left(\mathbb{E}_{j}-\mathbb{E}_{j-1}\right)\left[\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{z}_{j} \cdot \boldsymbol{z}_{j}^{\top}\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}-\boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j}\right) \boldsymbol{S}_{-j} \boldsymbol{u}\right] \\
\alpha_{j, 4} & :=\left(\mathbb{E}_{j}-\mathbb{E}_{j-1}\right)\left[\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{S}_{-j}\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}-\boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j}\right) \boldsymbol{S}_{-j} \boldsymbol{u}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

The proof of (A.3) is a consequence of the Burkholder inequality applied to $\left\{\alpha_{j}\right\}_{j \in[n]}$ and the following bound on $\mathbb{E}_{j-1}\left|\alpha_{j}\right|^{k}$ (which we derive by bounding $\alpha_{j 1}, \ldots, \alpha_{j 4}$ ):

Lemma A.6. For each $j \in[n]$, define the random variable

$$
\Gamma_{j}:=1 \vee\left\|\boldsymbol{S}_{-j}\right\|_{2} \vee\left(\sup _{\ell \in[L]}\left\|\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}\left(h_{\ell}\right)\right\|_{2}\right) \vee\left(\sup _{\ell \in[L]} \sqrt{n}\left\|\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}\left(h_{\ell}\right)\right\|_{\infty}\right)
$$

Then,

$$
\mathbb{E}_{j-1}\left|\alpha_{j}\right|^{k} \lesssim \frac{(\log n)^{4 L k}}{n^{k}} \mathbb{E}_{j-1} \Gamma_{j}^{4 k}
$$

Lemma A.7. For all $j \in[n], \varepsilon>0$, and $k \in \mathbb{N}$,

$$
\Gamma_{j} \prec 1, \quad \mathbb{E} \Gamma_{j}^{k} \lesssim n^{\varepsilon}
$$

Lemma A. 8 (Burkholder inequality, Lemma 2.13 of [5]). Let $\left\{\alpha_{j}\right\}_{j=1}^{\infty}$ be a martingale difference sequence with respect to the filtration $\left\{\mathcal{F}_{j}\right\}_{j=1}^{\infty}$, and let $\mathbb{E}_{j}(\cdot)=\mathbb{E}\left(\cdot \mid \mathcal{F}_{j}\right)$. Then, for $k \geq 2$,

$$
\mathbb{E}\left|\sum_{j=1}^{n} \alpha_{j}\right|^{k} \lesssim \mathbb{E}\left[\left(\sum_{j=1}^{n} \mathbb{E}_{j-1}\left|\alpha_{j}\right|^{2}\right)^{k / 2}\right]+\sum_{j=1}^{n} \mathbb{E}\left|\alpha_{j}\right|^{k}
$$

(the implied constant depends only on $k$ ).
Proof of (A.3). By Lemma A. 6 and Jensen's inequality,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sum_{j=1}^{n} \mathbb{E}\left|\alpha_{j}\right|^{k} & \lesssim \frac{(\log n)^{4 L k}}{n^{k-1}} \mathbb{E} \Gamma_{1}^{4 k} \\
\mathbb{E}\left[\left(\sum_{j=1}^{n} \mathbb{E}_{j-1}\left|\alpha_{j}\right|^{2}\right)^{k / 2}\right] & \lesssim \frac{(\log n)^{4 L k}}{n^{k}} \mathbb{E}\left[\left(\sum_{j=1}^{n} \mathbb{E}_{j-1} \Gamma_{j}^{8}\right)^{k / 2}\right] \\
& \lesssim \frac{(\log n)^{4 L k}}{n^{k / 2}} \mathbb{E}\left[\left(\sup _{j \in[n]} \mathbb{E}_{j-1} \Gamma_{j}^{8}\right)^{k / 2}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Now, for $j \in[n]$, let $\widetilde{\Gamma}_{j}$ denote $\Gamma_{j}$ with columns $\boldsymbol{z}_{1}, \ldots, \boldsymbol{z}_{j-1}$ of $\boldsymbol{Z}$ replaced by i.i.d. copies $\tilde{\boldsymbol{z}}_{1}, \ldots, \tilde{\boldsymbol{z}}_{j-1}$, enabling us to write $\mathbb{E}_{j-1} \Gamma_{j}^{8}=\mathbb{E}\left[\widetilde{\Gamma}_{j}^{8} \mid \tilde{z}_{1}, \ldots, \tilde{z}_{n}\right]$ and yielding the bound

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left[\left(\sum_{j=1}^{n} \mathbb{E}_{j-1}\left|\alpha_{j}\right|^{2}\right)^{k / 2}\right] & \lesssim \frac{(\log n)^{4 L k}}{n^{k / 2}} \mathbb{E}\left[\left(\sup _{j \in[n]} \mathbb{E}\left[\widetilde{\Gamma}_{j}^{8} \mid \tilde{z}_{1}, \ldots, \tilde{z}_{n}\right]\right)^{k / 2}\right] \\
& \lesssim \frac{(\log n)^{4 L k}}{n^{k / 2}} \mathbb{E}\left[\sup _{j \in[n]} \widetilde{\Gamma}_{j}^{4 k}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Using Lemma A. 7 and a union bound, for $\varepsilon, D>0$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left[\sup _{j \in[n]} \widetilde{\Gamma}_{j}^{4 k}\right] & \lesssim n^{\varepsilon}+\mathbb{E}\left[\sup _{j \in[n]} \widetilde{\Gamma}_{j}^{4 k} \cdot \mathbf{1}\left(\sup _{j \in[n]} \widetilde{\Gamma}_{j}^{4 k}>n^{\varepsilon}\right)\right] \\
& \lesssim n^{\varepsilon}+\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\sup _{j \in[n]} \widetilde{\Gamma}_{j}^{8 k}\right] \cdot \mathbb{P}\left(\sup _{j \in[n]} \widetilde{\Gamma}_{j}^{4 k}>n^{\varepsilon}\right)\right)^{1 / 2} \\
& \lesssim n^{\varepsilon}+n^{1+\varepsilon-D / 2}
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, applying the Burkholder inequality (Lemma A.8) to (A.15) with (A.18)-(A.20), we obtain

$$
\mathbb{E}\left|\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{u}-\mathbb{E}\left|\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{u}\right|\right|^{k} \lesssim n^{1+\varepsilon-k}+n^{\varepsilon-k / 2}
$$

implying (A.3) by Markov's inequality as $k \geq 2$ is arbitrary.

Lemma A.9. The kernel matrix has the decomposition

$$
\boldsymbol{K}_{0}(f)=\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}(f)+\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{1, j}+\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{2, j}+\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{3, j}
$$

where

$$
\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{1, j}:=\frac{a_{1}}{n} \boldsymbol{z}_{j} \boldsymbol{z}_{j}^{\top}, \quad \boldsymbol{\Delta}_{2, j}:=\frac{1}{\sqrt{n}} \boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}\left(f^{\prime}-a_{1}\right) \odot\left(\boldsymbol{z}_{j} \boldsymbol{z}_{j}^{\top}\right)
$$

and the operator norm of $\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{3}$ satisfies

$$
\left\|\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{3, j}\right\|_{2} \lesssim \frac{1}{n}\left(1 \vee\left\|\boldsymbol{z}_{j}\right\|_{\infty}^{2 L}\right) \cdot \Gamma_{j}
$$

The following concentration inequality for Gaussian quadratic forms, which is a special case of Lemma B. 26 from [4], is key to the proof of Lemma A.6:
Lemma A.10. Let $\boldsymbol{A} \in \mathbb{R}^{p \times p}$ be independent of $\boldsymbol{z}_{j}$. For $k \geq 2$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|\left(\mathbb{E}_{j}-\mathbb{E}_{j-1}\right) \boldsymbol{z}_{j}^{\top} \boldsymbol{A} \boldsymbol{z}_{j}\right|^{k} & =\left|\mathbb{E}_{j-1}\left(\boldsymbol{z}_{j}^{\top} \boldsymbol{A} \boldsymbol{z}_{j}-\operatorname{tr} \boldsymbol{A}\right)\right|^{k} \leq \mathbb{E}_{j-1}\left|\mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{z}_{j}}\left(\boldsymbol{z}_{j}^{\top} \boldsymbol{A} \boldsymbol{z}_{j}-\operatorname{tr} \boldsymbol{A}\right)\right|^{k} \\
& \lesssim \mathbb{E}_{j-1}\|\boldsymbol{A}\|_{F}^{k}
\end{aligned}
$$

Proof of Lemma A.6. The claim follows immediately from the bounds

$$
\mathbb{E}_{j-1}\left|\alpha_{j, r}\right|^{k} \lesssim \frac{(\log n)^{4 L k}}{n^{k}} \mathbb{E}_{j-1} \Gamma_{j}^{4 k}, \quad r \in[4]
$$

which we prove below:
(1) By Jensen's inequality and $\left\|\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right\|_{2} \leq \operatorname{Im}(z)^{-1} \lesssim 1$,

$$
\mathbb{E}_{j-1}\left|\alpha_{j, 1}\right|^{k} \lesssim \frac{1}{n^{2 k}} \mathbb{E}_{j-1}\left[\left(\boldsymbol{z}_{j}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{z}_{j}\right)^{k}\left|\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{z}_{j}\right|^{2 k}\right] \lesssim \frac{1}{n^{2 k}} \mathbb{E}_{j-1}\left[\left\|\boldsymbol{z}_{j}\right\|_{2}^{2 k}\left|\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{z}_{j}\right|^{2 k}\right] \lesssim \frac{1}{n^{k}}
$$

(2) Let $\mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{z}_{j}}(\cdot)$ denote expectation with respect to $\boldsymbol{z}_{j}$. Since $\mathbb{E}_{j-1}(\cdot)=\mathbb{E}_{j} \mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{z}_{j}}(\cdot)$,

$$
\mathbb{E}_{j-1}\left|\alpha_{j, 2}\right|^{k} \lesssim \frac{1}{n^{k}} \mathbb{E}_{j}\left[\mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{z}_{j}}\left|\boldsymbol{z}_{j}^{\top} \boldsymbol{u} \cdot \boldsymbol{z}_{j}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j} \boldsymbol{S}_{-j} \boldsymbol{u}\right|^{k}\right] \lesssim \frac{1}{n^{k}} \mathbb{E}_{j}\left\|\boldsymbol{S}_{-j}\right\|_{2}^{k} \leq \mathbb{E}_{j} \Gamma_{j}^{k}
$$

(3) By Lemma A. 9 and $\left\|\boldsymbol{z}_{j}\right\|_{2} \leq \sqrt{n}\left\|\boldsymbol{z}_{j}\right\|_{\infty}$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\boldsymbol{z}_{j}^{\top}\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}-\boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j}\right) \boldsymbol{S}_{-j} \boldsymbol{u} & =-\boldsymbol{z}_{j}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0}\left(\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{1, j}+\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{2, j}+\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{3, j}\right) \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j} \boldsymbol{S}_{-j} \boldsymbol{u} \\
\left|\boldsymbol{z}_{j}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{\Delta}_{1, j} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j} \boldsymbol{S}_{-j} \boldsymbol{u}\right| & \lesssim \frac{1}{n}\left\|\boldsymbol{z}_{j}\right\|_{2}^{2}\left|\boldsymbol{z}_{j}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j} \boldsymbol{S}_{-j} \boldsymbol{u}\right| \leq\left\|\boldsymbol{z}_{j}\right\|_{\infty}^{2}\left|\boldsymbol{z}_{j}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j} \boldsymbol{S}_{-j} \boldsymbol{u}\right| \\
\left|\boldsymbol{z}_{j}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{\Delta}_{2, j} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j} \boldsymbol{S}_{-j} \boldsymbol{u}\right| & =\frac{1}{\sqrt{n}}\left|\boldsymbol{z}_{j}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \operatorname{diag}\left(\boldsymbol{z}_{j}\right) \boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}\left(f^{\prime}-a_{1}\right) \operatorname{diag}\left(\boldsymbol{z}_{j}\right) \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j} \boldsymbol{S}_{-j} \boldsymbol{u}\right| \\
& \lesssim \frac{1}{\sqrt{n}}\left\|\boldsymbol{z}_{j}\right\|_{2}\left\|\boldsymbol{z}_{j}\right\|_{\infty}^{2}\left\|\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}\left(f^{\prime}-a_{1}\right)\right\|_{2}\left\|\boldsymbol{S}_{-j}\right\|_{2} \lesssim\left\|\boldsymbol{z}_{j}\right\|_{\infty}^{3} \Gamma_{j}^{2} \\
\left|\boldsymbol{z}_{j}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{\Delta}_{3, j} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j} \boldsymbol{S}_{-j} \boldsymbol{u}\right| & \lesssim\left\|\boldsymbol{z}_{j}\right\|_{2}\left\|\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{3, j}\right\|_{2}\left\|\boldsymbol{S}_{-j}\right\|_{2} \lesssim \frac{1}{\sqrt{n}}\left(1 \vee\left\|\boldsymbol{z}_{j}\right\|_{\infty}^{2 L+1}\right) \Gamma_{j}^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

Moreover, as $\boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j}$ and $\boldsymbol{S}_{-j}$ are independent of $\boldsymbol{z}_{j}, \mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{z}_{j}}\left|\boldsymbol{z}_{j}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j} \boldsymbol{S}_{-j} \boldsymbol{u}\right|^{k} \lesssim\left\|\boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j} \boldsymbol{S}_{-j} \boldsymbol{u}\right\|_{2}^{k} \lesssim$ $\left\|\boldsymbol{S}_{-j}\right\|_{2}^{k}$. Together, these bounds imply

$$
\mathbb{E}_{j-1}\left|\alpha_{j, 3}\right|^{k} \lesssim \frac{1}{n^{k}} \mathbb{E}_{j-1}\left|\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{z}_{j} \cdot \boldsymbol{z}_{j}^{\top}\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}-\boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j}\right) \boldsymbol{S}_{-j} \boldsymbol{u}\right|^{k} \lesssim \frac{(\log n)^{2 L k}}{n^{k}} \mathbb{E}_{j} \Gamma_{j}^{2 k}
$$

(4) Since $\boldsymbol{R}_{0}-\boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j}=-\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0}-\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}\right) \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j}$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{S}_{-j}\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}-\boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j}\right) \boldsymbol{S}_{-j} \boldsymbol{u}= & -\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{S}_{-j} \boldsymbol{R}_{0}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0}-\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}\right) \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j} \boldsymbol{S}_{-j} \boldsymbol{u} \\
= & -\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{S}_{-j} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0}-\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}\right) \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j} \boldsymbol{S}_{-j} \boldsymbol{u} \\
& +\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{S}_{-j} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0}-\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}\right) \boldsymbol{R}_{0}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0}-\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}\right) \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j} \boldsymbol{S}_{-j} \boldsymbol{u}
\end{aligned}
$$

We bound $\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{S}_{-j} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0}-\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}\right) \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j} \boldsymbol{S}_{-j} \boldsymbol{u}$ similarly to (A.23):

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbb{E}_{z_{j}}\left|\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{S}_{-j} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j} \boldsymbol{\Delta}_{1, j} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j} \boldsymbol{S}_{-j} \boldsymbol{u}\right|^{k} \lesssim \frac{1}{n^{k}} \mathbb{E}_{z_{j}}\left|\boldsymbol{z}_{j}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j} \boldsymbol{S}_{-j} \boldsymbol{u}\right|^{2 k} \lesssim \frac{1}{n^{k}} \Gamma_{j}^{2 k} \\
& \mathbb{E}_{z_{j}}\left|\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{S}_{-j} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j} \boldsymbol{\Delta}_{3, j} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j} \boldsymbol{S}_{-j} \boldsymbol{u}\right|^{k} \lesssim \mathbb{E}_{z_{j}}\left\|\boldsymbol{S}_{-j}\right\|_{2}^{2 k}\left\|\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{3, j}\right\|_{2}^{k} \lesssim \frac{(\log n)^{2 L k}}{n^{k}} \Gamma_{j}^{3 k}
\end{aligned}
$$

To analyze the corresponding term involving $\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{2, j}$, we use the identity

$$
\begin{aligned}
\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{S}_{-j} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j} \boldsymbol{\Delta}_{2, j} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j} \boldsymbol{S}_{-j} \boldsymbol{u} & =\frac{1}{\sqrt{n}} \boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{S}_{-j} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}\left(f^{\prime}-a_{1}\right) \odot\left(\boldsymbol{z}_{j} \boldsymbol{z}_{j}^{\top}\right)\right) \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j} \boldsymbol{S}_{-j} \boldsymbol{u} \\
& =\frac{1}{\sqrt{n}} \boldsymbol{z}_{j}^{\top}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}\left(f^{\prime}-a_{1}\right) \odot\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j} \boldsymbol{S}_{-j} \boldsymbol{u} \boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{S}_{-j} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j}\right)\right) \boldsymbol{z}_{j}
\end{aligned}
$$

(this follows from $\operatorname{diag}\left(\boldsymbol{z}_{j}\right) \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j} \boldsymbol{S}_{-j} \boldsymbol{u}=\operatorname{diag}\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j} \boldsymbol{S}_{-j} \boldsymbol{u}\right) \boldsymbol{z}_{j}$ ) and concentration of Gaussian quadratic forms (Lemma A.10):

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|\left(\mathbb{E}_{j}-\mathbb{E}_{j-1}\right) \boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{S}_{-j} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j} \boldsymbol{\Delta}_{2, j} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j} \boldsymbol{S}_{-j} \boldsymbol{u}\right|^{k} \\
= & \frac{1}{n^{k / 2}}\left|\left(\mathbb{E}_{j}-\mathbb{E}_{j-1}\right)\right| \boldsymbol{z}_{j}^{\top}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}\left(f^{\prime}-a_{1}\right) \odot\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j} \boldsymbol{S}_{-j} \boldsymbol{u} \boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{S}_{-j} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j}\right)\right) \boldsymbol{z}_{j}\right| \|^{k} \\
\lesssim & \frac{1}{n^{k / 2}} \mathbb{E}_{j-1}\left\|\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}\left(f^{\prime}-a_{1}\right) \odot\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j} \boldsymbol{S}_{-j} \boldsymbol{u} \boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{S}_{-j} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j}\right)\right\|_{F}^{k} \\
\lesssim & \frac{1}{n^{k}} \mathbb{E}_{j-1}\left[\left\|\boldsymbol{S}_{-j}\right\|_{2}^{2 k}\left\|\sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}\left(f^{\prime}-a_{1}\right)\right\|_{\infty}^{k}\right] \\
\lesssim & \frac{1}{n^{k}} \mathbb{E}_{j-1} \Gamma_{j}^{3 k}
\end{aligned}
$$

To obtain the second inequality, we used $\left\|\boldsymbol{A} \odot\left(\boldsymbol{x} \boldsymbol{x}^{\top}\right)\right\|_{F} \leq\|\boldsymbol{A}\|_{\infty}\left\|\boldsymbol{x} \boldsymbol{x}^{\top}\right\|_{F}=\|\boldsymbol{A}\|_{\infty}\|\boldsymbol{x}\|_{2}^{2}$, where $\boldsymbol{A} \in \mathbb{R}^{p \times p}, \boldsymbol{x} \in \mathbb{R}^{p}$, and $\|\boldsymbol{A}\|_{\infty}:=\max _{i, j \in[p]}\left|\boldsymbol{A}_{i j}\right|$.

The second term on the right-hand side of (A.24) satisfies

$$
\left|\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{S}_{-j} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0}-\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}\right) \boldsymbol{R}_{0}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0}-\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}\right) \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j} \boldsymbol{S}_{-j} \boldsymbol{u}\right| \lesssim \delta_{1, j}+\delta_{2, j}+\delta_{3, j}
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \delta_{1, j}:=\frac{1}{n^{2}}\left\|\boldsymbol{z}_{j}\right\|_{2}^{2}\left|\boldsymbol{z}_{j}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{-j} \boldsymbol{S}_{-j} \boldsymbol{u}\right|^{2} \\
& \delta_{2, j}:=\frac{1}{n}\left\|\boldsymbol{z}_{j}\right\|_{2}\left|\boldsymbol{z}_{j}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{-j} \boldsymbol{S}_{-j} \boldsymbol{u}\right|\left\|\boldsymbol{S}_{-j}\right\|_{2}\left(\left\|\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{2, j}\right\|_{2}+\left\|\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{3, j}\right\|_{2}\right) \\
& \delta_{3, j}:=\left\|\boldsymbol{S}_{-j}\right\|_{2}^{2}\left(\left\|\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{2, j}\right\|_{2}^{2}+\left\|\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{3, j}\right\|_{2}^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

By arguments similar to (A.23)-(A.25), we have

$$
\mathbb{E}_{z_{j}}\left|\delta_{1, j}\right|^{k} \lesssim \frac{1}{n^{k}} \Gamma_{j}^{2 k}, \quad \mathbb{E}_{z_{j}}\left|\delta_{2, j}\right|^{k} \lesssim \frac{(\log n)^{2 L k}}{n^{k}} \Gamma_{j}^{3 k}, \quad \mathbb{E}_{z_{j}}\left|\delta_{3, j}\right|^{k} \lesssim \frac{(\log n)^{4 L k}}{n^{k}} \Gamma_{j}^{4 k}
$$

Combining the above bounds completes the proof:

$$
\mathbb{E}_{j-1}\left|\alpha_{j, 4}\right|^{k} \lesssim \frac{(\log n)^{4 L k}}{n^{k}} \mathbb{E}_{j-1} \Gamma_{j}^{4 k}
$$

Proof of Lemma A.7. By Theorem 1.6 of [26] and standard results on Gaussian matrices (such as Corollary 5.35 of [60]), we have $\left\|\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}\left(h_{\ell}\right)\right\|_{2} \prec 1$ for $\ell \in[L]$ and $\left\|\boldsymbol{S}_{-j}\right\|_{2} \prec 1$. Moreover,

$$
\sup _{\ell \in[L]} \sqrt{n}\left\|\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}\left(h_{\ell}\right)\right\|_{\infty}=\sup _{\ell \in[L]} \sup _{k_{1} \neq k_{2} \in[n] \backslash\{j\}}\left|h_{\ell}\left(n^{-1 / 2} \boldsymbol{z}_{k_{1}}^{\top} \boldsymbol{z}_{k_{2}}\right)\right|
$$

and each term satisfies $\left|h_{\ell}\left(n^{-1 / 2} \boldsymbol{z}_{k_{1}}^{\top} \boldsymbol{z}_{k_{2}}\right)\right| \prec 1$ by Lemma 4.1 of [16] and Markov's inequality. Thus, using a union bound, we conclude that $\Gamma_{j} \prec 1$.

To prove the second point of the lemma, we use the bound

$$
\mathbb{E} \Gamma_{j}^{2 k} \lesssim 1+\mathbb{E}\left\|\boldsymbol{S}_{-j}\right\|_{2}^{2 k}+\sum_{\ell=1}^{L} \mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}\left(h_{\ell}\right)\right\|_{2}^{2 k}+\left\|\sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}\left(h_{\ell}\right)\right\|_{\infty}^{2 k}\right] \lesssim n^{2 k}
$$

(which follows from $\left\|\boldsymbol{S}_{-j}\right\|_{2} \leq\left\|\boldsymbol{S}_{-j}\right\|_{F}$ and $\left\|\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}\left(h_{\ell}\right)\right\|_{2} \leq\left\|\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}\left(h_{\ell}\right)\right\|_{F}$ ) and the fact that for any $\varepsilon, D>0, \mathbb{P}\left(\left|\Gamma_{j}\right|>n^{\varepsilon}\right) \leq n^{-D}$ for sufficiently large $n$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E} \Gamma_{j}^{k} & \leq \mathbb{E}\left[\Gamma_{j}^{k} \mathbf{1}\left(\Gamma_{j} \leq n^{\varepsilon}\right)\right]+\mathbb{E}\left[\Gamma_{j}^{k} \mathbf{1}\left(\Gamma_{j}>n^{\varepsilon}\right)\right] \\
& \leq n^{\varepsilon}+\left(\mathbb{E} \Gamma_{j}^{2 k} \cdot \mathbb{P}\left(\Gamma_{j}>n^{\varepsilon}\right)\right)^{1 / 2} \\
& \lesssim n^{\varepsilon}+n^{k-D / 2}
\end{aligned}
$$

Taking $D \geq 2 k$ completes the proof.

Proof of Lemma A.9. Similarly to (5.1),

$$
\begin{aligned}
\boldsymbol{K}_{0}(f)= & \boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}(f)+\frac{1}{\sqrt{n}} \boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}\left(f^{\prime}\right) \odot\left(\boldsymbol{z}_{j} \boldsymbol{z}_{j}^{\top}\right) \\
& +\sum_{\ell=0}^{L} \sum_{k=2}^{L-\ell} \frac{a_{\ell+k}}{k!n^{k / 2}} \sqrt{\frac{(\ell+k)!}{\ell!}}\left[\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}\left(h_{\ell}\right) \odot\left(\boldsymbol{z}_{j} \boldsymbol{z}_{j}^{\top}\right)^{\odot k}\right] \\
\frac{1}{\sqrt{n}} \boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}\left(f^{\prime}\right) \odot\left(\boldsymbol{z}_{j} \boldsymbol{z}_{j}^{\top}\right)= & \frac{a_{1}}{n} \boldsymbol{z}_{j} \boldsymbol{z}_{j}^{\top}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{n}} \boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}\left(f^{\prime}-a_{1}\right) \odot\left(\boldsymbol{z}_{j} \boldsymbol{z}_{j}^{\top}\right)-\frac{a_{1}}{n} \operatorname{diag}\left(\boldsymbol{z}_{j}^{\odot 2}\right) \\
= & \boldsymbol{\Delta}_{1, j}+\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{2, j}-\frac{a_{1}}{n} \operatorname{diag}\left(\boldsymbol{z}_{j}^{\odot 2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{3, j} & :=\boldsymbol{K}_{0}(f)-\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}(f)-\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{1, j}-\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{2, j} \\
& =-\frac{a_{1}}{n} \operatorname{diag}\left(\boldsymbol{z}_{j}^{\odot 2}\right)+\sum_{\ell=0}^{L} \sum_{k=2}^{L-\ell} \frac{a_{\ell+k}}{k!n^{k / 2}} \sqrt{\frac{(\ell+k)!}{\ell!}}\left[\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}\left(h_{\ell}\right) \odot\left(\boldsymbol{z}_{j} \boldsymbol{z}_{j}^{\top}\right)^{\odot k}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

The lemma now follows from $\left\|\operatorname{diag}\left(\boldsymbol{z}_{j}^{\odot 2}\right)\right\|_{2}=\left\|\boldsymbol{z}_{j}\right\|_{\infty}^{2}$, our assumption that $f$ is an odd function (implying $a_{2}=0$ ), and the bounds

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{1}{n^{k / 2}}\left\|\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}\left(h_{0}\right) \odot\left(\boldsymbol{z}_{j} \boldsymbol{z}_{j}^{\top}\right)^{\odot k}\right\|_{2} & \leq \frac{2}{n^{(k-1) / 2}}\left\|\boldsymbol{z}_{j}^{\odot k}\right\|_{\infty}^{2} \leq \frac{2}{n^{(k-1) / 2}}\left\|\boldsymbol{z}_{j}\right\|_{\infty}^{2 k} \\
\frac{1}{n^{k / 2}}\left\|\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}\left(h_{\ell}\right) \odot\left(\boldsymbol{z}_{j} \boldsymbol{z}_{j}^{\top}\right)^{\odot k}\right\|_{2} & \leq \frac{1}{n}\left\|\operatorname{diag}\left(\boldsymbol{z}_{j}^{\odot k}\right) \boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}\left(h_{\ell}\right) \operatorname{diag}\left(\boldsymbol{z}_{j}^{\odot k}\right)\right\|_{2} \\
& \leq \frac{1}{n}\left\|\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}\left(h_{\ell}\right)\right\|_{2} \cdot\left\|\boldsymbol{z}_{j}\right\|_{\infty}^{2 k}
\end{aligned}
$$

# A. 2 Proof of Lemma A. 2 

Lemma A.11. Under the assumptions of Lemma A.2,

$$
\mathbb{E}\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{11}-s(z)=O\left(n^{-1 / 2+\varepsilon}\right), \quad \mathbb{E}\left(\boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{11}-\breve{s}(z)=O\left(n^{-1 / 2+\varepsilon}\right)
$$

Moreover, the convergence is uniform in z on compact subsets disjoint from $\operatorname{supp}(\mu)$.
Proof. The first claim follows from the proof of Theorem 3.4 of [16] and Theorem 1.6 of [26]. The proof of the second claim is similar to that of Lemma 1 of [48].

For $j \in[p]$, let $\boldsymbol{z}_{(j)}$ denote the $j$-th column of $\boldsymbol{Z}$ and $\boldsymbol{Z}_{(-j)}$ contain the remaining columns. Then,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{11}=-\left(z+n^{-1} f\left(n^{-1 / 2} \boldsymbol{z}_{(1)}^{\top} \boldsymbol{Z}_{(-1)}^{\top}\right)\left(\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0}\right)_{[2: p, 2: p]}-z \mathbf{I}_{p-1}\right)^{-1} f\left(n^{-1 / 2} \boldsymbol{Z}_{(-1)} \boldsymbol{z}_{(1)}\right)\right)^{-1} \\
& \left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{12}=-\frac{1}{\sqrt{n}}\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{11} \cdot f\left(n^{-1 / 2} \boldsymbol{z}_{(1)}^{\top} \boldsymbol{Z}_{(-1)}^{\top}\right)\left(\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0}\right)_{[2: p, 2: p]}-z \mathbf{I}_{p-1}\right)^{-1} \boldsymbol{e}_{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $f$ is applied elementwise.
Proof of (A.4). By exchangeability,

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{u}\right]=\mathbb{E}\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{11}+\left(\left\langle\boldsymbol{u}, \mathbf{1}_{p}\right\rangle^{2}-1\right) \mathbb{E}\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{12}
$$

Since $f$ is an odd function, (A.33) implies $\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{12}$ is odd with respect to $\boldsymbol{z}_{(1)}$; therefore, by the symmetry of the Gaussian distribution,

$$
