\mathbb{E}\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{12}=\mathbb{E}\left[\mathbb{E}\left[\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{12} \mid \boldsymbol{Z}_{(-1)}\right]\right]=0
$$

The claim now follows Lemma A. 11 .
Proof of (A.5). The proof is similar to that of (A.4):

$$
\begin{gathered}
\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{u}\right]=\mathbb{E}\left(\boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{11}+\left(\left\langle\boldsymbol{u}, \mathbf{1}_{p}\right\rangle^{2}-1\right) \mathbb{E}\left(\boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{12} \\
\left(\boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{12}=\frac{1}{n} \sum_{j=1}^{p}\left\langle\boldsymbol{z}_{(1)}, \boldsymbol{z}_{(j)}\right\rangle\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{j 2}=\frac{1}{n}\left\langle\boldsymbol{z}_{(1)}, \boldsymbol{z}_{(2)}\right\rangle\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{22}+\frac{1}{n} \sum_{j \neq 2}\left\langle\boldsymbol{z}_{(1)}, \boldsymbol{z}_{(j)}\right\rangle\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{j 2}
\end{gathered}
$$

Since $\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{22}$ and $\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{j 2}$ are even and odd functions of $\boldsymbol{z}_{(2)}$, respectively,

$$
\mathbb{E}\left(\boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{12}=\mathbb{E}\left[\mathbb{E}\left[\left(\boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{12} \mid \boldsymbol{Z}_{(-2)}\right]\right]=0
$$

Proof of (A.6). By exchangeability,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{u}\right]= & \frac{1}{n^{2}} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \mathbb{E}\left[\left(\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{z}_{i}\right)^{2} \cdot \boldsymbol{z}_{i}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{z}_{i}\right]+\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{z}_{i} \cdot \boldsymbol{z}_{i}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{S}_{-i} \boldsymbol{u}\right] \\
= & \frac{1}{n} \mathbb{E}\left[\left(\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{z}_{1}\right)^{2} \cdot \boldsymbol{z}_{1}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{z}_{1}\right]+\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{z}_{1} \cdot \boldsymbol{z}_{1}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{S}_{-1} \boldsymbol{u}\right] \\
= & \frac{1}{n} \mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{z}_{1}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{z}_{1}\right]+\frac{1}{n} \mathbb{E}\left[\left(\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{z}_{1}\right)^{2}\left(\boldsymbol{z}_{1}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{z}_{1}-\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{z}_{1}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{z}_{1}\right]\right)\right] \\
& +\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1} \boldsymbol{S}_{-1} \boldsymbol{u}\right]+\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{z}_{1} \cdot \boldsymbol{z}_{1}^{\top}\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}-\boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1}\right) \boldsymbol{S}_{-1} \boldsymbol{u}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

where the final equality holds as $\mathbb{E}\left(\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{z}_{1}\right)^{2}=1$ and $\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{z}_{1} \cdot \boldsymbol{z}_{1}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1} \boldsymbol{S}_{-1} \boldsymbol{u}\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1} \boldsymbol{S}_{-1} \boldsymbol{u}\right]$. We will consider each of the terms on the right-hand side (A.36), beginning with the first and third: using (A.5),

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{1}{n} \mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{z}_{1}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{z}_{1}\right]=\frac{p}{n} \cdot \frac{1}{p} \mathbb{E} \operatorname{tr}\left(\boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)=\gamma \bar{s}(z)+O\left(n^{-1 / 2+\varepsilon}\right) \\
& \mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1} \boldsymbol{S}_{-1} \boldsymbol{u}\right]=\bar{s}(z)+O\left(n^{-1 / 2+\varepsilon}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

The second term is negligible: an argument similar to the proof of Lemma A. 1 yields

$$
\frac{1}{n} \boldsymbol{z}_{1}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{z}_{1}-\frac{1}{n} \mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{z}_{1}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{z}_{1}\right]=O_{\prec}\left(n^{-1 / 2}\right), \quad \frac{1}{n^{2}} \mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{z}_{1}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{z}_{1}-\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{z}_{1}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{z}_{1}\right]\right]^{2}=O\left(n^{-1+\varepsilon}\right)
$$

for any $\varepsilon>0$, implying

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{1}{n} \mathbb{E}\left[\left(\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{z}_{1}\right)^{2}\left(\boldsymbol{z}_{1}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{z}_{1}-\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{z}_{1}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{z}_{1}\right]\right)\right] & \lesssim \frac{1}{n}\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{z}_{1}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{z}_{1}-\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{z}_{1}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{z}_{1}\right]\right]^{2}\right)^{1 / 2} \\
& =O\left(n^{-1 / 2+\varepsilon}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

We expand the fourth term of (A.36) using Lemma A.9:

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{z}_{1}^{\top}\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}-\boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1}\right) \boldsymbol{S}_{-1} \boldsymbol{u} \boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{z}_{1}\right]=-\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{z}_{1}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0}\left(\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{1,1}+\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{2,1}+\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{3,1}\right) \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1} \boldsymbol{S}_{-1} \boldsymbol{u} \boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{z}_{1}\right]
$$

Denoting $\eta_{1}:=\boldsymbol{z}_{1}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1} \boldsymbol{S}_{-1} \boldsymbol{u} \boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{z}_{1}-\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1} \boldsymbol{S}_{-1} \boldsymbol{u}$, we have $\mathbb{E}\left|\eta_{1}\right|^{2}=O\left(n^{\varepsilon}\right)$ by Lemma A. 10 and $\left\|\boldsymbol{S}_{-1}\right\|_{2} \prec 1$. Using this bound, the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality, (A.37), and (A.38), we find that the component of (A.40) involving $\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{1,1}$ is approximately $-a_{1} \gamma \bar{s}^{2}(z)$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{z}_{1}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{\Delta}_{1,1} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1} \boldsymbol{S}_{-1} \boldsymbol{u} \boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{z}_{1}\right]= & \frac{a_{1}}{n} \mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{z}_{1}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{z}_{1} \cdot \boldsymbol{z}_{1}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1} \boldsymbol{S}_{-1} \boldsymbol{u} \boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{z}_{1}\right] \\
= & a_{1} \mathbb{E}\left[\left(n^{-1} \boldsymbol{z}_{1}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{z}_{1}-\gamma \bar{s}(z)\right) \boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1} \boldsymbol{S}_{-1} \boldsymbol{u}\right]+a_{1} \gamma \bar{s}(z) \mathbb{E} \eta_{1} \\
& +a_{1} \mathbb{E}\left[\left(n^{-1} \boldsymbol{z}_{1}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{z}_{1}-\gamma \bar{s}(z)\right) \eta_{1}\right]+a_{1} \gamma \bar{s}(z) \mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1} \boldsymbol{S}_{-1} \boldsymbol{u}\right] \\
= & a_{1} \gamma \bar{s}^{2}(z)+O\left(n^{-1 / 2+\varepsilon}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Furthermore, the final line of (A.23) implies

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{z}_{1}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{\Delta}_{3,1} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1} \boldsymbol{S}_{-1} \boldsymbol{u} \boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{z}_{1}\right] & \lesssim\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{z}_{1}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{\Delta}_{3,1} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1} \boldsymbol{S}_{-1} \boldsymbol{u}\right]^{2}\right)^{1 / 2} \\
& \lesssim \frac{1}{\sqrt{n}}\left((\log n)^{4 L+2} \mathbb{E} \Gamma_{1}^{4}\right)^{1 / 2} \\
& =O\left(n^{-1 / 2+\varepsilon}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

It remains to prove that the component of (A.40) involving $\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{2,1}$ is negligible,

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{z}_{1}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{\Delta}_{2,1} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1} \boldsymbol{S}_{-1} \boldsymbol{u} \boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{z}_{1}\right]=O\left(n^{-1 / 2+\varepsilon}\right)
$$

which we address below. From (A.40)-(A.42), we obtain

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{z}_{1}^{\top}\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}-\boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1}\right) \boldsymbol{S}_{-1} \boldsymbol{u} \boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{z}_{1}\right]=-a_{1} \gamma \hat{s}^{2}(z)+O\left(n^{-1 / 2+\varepsilon}\right)
$$

Together with (A.36)-(A.39), this equation yields

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{S} \boldsymbol{u}\right]=\gamma \hat{s}(z)+\hat{s}(z)-a_{1} \gamma \hat{s}^{2}(z)+O\left(n^{-1 / 2+\varepsilon}\right)
$$

completing the proof of the lemma.
Proof of (A.42). By Lemma A.9,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{z}_{1}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{\Delta}_{2,1} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1} \boldsymbol{S}_{-1} \boldsymbol{u} \boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{z}_{1}\right]= & \mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{z}_{1}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1} \boldsymbol{\Delta}_{2,1} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1} \boldsymbol{S}_{-1} \boldsymbol{u} \boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{z}_{1}\right] \\
& -\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{z}_{1}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1}\left(\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{1,1}+\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{2,1}+\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{3,1}\right) \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{\Delta}_{2,1} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1} \boldsymbol{S}_{-1} \boldsymbol{u} \boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{z}_{1}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Using the bounds $\left\|\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{2,1}\right\|_{2} \leq n^{-1 / 2}\left\|\boldsymbol{z}_{1}\right\|_{\infty}^{2} \Gamma_{1}$ and $\left\|\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{3,1}\right\|_{2} \leq n^{-1}\left(1 \vee\left\|\boldsymbol{z}_{1}\right\|_{\infty}^{2 L}\right) \Gamma_{1}$ and the CauchySchwarz inequality, we find that the terms of this expansion involving $\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{2,1}$ and $\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{3,1}$ are negligible:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{z}_{1}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1} \boldsymbol{\Delta}_{2,1} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{\Delta}_{2,1} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1} \boldsymbol{S}_{-1} \boldsymbol{u} \boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{z}_{1}\right] & \lesssim\left(\mathbb{E}\left|\boldsymbol{z}_{1}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1} \boldsymbol{\Delta}_{2,1} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{\Delta}_{2,1} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1} \boldsymbol{S}_{-1} \boldsymbol{u}\right|^{2}\right)^{1 / 2} \\
& \lesssim \frac{1}{\sqrt{n}}\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\boldsymbol{z}_{1}\right\|_{\infty}^{10} \Gamma_{1}^{6}\right]\right)^{1 / 2}=O\left(n^{-1 / 2+\varepsilon}\right) \\
\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{z}_{1}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1} \boldsymbol{\Delta}_{3,1} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{\Delta}_{2,1} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1} \boldsymbol{S}_{-1} \boldsymbol{u} \boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{z}_{1}\right] & \lesssim\left(\mathbb{E}\left|\boldsymbol{z}_{1}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1} \boldsymbol{\Delta}_{3,1} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{\Delta}_{2,1} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1} \boldsymbol{S}_{-1} \boldsymbol{u}\right|^{2}\right)^{1 / 2} \\
& \lesssim \frac{1}{n}\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\boldsymbol{z}_{1}\right\|_{\infty}^{4 L+6} \Gamma_{1}^{6}\right]\right)^{1 / 2}=O\left(n^{-1 / 2+\varepsilon}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

However, the corresponding term containing $\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{1,1}$ is significant: by (A.37) and (A.38),

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{z}_{1}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1} \boldsymbol{\Delta}_{1,1} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{\Delta}_{2,1} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1} \boldsymbol{S}_{-1} \boldsymbol{u} \boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{z}_{1}\right]=a_{1} \gamma s(z) \mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{z}_{1}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{\Delta}_{2,1} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1} \boldsymbol{S}_{-1} \boldsymbol{u} \boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{z}_{1}\right]+O\left(n^{-1 / 2+\varepsilon}\right)
$$

Thus,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{z}_{1}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{\Delta}_{2,1} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1} \boldsymbol{S}_{-1} \boldsymbol{u} \boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{z}_{1}\right] \\
= & \frac{1}{1+a_{1} \gamma s(z)} \mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{z}_{1}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1} \boldsymbol{\Delta}_{2,1} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1} \boldsymbol{S}_{-1} \boldsymbol{u} \boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{z}_{1}\right]+O\left(n^{-1 / 2+\varepsilon}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

We proceed by expanding the expectation on the right-hand side as

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{z}_{1}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1} \boldsymbol{\Delta}_{2,1} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1} \boldsymbol{S}_{-1} \boldsymbol{u} \boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{z}_{1}\right] \\
= & \frac{1}{\sqrt{n}} \sum_{i, j, k, \ell=1}^{p} \mathbb{E}\left[z_{1 i} z_{1 j} z_{1 k} z_{1 \ell}\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1}\right)_{i k}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-1}\left(f^{\prime}-a_{1}\right)\right)_{k \ell}\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1} \boldsymbol{S}_{-1} \boldsymbol{u} \boldsymbol{u}^{\top}\right)_{\ell j}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Now, for $\boldsymbol{z}_{1} \sim \mathcal{N}\left(0, \mathbf{I}_{p}\right)$ and an array $\left(a_{i j k \ell}: i, j, k, \ell \in[p]\right)$,

$$
\sum_{i, j, k, \ell=1}^{p} a_{i j k \ell} \mathbb{E}\left[z_{1 i} z_{1 j} z_{1 k} z_{1 \ell}\right]=\sum_{i, j=1}^{p}\left(a_{i i j j}+a_{i j i j}+a_{i j j i}\right)
$$

Applying this identity to (A.45), we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sqrt{n} \mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{z}_{1}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1} \boldsymbol{\Delta}_{2,1} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1} \boldsymbol{S}_{-1} \boldsymbol{u} \boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{z}_{1}\right]= & \sum_{i, j=1}^{p} \mathbb{E}\left[\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1}\right)_{i j}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-1}\left(f^{\prime}-a_{1}\right)\right)_{j j}\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1} \boldsymbol{S}_{-1} \boldsymbol{u} \boldsymbol{u}^{\top}\right)_{i i}\right] \\
& +\sum_{i, j=1}^{p} \mathbb{E}\left[\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1}\right)_{i i}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-1}\left(f^{\prime}-a_{1}\right)\right)_{i j}\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1} \boldsymbol{S}_{-1} \boldsymbol{u} \boldsymbol{u}^{\top}\right)_{j j}\right] \\
& +\sum_{i, j=1}^{p} \mathbb{E}\left[\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1}\right)_{i j}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-1}\left(f^{\prime}-a_{1}\right)\right)_{i j}\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1} \boldsymbol{S}_{-1} \boldsymbol{u} \boldsymbol{u}^{\top}\right)_{i j}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

with the first summation equal to zero as $\operatorname{diag}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-1}\left(f^{\prime}-a_{1}\right)\right)=0$.
Since $\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-1}\left(f^{\prime}-a_{1}\right)_{i j}$ and $\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1}\right)_{i i}$ are even functions of $\boldsymbol{z}_{(i)}$ and $\boldsymbol{z}_{(j)}$ (recall that $f^{\prime}-a_{1}$ is even), and $\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1} \boldsymbol{S}_{-1}\right)_{j \ell}$ is an odd function of $\boldsymbol{z}_{(\ell)}$ unless $j=\ell$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sum_{i, j=1}^{p} \mathbb{E}\left[\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1}\right)_{i i}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-1}\left(f^{\prime}-a_{1}\right)\right)_{i j}\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1} \boldsymbol{S}_{-1} \boldsymbol{u} \boldsymbol{u}^{\top}\right)_{j j}\right] \\
= & \sum_{i, j, \ell=1}^{p} u_{j} u_{\ell} \mathbb{E}\left[\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1}\right)_{i i}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-1}\left(f^{\prime}-a_{1}\right)\right)_{i j}\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1} \boldsymbol{S}_{-1}\right)_{j \ell}\right] \\
= & \sum_{i, j=1}^{p} u_{j}^{2} \mathbb{E}\left[\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1}\right)_{i i}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-1}\left(f^{\prime}-a_{1}\right)\right)_{i j}\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1} \boldsymbol{S}_{-1}\right)_{j j}\right] \\
= & (p-1) \mathbb{E}\left[\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1}\right)_{11}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-1}\left(f^{\prime}-a_{1}\right)\right)_{12}\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1} \boldsymbol{S}_{-1}\right)_{22}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Recall that $\left|\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1}\right)_{i i}-s(z)\right| \prec n^{-1 / 2}$ and $\left|\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1} \boldsymbol{S}_{-1}\right)_{i i}-\gamma \bar{s}(z)\right| \prec n^{-1 / 2}$ by Lemma A.1, (A.4), and (A.5); the corresponding bounds

$$
\mathbb{E}\left|\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1}\right)_{i i}-s(z)\right|^{k} \lesssim n^{-k / 2+\varepsilon}, \quad \mathbb{E}\left|\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1} \boldsymbol{S}_{-1}\right)_{i i}-\gamma \bar{s}(z)\right|^{k} \lesssim n^{-k / 2+\varepsilon}
$$

are established through an analogous argument to the proof of Lemma A.7. Thus,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbb{E}\left|\left(\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1}\right)_{11}-s(z)\right)\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-1}\left(f^{\prime}-a_{1}\right)\right)_{12}\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1} \boldsymbol{S}_{-1}\right)_{22}\right| \\
& \lesssim \frac{1}{n^{1 / 2-\varepsilon}}\left(\mathbb{E}\left|\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-1}\left(f^{\prime}-a_{1}\right)\right)_{12}\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1} \boldsymbol{S}_{-1}\right)_{22}\right|^{2}\right)^{1 / 2} \\
& \lesssim \frac{1}{n^{1-\varepsilon}}\left(\mathbb{E} \Gamma_{1}^{4}\right)^{1 / 2} \lesssim \frac{1}{n^{1-\varepsilon}} \\
& \mathbb{E}\left|\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-1}\left(f^{\prime}-a_{1}\right)\right)_{12}\left(\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1} \boldsymbol{S}_{-1}\right)_{22}-\gamma \bar{s}(z)\right)\right| \\
& \lesssim \frac{1}{n^{1 / 2-\varepsilon}}\left(\mathbb{E}\left|\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-1}\left(f^{\prime}-a_{1}\right)\right)_{12}\right|^{2}\right)^{1 / 2} \lesssim \frac{1}{n^{1-\varepsilon}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Applying these bounds to (A.46), we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sum_{i, j=1}^{p} \mathbb{E}\left[\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1}\right)_{i i}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-1}\left(f^{\prime}-a_{1}\right)\right)_{i j}\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1} \boldsymbol{S}_{-1} \boldsymbol{u} \boldsymbol{u}^{\top}\right)_{j j}\right] \\
= & \gamma s(z) \bar{s}(z)(p-1) \cdot \mathbb{E}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-1}\left(f^{\prime}-a_{1}\right)\right)_{12}+O\left(n^{\varepsilon}\right)=O\left(n^{\varepsilon}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where the second equality follows from Section 4.1 of [16]:

$$
\sqrt{n} \mathbb{E}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-1}\left(f^{\prime}-a_{1}\right)\right)_{12}=\left\langle f^{\prime}-a_{1}, h_{0}\right\rangle_{\phi}+O\left(p^{-1}\right)=O\left(p^{-1}\right)
$$

Similarly,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|\sum_{i, j=1}^{p} \mathbb{E}\left[\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1}\right)_{i j}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-1}\left(f^{\prime}-a_{1}\right)\right)_{i j}\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1} \boldsymbol{S}_{-1} \boldsymbol{u} \boldsymbol{u}^{\top}\right)_{i j}\right]\right| \\
\leq & (p-1) \mathbb{E}\left[\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1}\right)_{12}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-1}\left(f^{\prime}-a_{1}\right)\right)_{12}\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0,-1} \boldsymbol{S}_{-1}\right)_{12}\right] \leq O\left(n^{-1 / 2+\varepsilon}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

The claim follows from (A.44), (A.49), and (A.50).

# A. 3 Proof of Lemma A. 3 

We shall prove (A.7); the proofs of (A.8) and (A.9) are similar and omitted.
Lemma A.12. For each $j \in[n]$, define the random variables

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \boldsymbol{X}_{-j}:=\boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{1 / 2} \boldsymbol{S}_{-j} \boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{1 / 2}-\boldsymbol{S}_{-j}, \quad \boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}^{(m)}:=\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j} \odot\left(\sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{X}_{-j}\right), \\
& \overline{\Gamma}_{j}:=\Gamma_{j} \vee\left(\sup _{\ell \in[L]} \sqrt{m}\left\|\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}^{(m)}\left(h_{\ell}\right)\right\|_{2}\right) \vee\left(\sup _{\ell \in[L]} \sqrt{n}\left\|\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}^{(m)}\left(h_{\ell}\right)\right\|_{\infty}\right) \\
& \quad \vee\left(\sup _{i \in[p]} \sqrt{n}\left(\boldsymbol{S}_{-j} \boldsymbol{v}-\boldsymbol{v}\right)_{i}\right) \vee\left(\sup _{i \in[p]}\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j}\right)_{i i}\right) \vee\left(\sup _{i, k \in[p], i \neq k} \sqrt{n}\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j}\right)_{i k}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Then, for all $\varepsilon>0$ and $k \in \mathbb{N}$,

$$
\overline{\Gamma}_{j} \prec 1, \quad \mathbb{E} \bar{\Gamma}_{j}^{k} \lesssim n^{\varepsilon}
$$

Lemma A.13. For each $j \in[n]$,

$$
\left\|\boldsymbol{K}_{0}^{(m)}-\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}^{(m)}\right\|_{2} \lesssim \frac{1}{\sqrt{n}}\left(1+\left|\boldsymbol{v}^{\top} \boldsymbol{z}_{j}\right|\right) \cdot\left(1 \vee\left\|z_{j}\right\|_{\infty}^{2 L+1}\right) \cdot \bar{\Gamma}_{j}^{2}
$$

Proofs of Lemmas A. 12 and A. 13 are provided at the end of this section.
Proof of (A.7). Analogous to Section A.1, we express the left-hand side of (A.7) as the sum of a martingale difference sequence: introducing

$$
\begin{aligned}
\bar{\alpha}_{j} & :=\left(\mathbb{E}_{j}-\mathbb{E}_{j-1}\right)\left(\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{K}_{0}^{(m)} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{u}-\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j} \boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}^{(m)} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j} \boldsymbol{u}\right) \\
\bar{\alpha}_{j, 1} & :=\left(\mathbb{E}_{j}-\mathbb{E}_{j-1}\right) \boldsymbol{u}^{\top}\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}-\boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j}\right) \boldsymbol{K}_{0}^{(m)}\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}-\boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j}\right) \boldsymbol{u} \\
\bar{\alpha}_{j, 2} & :=\left(\mathbb{E}_{j}-\mathbb{E}_{j-1}\right) \boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j} \boldsymbol{K}_{0}^{(m)}\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}-\boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j}\right) \boldsymbol{u} \\
\bar{\alpha}_{j, 3} & :=\left(\mathbb{E}_{j}-\mathbb{E}_{j-1}\right) \boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0}^{(m)}-\boldsymbol{K}_{0} \odot\left(\sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{X}_{-j}\right)\right) \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j} \boldsymbol{u} \\
\bar{\alpha}_{j, 4} & :=\left(\mathbb{E}_{j}-\mathbb{E}_{j-1}\right) \boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0} \odot\left(\sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{X}_{-j}\right)-\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}^{(m)}\right) \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j} \boldsymbol{u}
\end{aligned}
$$

we have the decomposition

$$
\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{K}^{(m)} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{u}-\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{K}^{(m)} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{u}\right]=\sum_{j=1}^{n} \bar{\alpha}_{j}=\sum_{j=1}^{n}\left(\bar{\alpha}_{j, 1}+2 \bar{\alpha}_{j, 2}+\bar{\alpha}_{j, 3}+\bar{\alpha}_{j, 4}\right)
$$

Given the proof of Lemma A.1, it suffices to establish

$$
\mathbb{E}_{j-1}\left|\bar{\alpha}_{j, r}\right|^{k} \lesssim \frac{(\log n)^{4 k}}{n^{k}} \mathbb{E}_{j-1} \bar{\Gamma}_{j}^{4 k}, \quad r \in[4]
$$

For brevity, we bound only $\mathbb{E}_{j-1}\left|\bar{\alpha}_{j, 2}\right|^{k}$ and $\mathbb{E}_{j-1}\left|\bar{\alpha}_{j, 3}\right|^{k}$; the analysis of $\bar{\alpha}_{j, 1}$ and $\bar{\alpha}_{j, 4}$ does not differ substantively from the arguments presented below and in Section A.1.
(2) We expand $\bar{\alpha}_{j, 2}$ using the identity $\boldsymbol{R}_{0}=\boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j}-\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0}-\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}\right) \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j}$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
\bar{\alpha}_{j, 2} & =-\left(\mathbb{E}_{j}-\mathbb{E}_{j-1}\right) \boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j} \boldsymbol{K}_{0}^{(m)} \boldsymbol{R}_{0}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0}-\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}\right) \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j} \boldsymbol{u} \\
& =-\left(\mathbb{E}_{j}-\mathbb{E}_{j-1}\right)\left(\bar{\delta}_{j, 1}+\bar{\delta}_{j, 2}-\bar{\delta}_{j, 3}\right) \\
\bar{\delta}_{j, 1} & :=\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j} \boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}^{(m)} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0}-\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}\right) \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j} \boldsymbol{u} \\
\bar{\delta}_{j, 2} & :=\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0}^{(m)}-\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}^{(m)}\right) \boldsymbol{R}_{0}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0}-\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}\right) \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j} \boldsymbol{u} \\
\bar{\delta}_{j, 3} & :=\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j} \boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}^{(m)} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0}-\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}\right) \boldsymbol{R}_{0}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0}-\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}\right) \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j} \boldsymbol{u}
\end{aligned}
$$

The component of $\bar{\alpha}_{j, 2}$ involving $\bar{\delta}_{j, 1}$ is bounded similarly to (A.26): denoting $\widetilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{j}:=\boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j} \boldsymbol{u}$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|\left(\mathbb{E}_{j}-\mathbb{E}_{j-1}\right) \widetilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{j}^{\top} \boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}^{(m)} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j} \boldsymbol{\Delta}_{j, 1} \widetilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{j}\right|^{k}=\frac{1}{n^{k}}\left|\left(\mathbb{E}_{j}-\mathbb{E}_{j-1}\right) \boldsymbol{z}_{j}^{\top} \widetilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{j} \widetilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{j}^{\top} \boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}^{(m)} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j} \boldsymbol{z}_{j}\right|^{k} \\
& \lesssim \frac{1}{n^{k}} \mathbb{E}_{j-1}\left\|\widetilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{j} \widetilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{j}^{\top} \boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}^{(m)} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j}\right\|_{F}^{k} \\
& \lesssim \frac{1}{n^{5 k / 4}} \mathbb{E}_{j-1} \bar{\Gamma}_{j}^{k} \\
& \left|\left(\mathbb{E}_{j}-\mathbb{E}_{j-1}\right) \widetilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{j}^{\top} \boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}^{(m)} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j} \boldsymbol{\Delta}_{j, 2} \widetilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{j}\right|^{k} \lesssim \frac{1}{n^{k / 2}} \mathbb{E}_{j-1}\left\|\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}\left(f^{\prime}-a_{1}\right) \odot\left(\widetilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{j} \widetilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{j}^{\top} \boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}^{(m)}\right)\right\|_{F}^{k} \\
& \lesssim \frac{1}{n^{5 k / 4}} \mathbb{E}_{j-1} \bar{\Gamma}_{j}^{2 k} \\
& \left.\mathbb{E}_{j-1}\left|\widetilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{j}^{\top} \boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}^{(m)} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j} \boldsymbol{\Delta}_{j, 3} \widetilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{j}\right|^{k} \lesssim \frac{(\log n)^{2 L k}}{n^{5 k / 4}} \mathbb{E}_{j-1} \bar{\Gamma}_{j}^{2 k}\right.
\end{aligned}
$$

Together with Lemma A.9, these bounds yield

$$
\mathbb{E}_{j-1}\left|\bar{\delta}_{j, 1}\right|^{k}=\mathbb{E}_{j-1}\left|\widetilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{j}^{\top} \boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}^{(m)} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j}\left(\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{j, 1}+\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{j, 2}+\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{j, 3}\right) \widetilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{j}\right|^{k} \lesssim \frac{(\log n)^{2 L k}}{n^{5 k / 4}} \mathbb{E}_{j-1} \bar{\Gamma}_{j}^{2 k}
$$

Now, we consider $\bar{\delta}_{j, 2}$. By Lemma A. 13 and the independence of $\boldsymbol{z}_{j}$ and $\left(\bar{\Gamma}_{j}, \widetilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{j}\right)$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{z}_{j}}\left|\widetilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{j}^{\top}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0}^{(m)}-\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}^{(m)}\right) \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{\Delta}_{j, 1} \widetilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{j}\right|^{k} & \lesssim \frac{1}{n^{k / 2}} \mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{z}_{j}}\left\|\left\|\boldsymbol{K}_{0}^{(m)}-\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}^{(m)}\right\|_{2}\left\|\boldsymbol{z}_{j}\right\|_{\infty} \cdot \boldsymbol{z}_{j}^{\top} \widetilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{j}\right|^{k} \\
& \lesssim \frac{1}{n^{k}} \mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{z}_{j}}\left|\left(1+\left\|\boldsymbol{z}_{j}\right\|_{\infty}^{2(L+1)}\right) \bar{\Gamma}_{j}^{2} \cdot\left(1+\left|\boldsymbol{z}_{j}^{\top} \boldsymbol{v}\right|\right) \cdot \boldsymbol{z}_{j}^{\top} \widetilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{j}\right|^{k} \\
& \lesssim \frac{(\log n)^{2(L+1) k}}{n^{k}} \bar{\Gamma}_{j}^{2 k} \\
\mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{z}_{j}}\left|\widetilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{j}^{\top}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0}^{(m)}-\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}^{(m)}\right) \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{\Delta}_{j, 2} \widetilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{j}\right|^{k} & \lesssim \frac{1}{n^{k / 2}} \mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{z}_{j}}\left\|\left\|\boldsymbol{K}_{0}^{(m)}-\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}^{(m)}\right\|_{2}\left\|\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}\left(f^{\prime}-a_{1}\right)\right\|_{2}\left\|\boldsymbol{z}_{j}\right\|_{\infty}^{2}\right|^{k} \\
& \lesssim \frac{(\log n)^{(2 L+3) k}}{n^{k}} \bar{\Gamma}_{j}^{3 k}
\end{aligned}
$$

Similarly bounding $\left|\widetilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{j}^{\top}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0}^{(m)}-\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}^{(m)}\right) \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{\Delta}_{j, 3} \widetilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{j}\right| \lesssim\left\|\boldsymbol{K}_{0}^{(m)}-\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}^{(m)}\right\|_{2}\left\|\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{j, 3}\right\|_{2}$, we obtain

$$
\mathbb{E}_{j-1}\left|\tilde{\delta}_{j, 2}\right|^{k} \lesssim \frac{(\log n)^{(4 L+1) k}}{n^{k}} \mathbb{E}_{j-1} \bar{\Gamma}_{j}^{3 k}
$$

The analysis of $\tilde{\delta}_{j, 3}$ is analogous to (A.27)-(A.28). For example,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|\widetilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{j}^{\top} \boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}^{(m)} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j} \boldsymbol{\Delta}_{j, 1} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{\Delta}_{j, 1} \widetilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{j}\right| & =\frac{1}{n^{2}}\left|\widetilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{j}^{\top} \boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}^{(m)} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j} \boldsymbol{z}_{j}\right|\left|\boldsymbol{z}_{j}^{\top} \widetilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{j}\right|\left|\boldsymbol{z}_{j}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{z}_{j}\right| \\
& \lesssim \frac{1}{n}\left\|\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}^{(m)} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j} \boldsymbol{z}_{j}\right\|_{2}\left|\boldsymbol{z}_{j}^{\top} \widetilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{j}\right|\left\|\boldsymbol{z}_{j}\right\|_{\infty}^{2} \\
\mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{z}_{j}}\left|\widetilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{j}^{\top} \boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}^{(m)} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j} \boldsymbol{\Delta}_{j, 1} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{\Delta}_{j, 1} \widetilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{j}\right|^{k} & \lesssim \frac{(\log n)^{2 k}}{n^{k}}\left\|\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}^{(m)} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j}\right\|_{2}^{k} \lesssim \frac{(\log n)^{2 k}}{n^{k}} \bar{\Gamma}_{j}^{k} \\
\left|\widetilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{j}^{\top} \boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}^{(m)} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j} \boldsymbol{\Delta}_{j, 1} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{\Delta}_{j, 2} \widetilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{j}\right| & =\frac{1}{n}\left|\widetilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{j}^{\top} \boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}^{(m)} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j} \boldsymbol{z}_{j}\right|\left|\boldsymbol{z}_{j}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{\Delta}_{j, 2} \widetilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{j}\right| \\
& \lesssim \frac{1}{n}\left\|\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}^{(m)} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j} \boldsymbol{z}_{j}\right\|_{2}\left\|\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}\left(f^{\prime}-a_{1}\right)\right\|_{2}\left\|\boldsymbol{z}_{j}\right\|_{\infty}^{3} \\
\mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{z}_{j}}\left|\widetilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{j}^{\top} \boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}^{(m)} \boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j} \boldsymbol{\Delta}_{j, 1} \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{\Delta}_{j, 2} \widetilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{j}\right|^{k} & \lesssim \frac{(\log n)^{3 k}}{n^{k}} \bar{\Gamma}_{j}^{2 k}
\end{aligned}
$$

From these and related bounds, we have

$$
\mathbb{E}_{j-1}\left|\tilde{\delta}_{j, 3}\right|^{k} \lesssim \frac{(\log n)^{4 L k}}{n^{k}} \bar{\Gamma}_{j}^{3 k}
$$

Thus, by (A.55), (A.56), and (A.57),

$$
\mathbb{E}_{j-1}\left|\widetilde{\alpha}_{j, 2}\right|^{k} \lesssim \frac{(\log n)^{4(L+1) k}}{n^{k}} \bar{\Gamma}_{j}^{3 k}
$$

(3) Since $\boldsymbol{X}-\boldsymbol{X}_{-j}=(\sqrt{\lambda}-1)\left(\boldsymbol{v} \boldsymbol{v}^{\top}\left(\boldsymbol{S}-\boldsymbol{S}_{-j}\right)+\left(\boldsymbol{S}-\boldsymbol{S}_{-j}\right) \boldsymbol{v} \boldsymbol{v}^{\top}\right)$, it suffices to consider

$$
\begin{aligned}
\widetilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{j}^{\top}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0} \odot\left(\sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{v} \boldsymbol{v}^{\top}\left(\boldsymbol{S}-\boldsymbol{S}_{-j}\right)\right)\right) \widetilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{j}= & \widetilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{j}^{\top}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j} \odot\left(\sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{v} \boldsymbol{v}^{\top}\left(\boldsymbol{S}-\boldsymbol{S}_{-j}\right)\right)\right) \widetilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{j} \\
& +\widetilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{j}^{\top}\left(\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0}-\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}\right) \odot\left(\sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{v} \boldsymbol{v}^{\top}\left(\boldsymbol{S}-\boldsymbol{S}_{-j}\right)\right)\right) \widetilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{j}
\end{aligned}
$$

We prove below a bound on the first term on the right-hand side; the second is handled in the standard manner by applying Lemma A. 9 to $\boldsymbol{K}_{0}-\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}$, which yields

$$
\mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{z}_{j}}\left|\widetilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{j}^{\top}\left(\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0}-\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}\right) \odot\left(\sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{v} \boldsymbol{v}^{\top}\left(\boldsymbol{S}-\boldsymbol{S}_{-j}\right)\right)\right) \widetilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{j}\right|^{k} \lesssim \frac{(\log n)^{2 k}}{n^{k}}+\frac{(\log n)^{2 L k}}{n^{5 k / 4}} \bar{\Gamma}_{j}^{k}
$$

Similarly to (A.26),

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|\left(\mathbb{E}_{j}-\mathbb{E}_{j-1}\right) \widetilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{j}^{\top}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j} \odot\left(\sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{v} \boldsymbol{v}^{\top}\left(\boldsymbol{S}-\boldsymbol{S}_{-j}\right)\right)\right) \widetilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{j}\right|^{k} \\
= & \frac{1}{n^{k / 2}}\left|\left(\mathbb{E}_{j}-\mathbb{E}_{j-1}\right) \boldsymbol{z}_{j}^{\top} \boldsymbol{v} \boldsymbol{v}^{\top}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j} \odot\left(\widetilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{j} \widetilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{j}^{\top}\right)\right) \boldsymbol{z}_{j}\right|^{k} \\
\lesssim & \frac{1}{n^{k / 2}} \mathbb{E}_{j-1}\left\|\boldsymbol{v} \boldsymbol{v}^{\top}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j} \odot\left(\widetilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{j} \widetilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{j}^{\top}\right)\right)\right\|_{F}^{k} \\
\lesssim & \frac{1}{m^{k / 2} n^{k}} \mathbb{E}_{j-1}\left\|\left(\widetilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{j}\right)_{[1: m]}\right\|_{1}^{k} \Gamma_{j}^{k}
\end{aligned}
$$

where the final inequality follows from

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\|\boldsymbol{v} \boldsymbol{v}^{\top}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j} \odot\left(\widetilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{j} \widetilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{j}^{\top}\right)\right)\right\|_{F}^{2} & =\left|\boldsymbol{v}^{\top}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j} \odot\left(\widetilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{j} \widetilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{j}^{\top}\right)\right)^{2} \boldsymbol{v}\right| \\
& \leq \sum_{i, k=1}^{m} \sum_{\ell=1}^{p}\left|v_{i} v_{k}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}\right)_{i \ell}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}\right)_{\ell k}\left(\widetilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{j}\right)_{i}\left(\widetilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{j}\right)_{k}\left(\widetilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{j}\right)_{\ell}^{2}\right| \\
& \leq \frac{1}{m n} \sum_{i, k=1}^{m} \sum_{\ell=1}^{p}\left|\left(\widetilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{j}\right)_{i}\left(\widetilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{j}\right)_{k}\left(\widetilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{j}\right)_{\ell}^{2}\right| \cdot \Gamma_{j}^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

Now, to bound $\left\|\left(\widetilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{j}\right)_{[1: m]}\right\|_{1}$, we use $\|\boldsymbol{u}\|_{0} \lesssim m$ and Lemma A.12:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\|\left(\widetilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{j}\right)_{[1: m]}\right\|_{1} & =\sum_{i=1}^{m}\left|\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j} \boldsymbol{u}\right)_{i}\right|=\sum_{i=1}^{m}\left|\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j}\right)_{i i} u_{i}+\sum_{k \in[p], k \neq i}\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j}\right)_{i k} u_{k}\right| \\
& \leq\left(\sum_{i=1}^{m}\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j}\right)_{i i}^{2}\right)^{1 / 2}+\sum_{i=1}^{m}\left(\sum_{k \in \operatorname{supp}(\boldsymbol{u}), k \neq i}\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j}\right)_{i k}^{2}\right)^{1 / 2} \\
& \lesssim \sqrt{m} \bar{\Gamma}_{j}
\end{aligned}
$$

From (A.59)-(A.61), we conclude

$$
\mathbb{E}_{j-1}\left|\bar{\alpha}_{j, 3}\right|^{k} \lesssim \frac{(\log n)^{2 L k}}{n^{k}} \bar{\Gamma}_{j}^{k}
$$

Proof of Lemma A.12. Recall the identity $\boldsymbol{A} \odot\left(\boldsymbol{x} \boldsymbol{y}^{\top}\right)=\operatorname{diag}(\boldsymbol{x}) \boldsymbol{A} \operatorname{diag}(\boldsymbol{y})$ and from the proof of Theorem 2.1

$$
\boldsymbol{X}_{-j}=c_{-j} \cdot \boldsymbol{v} \boldsymbol{v}^{\top}+(\sqrt{\lambda}-1)\left(\boldsymbol{v}\left(\boldsymbol{S}_{-j} \boldsymbol{v}-\boldsymbol{v}\right)^{\top}+\left(\boldsymbol{S}_{-j} \boldsymbol{v}-\boldsymbol{v}\right) \boldsymbol{v}^{\top}\right)
$$

where $c_{-j}$ (defined analogously to $c$ in (5.2)) satisfies $\left|c_{-j}-1\right| \prec n^{-1 / 2}$. Used together with (5.3) and (5.9), these expressions lead to

$$
\left\|\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}\left(h_{\ell}\right) \odot(\sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{X})\right\|_{2} \lesssim\left\|\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}\left(h_{\ell}\right)\right)_{[1: m, 1: m]}\right\|_{2}+\sqrt{m}\left(\sup _{i \in[p]}\left|\left(\boldsymbol{S}_{-j} \boldsymbol{v}-\boldsymbol{v}\right)_{i}\right|\right)\left\|\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}\left(h_{\ell}\right)\right\|_{2} \prec \frac{1}{n^{1 / 4}}
$$

Thus,

$$
\left(\sup _{\ell \in[L]} \sqrt{m}\left\|\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}^{(m)}\left(h_{\ell}\right)\right\|_{2}\right) \vee\left(\sup _{i \in[p]} \sqrt{n}\left(\boldsymbol{S}_{-j} \boldsymbol{v}-\boldsymbol{v}\right)_{i}\right) \prec 1
$$

Furthermore, by Theorem 4.1,

$$
\left(\sup _{i \in[p]}\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j}\right)_{i i}\right) \vee\left(\sup _{i, k \in[p], i \neq k} \sqrt{n}\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0,-j}\right)_{i k}\right) \prec 1
$$

The claim now follows from Lemma A. 6 and an argument analogous to (A.29)-(A.30).
Proof of Lemma A.13. Using (A.63),

$$
\begin{aligned}
\boldsymbol{K}_{0}^{(m)}-\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}^{(m)} & =\boldsymbol{K}_{0} \odot\left(\sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{X}-\sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{X}_{-j}\right)+\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0}-\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}\right) \odot\left(\sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{X}_{-j}\right) \\
& =\frac{1}{\sqrt{n}}(\sqrt{\lambda}-1) \boldsymbol{v}^{\top} \boldsymbol{z}_{j} \cdot \boldsymbol{K}_{0} \odot\left(\boldsymbol{v} \boldsymbol{z}_{j}^{\top}+\boldsymbol{z}_{j} \boldsymbol{v}^{\top}\right)+\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{j, 1}^{(m)}+\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{j, 2}^{(m)}+\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{j, 3}^{(m)}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{j, 3}^{(m)}=\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{j, 3} \odot\left(\sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{X}_{-j}\right)+\left(c-c_{-j}\right) \boldsymbol{K}_{0} \odot\left(\sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{v} \boldsymbol{v}^{\top}\right)$ and

$$
\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{j, 1}^{(m)}:=\frac{\left\langle g, h_{1}\right\rangle_{\phi}}{\sqrt{n}}\left(\boldsymbol{z}_{j} \boldsymbol{z}_{j}^{\top}\right) \odot \boldsymbol{X}_{-j}, \quad \boldsymbol{\Delta}_{j, 2}^{(m)}:=\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}\left(g^{\prime}-\left\langle g, h_{1}\right\rangle_{\phi}\right) \odot\left(\boldsymbol{z}_{j} \boldsymbol{z}_{j}^{\top}\right) \odot \boldsymbol{X}_{-j}
$$

Using (5.3) and (5.9) as in the proof of Lemma A.12,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\|\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{j, 2}^{(m)}\right\|_{2} \lesssim \frac{1}{n^{3 / 4}}\left(1 \vee\left\|\boldsymbol{z}_{j}\right\|_{\infty}^{2}\right) \cdot \bar{\Gamma}_{j}^{2}, \quad\left\|\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{j, 3}^{(m)}\right\|_{2} \lesssim \frac{1}{n^{5 / 4}}\left(1 \vee\left\|\boldsymbol{z}_{j}\right\|_{\infty}^{2 L}\right) \cdot \bar{\Gamma}_{j}^{2} \\
& \left\|\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{j, 1}^{(m)}\right\|_{2} \lesssim \frac{1}{\sqrt{n}}\left(\left\|\left(\boldsymbol{z}_{j} \boldsymbol{z}_{j}^{\top}\right) \odot\left(\boldsymbol{v} \boldsymbol{v}^{\top}\right)\right\|_{2}+\left\|\left(\boldsymbol{z}_{j} \boldsymbol{z}_{j}^{\top}\right) \odot\left(\boldsymbol{v}\left(\boldsymbol{S}_{-j} \boldsymbol{v}-\boldsymbol{v}\right)^{\top}\right)\right\|_{2}\right) \\
& \quad \lesssim \frac{1}{\sqrt{n}}\left\|\boldsymbol{z}_{j}\right\|_{\infty}^{2}+\left\|\boldsymbol{z}_{j}\right\|_{\infty}^{2}\left\|\boldsymbol{S}_{-j} \boldsymbol{v}-\boldsymbol{v}\right\|_{\infty} \prec \frac{1}{\sqrt{n}}\left\|\boldsymbol{z}_{j}\right\|_{\infty}^{2} \bar{\Gamma}_{j} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Similarly, by Lemma A.9,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\|\boldsymbol{K}_{0} \odot\left(\boldsymbol{v} \boldsymbol{z}_{j}^{\top}+\boldsymbol{z}_{j} \boldsymbol{v}^{\top}\right)\right\|_{2} & \leq 2\left\|\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j} \odot\left(\boldsymbol{v} \boldsymbol{z}_{j}^{\top}\right)\right\|_{2}+2\left\|\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0}-\boldsymbol{K}_{0,-j}\right) \odot\left(\boldsymbol{v} \boldsymbol{z}_{j}^{\top}\right)\right\|_{2} \\
& \lesssim \frac{\left\|\boldsymbol{z}_{j}\right\|_{\infty}}{\sqrt{m}}\left(\bar{\Gamma}_{j}+\left\|\boldsymbol{\Delta}_{j, 1}\right\|_{2}+\frac{\left\|\boldsymbol{z}_{j}\right\|_{\infty}^{2}}{\sqrt{n}} \bar{\Gamma}_{j}+\frac{\left(1 \vee\left\|\boldsymbol{z}_{j}\right\|_{\infty}^{2 L}\right)}{n} \bar{\Gamma}_{j}\right) \\
& \lesssim \frac{1 \vee\left\|\boldsymbol{z}_{j}\right\|_{\infty}^{2 L+1}}{\sqrt{m}} \bar{\Gamma}_{j}
\end{aligned}
$$

# A. 4 Proof of Lemma A. 4 

We shall prove the bounds

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0}(g) \odot\left(\sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{v} \boldsymbol{v}^{\top}\right)\right) \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{u}\right]=O\left(n^{-1 / 2+\varepsilon}\right) \\
& \mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0}(g) \odot\left(\sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{v} \boldsymbol{v}^{\top} \boldsymbol{S}\right)\right) \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{u}\right]=O\left(n^{-1 / 2+\varepsilon}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

from which (A.10) immediately follows; the proofs of (A.11) and (A.12) are similar and omitted. For simplicity, we assume $\operatorname{supp}(\boldsymbol{u}) \subseteq \operatorname{supp}(\boldsymbol{v})=[m]$.

Proof of (A.66). Expanding the expectation,

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0}(g) \odot\left(\sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{v} \boldsymbol{v}^{\top}\right)\right) \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{u}\right]=\frac{\sqrt{n}}{m} \sum_{i, j, k, \ell=1}^{m} u_{i} u_{j} \mathbb{E}\left[\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{i k}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0}(g)\right)_{k \ell}\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{\ell j}\right]
$$

we claim only those terms on the right-hand side with $i=j$ have non-zero mean. To see this, suppose $i \neq j$, and recall that (1) $\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{i j}$ and $\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0}(g)\right)_{i j}$ are odd functions of $\boldsymbol{z}_{(i)}$ and $\boldsymbol{z}_{(j)}$ and (2) $\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{i i}$ is an even function of $\boldsymbol{z}_{(i)}$ by (A.33). Therefore, unless $(i, j)=(k, \ell)$ or $(i, j)=(\ell, k)$,

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{i k}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0}(g)\right)_{k \ell}\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{\ell j}\right]=0
$$

In the former case,

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{i k}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0}(g)\right)_{k \ell}\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{\ell j}\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[\mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{z}_{(i)}}\left[\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{i i}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0}(g)\right)_{i j}\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{j j}\right]\right]=0
$$

and in the latter,

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{i k}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0}(g)\right)_{k \ell}\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{\ell j}\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[\mathbb{E}_{z_{(i)}}\left[\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{i j}^{2}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0}(g)\right)_{i j}\right]\right]=0
$$

Thus, by exchangeability and the fact that the diagonal of $\boldsymbol{K}_{0}(g)$ is zero,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0}(g) \odot\left(\sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{v} \boldsymbol{v}^{\top}\right)\right) \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{u}\right]= & \frac{\sqrt{n}}{m} \sum_{\substack{i, k, \ell \in[m] \\
k \neq l}} u_{i}^{2} \mathbb{E}\left[\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{i k}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0}(g)\right)_{k \ell}\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{\ell i}\right] \\
= & \frac{\sqrt{n}(m-1)(m-2)}{m} \mathbb{E}\left[\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{12}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0}(g)\right)_{23}\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{31}\right] \\
& +\frac{\sqrt{n}(m-1)}{m} \mathbb{E}\left[\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{11}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0}(g)\right)_{12}\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{21}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

To complete the proof, we use the bounds $\left|\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{12} \vee\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{31}\right| \prec n^{-1 / 2}$ and $\left|\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{11}\right| \prec 1$ (Theorem 4.1) as well as $\left|\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0}\right)_{23}\right| \prec n^{-1 / 2}$ (Lemma A.7): by a similar argument to (A.29)-(A.30), this implies $\left.\mathbb{E}\left[\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{12}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0}(g)\right)_{23}\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{31}\right]=O\left(n^{-3 / 2+\varepsilon}\right)\right)$ and $\mathbb{E}\left[\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{11}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0}(g)\right)_{12}\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{21}\right]=O\left(n^{-1+\varepsilon}\right)$. Thus,

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{u}^{\top} \boldsymbol{R}_{0}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0}(g) \odot\left(\sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{v} \boldsymbol{v}^{\top}\right)\right) \boldsymbol{R}_{0} \boldsymbol{u}\right]=O\left(n^{-1 / 2+\varepsilon}\right)
$$

Proof of (A.67). Similarly to (A.68),

$$
\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\left[\boldsymbol{K}_{0}(g) \odot\left(\sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{v} \boldsymbol{v}^{\top} \boldsymbol{S}\right)\right] \boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{i j}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{n}} \sum_{k, q=1}^{m} \sum_{\ell=1}^{p} v_{k} v_{q}\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{i k}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0}(g)\right)_{k \ell}\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{\ell j} \boldsymbol{z}_{(\ell)}^{\top} \boldsymbol{z}_{(q)}
$$

If $i \neq j$, the expectation of $\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{i k}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0}(g)\right)_{k \ell}\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{\ell j} \boldsymbol{z}_{(\ell)}^{\top} \boldsymbol{z}_{(q)}$ is zero unless $(k, \ell, q)=(i, j, i)$ or $(k, \ell, q)=(j, i, j)$, which leads to

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\left[\boldsymbol{K}_{0}(g) \odot\left(\sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{v} \boldsymbol{v}^{\top} \boldsymbol{S}\right)\right] \boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{i j}= & \frac{1}{m \sqrt{n}} \mathbb{E}\left[\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{i i}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0}(g)\right)_{i j}\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{j j} \boldsymbol{z}_{(i)}^{\top} \boldsymbol{z}_{(j)}\right] \\
& +\frac{1}{m \sqrt{n}} \mathbb{E}\left[\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{i j}^{2}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0}(g)\right)_{i j} \boldsymbol{z}_{(i)}^{\top} \boldsymbol{z}_{(j)}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Since $\left|\boldsymbol{z}_{(i)}^{\top} \boldsymbol{z}_{(j)}\right| \prec \sqrt{n}$ and $\|\boldsymbol{u}\|_{1} \leq \sqrt{m}$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbb{E}\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\left[\boldsymbol{K}_{0}(g) \odot\left(\sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{v} \boldsymbol{v}^{\top} \boldsymbol{S}\right)\right] \boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{i j}=O\left(n^{-1+\varepsilon}\right) \\
& \sum_{\substack{i, j \in[m] \\
i \neq j}} u_{i} u_{j} \mathbb{E}\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\left[\boldsymbol{K}_{0}(g) \odot\left(\sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{v} \boldsymbol{v}^{\top} \boldsymbol{S}\right)\right] \boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{i j}=O\left(n^{-1 / 2+\varepsilon}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

We now consider $i=j$. Using the identity

$$
\mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{z}_{(\ell)}}\left[\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{i k}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0}(g)\right)_{k \ell}\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{\ell i} \boldsymbol{z}_{(\ell)}^{\top} \boldsymbol{z}_{(q)}\right]=\mathbf{1}_{\ell=q} \mathbb{E}\left[\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{i k}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0}(g)\right)_{k \ell}\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{\ell i} \| \boldsymbol{z}_{(\ell)} \|_{2}^{2}\right]
$$

and exchangeability, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\left[\boldsymbol{K}_{0}(g) \odot\left(\sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{v} \boldsymbol{v}^{\top} \boldsymbol{S}\right)\right] \boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{i i}= & \frac{1}{m \sqrt{n}} \sum_{k, \ell=1}^{m} \mathbb{E}\left[\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{i k}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0}(g)\right)_{k \ell}\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{\ell i} \| \boldsymbol{z}_{(\ell)} \|_{2}^{2}\right] \\
= & \frac{(m-1)(m-2)}{m \sqrt{n}} \mathbb{E}\left[\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{12}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0}(g)\right)_{23}\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{31} \| \boldsymbol{z}_{(3)} \|_{2}^{2}\right] \\
& +\frac{m-1}{m \sqrt{n}} \mathbb{E}\left[\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{11}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0}(g)\right)_{12}\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{21} \| \boldsymbol{z}_{(1)} \|_{2}^{2}\right] \\
& +\frac{m-1}{m \sqrt{n}} \mathbb{E}\left[\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{11}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{0}(g)\right)_{12}\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{21} \| \boldsymbol{z}_{(2)} \|_{2}^{2}\right] \\
= & O\left(n^{-1 / 2+\varepsilon}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus,

$$
\sum_{i=1}^{m} u_{i}^{2} \mathbb{E}\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{0}\left[\boldsymbol{K}_{0}(g) \odot\left(\sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{v} \boldsymbol{v}^{\top} \boldsymbol{S}\right)\right] \boldsymbol{R}_{0}\right)_{i i}=O\left(n^{-1 / 2+\varepsilon}\right)
$$

The claim follows from (A.71) and (A.73).

# B Proof of Lemma 5.1 

In [26], a decomposition of $\boldsymbol{K}_{0}(f)$ is developed:

$$
\boldsymbol{K}_{0}(f)=\boldsymbol{Q}(f)+\boldsymbol{R}(f)+\boldsymbol{S}(f)
$$

Here, we have adopted the notation of [26]; $\boldsymbol{R}$ and $\boldsymbol{S}$ are distinct from the resolvent and sample covariance matrices that appear in the body of this paper. Proposition 5.2 and Lemma 6.1 in [26] prove there exists $n_{\varepsilon, D} \in \mathbb{N}$ such that

$$
\mathbb{P}\left(\|\boldsymbol{Q}(f)\|_{2}>(1+\varepsilon) \lambda_{+}\right) \leq n^{-D}, \quad \mathbb{P}\left(\|\boldsymbol{S}(f)\|_{2}>n^{-\varepsilon}\right) \leq n^{-D}
$$

for all $n \geq n_{\varepsilon, D}$, while Lemma 6.3 proves $\|\boldsymbol{R}(f)\|_{2} \xrightarrow{a.s.} 0$. Specifically, $\boldsymbol{R}(f)$ is given by

$$
\begin{gathered}
\boldsymbol{R}(f):=\sum_{\ell=1}^{L} \frac{a_{\ell}}{\sqrt{\ell!}}\binom{\ell}{2} \boldsymbol{R}_{\ell} \\
\left(\boldsymbol{R}_{\ell}\right)_{i k}:= \begin{cases}\frac{1}{n^{(\ell+1) / 2}} \sum_{\boldsymbol{j} \in \mathcal{J}_{\ell-1}}\left[\left(z_{i j_{1}}^{2} z_{k j_{1}}^{2}-1\right) \prod_{t=2}^{\ell-1} z_{i j_{t}} z_{k j_{t}}\right] & i \neq k \\
0 & i=k\end{cases}
\end{gathered}
$$

where $\mathcal{J}_{\ell}$ is the set of sequences $\boldsymbol{j}=\left(j_{1}, \ldots, j_{\ell}\right) \in[p]^{\ell}$ without repetitions. We will generalize the moment method of [26] to prove

$$
\left\|\boldsymbol{R}_{\ell}\right\|_{2} \prec n^{-1 / 2}
$$

for odd indices $\ell$, implying $\|\boldsymbol{R}(f)\|_{2} \prec n^{-1 / 2}$. Together with (B.2), this establishes Lemma 5.1.
Proof of (B.3). Using the identities

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(z_{i j_{1}}^{2} z_{k j_{1}}^{2}-1\right)=\left(z_{i j_{1}}^{2}-1\right)\left(z_{k j_{1}}^{2}-1\right)+\left(z_{i j_{1}}^{2}-1\right)+\left(z_{k j_{1}}^{2}-1\right) \\
\sum_{\boldsymbol{j} \in \mathcal{J}_{\ell-1}}\left[\left(z_{i j_{1}}^{2}-1\right) \prod_{t=2}^{\ell-1} z_{i j_{t}} z_{k j_{t}}\right]= & \left(\sum_{j=1}^{p}\left(z_{i j}^{2}-1\right)\right) \sum_{\boldsymbol{j} \in \mathcal{J}_{\ell-2}} \prod_{t=1}^{\ell-2} z_{i j_{t}} z_{k j_{t}} \\
& -(\ell-2) \sum_{\boldsymbol{j} \in \mathcal{J}_{\ell-2}}\left[\left(z_{i j_{1}}^{2}-1\right) z_{i j_{1}} z_{k j_{1}} \prod_{t=2}^{\ell-2} z_{i j_{t}} z_{k j_{t}}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

(we adopt the convention that $\prod_{\ell=2}^{1}=1$ ), we expand $\boldsymbol{R}_{\ell}$ as

$$
\boldsymbol{R}_{\ell}=\widetilde{\boldsymbol{R}}_{\ell}+\boldsymbol{D} \boldsymbol{A}_{\ell}+\boldsymbol{A}_{\ell} \boldsymbol{D}-\boldsymbol{B}_{\ell}
$$

Here, $\boldsymbol{D}$ is a diagonal matrix with

$$
(\boldsymbol{D})_{i i}:=\frac{1}{\sqrt{n}} \sum_{j=1}^{p}\left(z_{i j}^{2}-1\right)
$$

and $\widetilde{\boldsymbol{R}}_{\ell}, \boldsymbol{A}_{\ell}$, and $\boldsymbol{B}_{\ell}$ have zero diagonal and off-diagonal elements

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left(\widetilde{\boldsymbol{R}}_{\ell}\right)_{i k}:=\frac{1}{n^{(\ell+1) / 2}} \sum_{\boldsymbol{j} \in \mathcal{J}_{\ell-1}}\left[\left(z_{i j_{1}}^{2}-1\right)\left(z_{k j_{1}}^{2}-1\right) \prod_{t=2}^{\ell-1} z_{i j_{t}} z_{k j_{t}}\right] \\
& \left(\boldsymbol{A}_{\ell}\right)_{i k}:=\frac{1}{n^{\ell / 2}} \sum_{\boldsymbol{j} \in \mathcal{J}_{\ell-2}} \prod_{t=1}^{\ell-2} z_{i j_{t}} z_{k j_{t}} \\
& \left(\boldsymbol{B}_{\ell}\right)_{i k}:=\frac{1}{n^{(\ell+1) / 2}} \sum_{\boldsymbol{j} \in \mathcal{J}_{\ell-2}}\left[\left(z_{i j_{1}}^{2}+z_{k j_{1}}^{2}-2\right) z_{i j_{1}} z_{k j_{1}} \prod_{t=2}^{\ell-2} z_{i j_{t}} z_{k j_{t}}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

We will bound the operator norms of the matrices appearing in (B.4). By the sub-exponentiality of the Chi-squared distribution and a union bound, we have $\|\boldsymbol{D}\|_{2} \prec 1$. Moreover, Proposition 5.2 of [26] (applied to $h_{\ell-2}$ ) yields $\sqrt{n}\left\|\boldsymbol{A}_{\ell}\right\|_{2} \prec 1$. Thus, $\left\|\boldsymbol{D} \boldsymbol{A}_{\ell}+\boldsymbol{A}_{\ell} \boldsymbol{D}\right\|_{2} \prec n^{-1 / 2}$.

To bound $\widetilde{\boldsymbol{R}}_{\ell}$, we use the moment method: for $k \geq 2$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbb{E} \operatorname{tr}\left(\widetilde{\boldsymbol{R}}_{\ell}^{k}\right)=\frac{1}{n^{k(\ell+1) / 2}} \sum_{i_{1} \neq \ldots \neq i_{k} \in[n]} \sum_{\boldsymbol{j}^{(1)}, \ldots, \boldsymbol{j}^{(k)} \in \mathcal{J}_{\ell-1}} W\left(i_{1}, \ldots, i_{k}, \boldsymbol{j}^{(1)}, \ldots, \boldsymbol{j}^{(k)}\right) \\
& W\left(i_{1}, \ldots, i_{k}, \boldsymbol{j}^{(1)}, \ldots, \boldsymbol{j}^{(k)}\right):=\mathbb{E}\left[\prod_{s \in[k]}\left(\left(z_{i_{s} j_{1}^{(s)}} ^{2}-1\right)\left(z_{i_{s+1} j_{1}^{(s)}} ^{2}-1\right) \prod_{t=2}^{\ell-1} z_{i_{s} j_{t}^{(s)}} \bar{z}_{i_{s+1} j_{t}^{(s)}}\right)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

with the convention that $i_{k+1}=i_{1}$. We follow the $k$-graph approach in [26]. From Definitions 5.35.8, let $\mathcal{L}$ denote a multi-labeling, $[\mathcal{L}]$ its equivalence class, and $\Delta([\mathcal{L}]):=1+k \ell / 2-m$ the excess of $[\mathcal{L}]$, where $m$ is the number of distinct $n$ and $p$ labels in $[\mathcal{L}]$. Since $\mathbb{E} W\left(i_{1}, \ldots, i_{k}, \boldsymbol{j}^{(1)}, \ldots, \boldsymbol{j}^{(k)}\right) \lesssim 1$,

$$
\mathbb{E} \operatorname{tr}\left(\widetilde{\boldsymbol{R}}_{\ell}^{k}\right) \lesssim \frac{1}{n^{k(\ell+1) / 2}} \sum_{s=0}^{\infty} \sum_{[\mathcal{L}]: \Delta([\mathcal{L}])=s}|[\mathcal{L}]| \lesssim \frac{1}{n^{k(\ell+1) / 2}} \sum_{s=0}^{\infty} n^{1+k \ell / 2-s} \lesssim n^{1-k / 2}
$$

where the second bound uses that the number of equivalent classes is bounded and $|[\mathcal{L}]| \lesssim n^{m}$.
By Markov's inequality,

$$
\mathbb{P}\left(\left\|\widetilde{\boldsymbol{R}}_{\ell}\right\|_{2} \geq n^{-1 / 2+\varepsilon}\right) \leq \frac{1}{n^{-(1 / 2-\varepsilon) k}} \mathbb{E} \operatorname{tr}\left(\widetilde{\boldsymbol{R}}^{k}\right) \lesssim \frac{1}{n^{k \varepsilon-1}}
$$

Taking $k$ to be sufficiently large, we deduce that $\left\|\widetilde{\boldsymbol{R}}_{\ell}\right\|_{2} \prec n^{-1 / 2}$. The bound $\left\|\boldsymbol{B}_{\ell}\right\|_{2} \prec n^{-1 / 2}$ follows from a similar argument.

# C Proof of Lemma 5.4 

The proof extends the argument of Theorem 1.6 of [26]. We first develop a polynomial approximation of $f^{\prime}$; this approximation is uniform on closed intervals in which $f$ is twice differentiable.

Lemma C.1. Suppose $f(x)$ is odd and there exist finitely many points $x_{1}<\ldots<x_{k}$ such that $f(x)$ is twice-differentiable on $\left(-\infty, x_{1}\right),\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right), \ldots,\left(x_{k-1}, x_{k}\right),\left(x_{k}, \infty\right)$. Additionally, assume there exists a constant $c>0$ such that

$$
\max \left(|f(x)|,\left\|f^{\prime}(x)\right|,\left|f^{\prime \prime}(x)\right|\right) \leq c e^{c|x|}, \quad x \in \mathbb{R} \backslash\left\{x_{1}, \ldots, x_{k}\right\}
$$

Given $\varepsilon>0$, let $\Omega_{\varepsilon}:=\bigcup_{1 \leq i \leq k}\left(x_{i}-\varepsilon / k, x_{i}+\varepsilon / k\right)$, so that the Lebesgue measure or length of $\Omega_{\varepsilon}$ is at most $\varepsilon$. There exists an odd polynomial $q_{\varepsilon}$ such that the residual $\kappa(x):=f(x)-q_{\varepsilon}(x)$ satisfies

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\left|\kappa^{\prime}(x)\right| \leq C \varepsilon e^{C|x|} & x \in \mathbb{R} \backslash \Omega_{\varepsilon} \\
\left|\kappa^{\prime}(x)\right| \leq C e^{C|x|} & x \in \Omega_{\varepsilon} \backslash\left\{x_{1}, \ldots, x_{k}\right\}
\end{array}
$$

where $C>0$ is a constant depending only on $c$.
The proof of Lemma C. 1 is deferred to Section C.1. We stress that the specific conditions that Theorem 2.3 and Lemma C. 1 place on $f$ are not the focus of this paper and are likely improvablewe have developed a minimal extension of [26] that accommodates soft thresholding.

Lemma 5.4 is an immediate consequence of Lemma C. 1 and the following result:
Theorem C.2. Suppose that $\kappa(x)$ is odd, continuous everywhere, and differentiable at all but finitely many points, with the derivative satisfying (C.1) wherever it exists. Denote by $\boldsymbol{K}(\kappa)$ the corresponding transformed matrix (1.4). Almost surely,

$$
\limsup _{n \rightarrow \infty}\|\boldsymbol{K}(\kappa)\| \lesssim \varepsilon^{1 / 4} \quad \text { as } \quad n, p, m \rightarrow \infty
$$

The remainder of this section is devoted to proving Theorem C. 2 by adapting the proof of Theorem 1.6 in [26].

For brevity, we will use the shorthand $\boldsymbol{K}:=\boldsymbol{K}(\kappa)$. We write $\boldsymbol{Z} \boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{1 / 2} / \sqrt{n}=\sqrt{\lambda-1} \boldsymbol{\xi} \boldsymbol{v}^{\top}+\boldsymbol{N}$, where $\boldsymbol{N}$ has i.i.d. $\mathcal{N}(0,1 / n)$ entries; and $\boldsymbol{\xi}$, which collects the factor loadings, has i.i.d. $\mathcal{N}(0,1 / n)$ entries. Accordingly,

$$
\boldsymbol{Y}=(\lambda-1)\|\boldsymbol{\xi}\|^{2} \boldsymbol{v} \boldsymbol{v}^{\top}+\sqrt{\lambda-1} \boldsymbol{v}\left(\boldsymbol{N}^{\top} \boldsymbol{\xi}\right)^{\top}+\sqrt{\lambda-1}\left(\boldsymbol{N}^{\top} \boldsymbol{\xi}\right) \boldsymbol{v}^{\top}+\boldsymbol{N}^{\top} \boldsymbol{N}
$$

In what follows, we think of $\boldsymbol{v}, \boldsymbol{\xi}$ as fixed, so that $\|\boldsymbol{v}\|_{0} \leq m,\|\boldsymbol{v}\|_{\infty} \lesssim m^{-1 / 2},\|\boldsymbol{\xi}\|_{2} \lesssim 1$. We first bound the expectation of $\boldsymbol{K}$; note that it is not zero, owing to the presence of the spike.

Lemma C.3. Under the conditions of Theorem C.2,

$$
\|\mathbb{E}[\boldsymbol{K}]\|_{2} \lesssim \varepsilon
$$

The proof appears below in Section C.2. The core of the proof of Theorem 1.6 in [26] is a delicate net argument. The idea, originally due to Latała [44], is to construct an explicit net of the sphere where the number of points that have large $\ell^{\infty}$ norm is small.

Denote $\overline{\boldsymbol{K}}:=\boldsymbol{K}-\mathbb{E}[\boldsymbol{K}]$. For $\boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{y} \in \mathbb{R}^{p},\|\boldsymbol{x}\|,\|\boldsymbol{y}\| \leq 1$, let $F_{\boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{y}}(\boldsymbol{N}):=\boldsymbol{x}^{\top} \overline{\boldsymbol{K}} \boldsymbol{y}$, where we think of $\overline{\boldsymbol{K}}$ as a function of $\boldsymbol{N}$. A key step in [26] is a bound on the gradient of $F_{\boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{y}}$.

Lemma C.4. The following holds with probability one:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\|\nabla_{\boldsymbol{N}} F_{\boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{y}}(\boldsymbol{N})\right\|^{2} \leq & 8\|\boldsymbol{N}\|^{2}\|\boldsymbol{y}\|_{\infty} \max _{1 \leq \ell \leq p}\left(\sum_{i \neq \ell}\left(\kappa^{\prime}\left(\sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{Y}_{i \ell}\right)\right)^{4}\right)^{1 / 2} \\
& +8(\lambda-1)\|\boldsymbol{\xi}\|^{2}\|\boldsymbol{v}\|_{\infty}^{2} \max _{i \leq \ell \leq p} \sum_{i \in \operatorname{supp}(\boldsymbol{v}) \backslash\{\ell\}}\left|\kappa^{\prime}\left(\sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{Y}_{i \ell}\right)\right|^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

The proof is given below in Section C.3. As in [26], we restrict attention to a high-probability subset of matrices $\boldsymbol{N}$ on which $F_{\boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{y}}(\boldsymbol{N})$ is Lipschitz. Fix $D>0$. For sufficiently large $C=C(D)$, let $\mathcal{G} \subseteq \mathbb{R}^{n \times p}$ be the subset of matrices $\boldsymbol{N}$ satisfying

(1) $\|\boldsymbol{N}\| \leq C(1+\sqrt{\gamma})^{2}$,
(2) $\max _{1 \leq \ell \leq p} \sum_{i=1, i \neq \ell}^{p}\left(\kappa^{\prime}\left(\sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{Y}_{i \ell}\right)\right)^{4} \leq p C \varepsilon$,
(3) $\max _{1 \leq \ell \leq p} \sum_{i \in \operatorname{supp}(\boldsymbol{v}) \backslash\{\ell\}}\left|\kappa^{\prime}\left(\sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{Y}_{i \ell}\right)\right|^{2} \leq m C \varepsilon$.

Lemma C.5. Under the conditions of Theorem C.2, $\mathbb{P}(\boldsymbol{N} \notin \mathcal{G}) \lesssim n^{-D}$.
The proof is essentially identical to that of Lemma 3.1 in [26] and is omitted. Note that Lemma C. 4 implies that $F_{\boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{y}}$ is Lipschitz on $\mathcal{G}$, with

$$
L:=\left\|F_{\boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{y}}\right\|_{\mathcal{G}} \|^{2} \sup _{L \mathrm{lip}} \lesssim\|y\|_{\infty} \sqrt{p \varepsilon}+\|\xi\|^{2}\|\boldsymbol{v}\|_{\infty}^{2} m \varepsilon \lesssim\|y\|_{\infty} \sqrt{p \varepsilon}
$$

Here, we used that $\|\boldsymbol{v}\|_{\infty} \lesssim m^{-1 / 2}$ and $\varepsilon<1$ (by assumption), and $\|\xi\| \lesssim 1$ (note that $p\|y\|_{\infty}^{2} \geq 1$, hence the first term is always the dominant one).

We now show that $F_{\boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{y}}$ concentrates, using the Gaussian Lipschitz concentration inequality. To this end, recall a well-known result on Lipschitz extension.

Theorem C. 6 (Kirszbraun). Let $F: \mathcal{G} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{d_{2}}, \mathcal{G} \subseteq \mathbb{R}^{d_{1}}$, be L-Lipschitz. Then $F$ has an $L$ Lipschitz extension to $\mathbb{R}^{d_{1}}$ :

$$
\tilde{F}: \mathbb{R}^{d_{1}} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{d_{2}}, \quad \tilde{F} \mid{ }_{\mathcal{G}}=F
$$

When $d_{2}=1$ and $\mathcal{G}$ is compact, there is a simple construction:

$$
\tilde{F}(x)=\min _{y \in \mathcal{G}}(F(y)+L\|x-y\|)
$$

Let $\tilde{F}_{\boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{y}}$ be a Lipschitz extension of $\left.F_{\boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{y}}\right|_{\mathcal{G}}$.
Lemma C.7. Under the conditions of Theorem C.2, for $\tilde{D}=\tilde{D}(D)$ that can be made arbitrarily small,

$$
\left|\mathbb{E}\left[\tilde{F}_{\boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{y}}(\boldsymbol{N})\right]-\mathbb{E}\left[F_{\boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{y}}(\boldsymbol{N})\right]\right| \lesssim n^{-\tilde{D}}
$$

Proof. For $\boldsymbol{N} \notin \mathcal{G}$

$$
\left|F_{\boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{y}}(\boldsymbol{N})\right| \leq\|\tilde{\boldsymbol{K}}\|_{2} \leq\|\tilde{\boldsymbol{K}}\|_{F}, \quad\left|\tilde{F}_{\boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{y}}(\boldsymbol{N})\right| \leq F_{\boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{y}}(0)+L\|\boldsymbol{N}\|_{F}
$$

We have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|\mathbb{E}\left[F_{\boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{y}}(\boldsymbol{N}) \mathbf{1}_{\boldsymbol{N} \notin \mathcal{G}}\right]\right| & \leq\left(\mathbb{E}\left|F_{\boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{y}}(\boldsymbol{N})\right|^{2}\right)^{1 / 2}(\mathbb{P}(\boldsymbol{N} \notin \mathcal{G}))^{1 / 2} \\
& \leq\left(\mathbb{E}\|\boldsymbol{K}\|_{F}^{2}\right)^{1 / 2}(\mathbb{P}(\boldsymbol{N} \notin \mathcal{G}))^{1 / 2} \lesssim p n^{-D / 2} \lesssim n^{-\tilde{D}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Similarly one can bound $\left|\mathbb{E}\left[\tilde{F}_{\boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{y}}(\boldsymbol{N}) \mathbf{1}_{\boldsymbol{N} \notin \mathcal{G}}\right]\right|$.
Lemma C.8. For $t>0$,

$$
\mathbb{P}\left(\tilde{F}_{\boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{y}}(\boldsymbol{N}) \gtrsim n^{-\tilde{D}}+\varepsilon t\right) \leq 2 e^{-\sqrt{p} t^{2} /\|\boldsymbol{y}\|_{\infty}}
$$

Proof. Gaussian Lipschitz concentration.
Finally, we apply the net argument of [26]. As in Section 2 of [26], let

$$
D_{2}^{p}=\left\{\boldsymbol{y} \in \mathbb{R}^{p}:\|\boldsymbol{y}\| \leq 1, y_{i}^{2} \in\left\{0,1,2^{-1}, \ldots, 2^{-(K+3)}\right\}\right\}, \quad K:=\left\lceil\log _{2} p\right\rceil
$$

Lemma C. 9 (Lemma 3.3 of [26]). For $\boldsymbol{A}$ symmetric, $\|\boldsymbol{A}\|_{2} \leq 10 \max _{\boldsymbol{y} \in D_{2}^{p}} \boldsymbol{y}^{\top} \boldsymbol{A} \boldsymbol{y}$.
For $l=0,1, \ldots, K+3$, define the projection $\pi_{l \backslash(l-1)}$ (resp. $\pi_{l}$ ) on dyadic scale $l$ (resp. $\leq l$ ):

$$
\pi_{l \backslash(l-1)}(\boldsymbol{y})_{i}=y_{i} \mathbf{1}_{y_{i}^{2}=2^{-l}}, \quad \pi_{l}(\boldsymbol{y})_{i}=y_{i} \mathbf{1}_{y_{i}^{2} \geq 2^{-l}}
$$

As shown in [26, Eq. (7)],

$$
\boldsymbol{y}^{\top} \overline{\boldsymbol{K}} \boldsymbol{y}=\sum_{l=0}^{K+3} \pi_{l}(\boldsymbol{y})^{\top} \overline{\boldsymbol{K}} \pi_{l \backslash(l-1)}(\boldsymbol{y})+\sum_{l=0}^{K+3} \pi_{l \backslash(l-1)}(\boldsymbol{y})^{\top} \overline{\boldsymbol{K}} \pi_{l-1}(\boldsymbol{y})
$$

Lemma C. 10 (Lemma 3.4 of [26]). There exists an absolute constant $C>0$ such that

$$
\left|\left\{\pi_{l}(\boldsymbol{y}): \boldsymbol{y} \in D_{2}^{p}\right\}\right| \leq \exp \left(C(K+4-l) 2^{l}\right), \quad l \in\{0,1, \ldots, K+3\}
$$

For $c_{0}$ large enough, set

$$
t_{l}^{2}=c_{0}(K+4-l) 2^{l / 2} \frac{1}{\sqrt{p}}
$$

As shown in the proof of Theorem 1.6 in [26],

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sum_{l=0}^{K+3} t_{l} & \leq c_{0}^{1 / 2} p^{-1 / 4} \sum_{l=0}^{K+3}(K+4-l) 2^{l / 4} \leq c_{0}^{1 / 2} p^{-1 / 4} \sum_{l=0}^{K+3} \sum_{j=0}^{l} 2^{j / 4} \\
& \lesssim p^{-1 / 4} \sum_{l=0}^{K+3} 2^{l / 4} \lesssim p^{-1 / 4} 2^{K / 4}=p^{-1 / 4} 2^{\frac{1}{4}\left[\log _{2} p\right]}=O(1)
\end{aligned}
$$

Proof of Theorem C.2. By Lemma C.9, (C.5), and (C.8), it suffices to show that

$$
\sup _{y \in D_{2}^{p}} \pi_{l}(\boldsymbol{y})^{\top} \overline{\boldsymbol{K}} \pi_{l \backslash(l-1)}(\boldsymbol{y}), \sup _{y \in D_{2}^{p}} \pi_{l \backslash(l-1)}(\boldsymbol{y})^{\top} \overline{\boldsymbol{K}} \pi_{l-1}(\boldsymbol{y}) \lesssim n^{-\tilde{D}}+\varepsilon t_{l}, \quad \ell \in\{0,1, \ldots, K+3\}
$$

with high probability. Without loss of generality, we focus on terms

$$
\pi_{l}(\boldsymbol{y})^{\top} \overline{\boldsymbol{K}} \pi_{l \backslash(l-1)}(\boldsymbol{y})=: F_{\pi_{l}(\boldsymbol{y}), \pi_{l \backslash(l-1)}(\boldsymbol{y})}(\boldsymbol{N})
$$

the other terms are similar. Under the high-probability event $F_{\boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{y}}(\boldsymbol{N})=\tilde{F}_{\boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{y}}(\boldsymbol{N})$ for any $\boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{y}$, where $\tilde{F}$ is the Lipschitz extension of $\left.F\right|_{\mathcal{G}}$. Consequently, as $\operatorname{Pr}(\boldsymbol{N} \notin \mathcal{G}) \lesssim n^{-D}$,

$$
\mathbb{P}\left(\sup _{\boldsymbol{y} \in D_{2}^{p}} F_{\pi_{l}(\boldsymbol{y}), \pi_{l \backslash(l-1)}(\boldsymbol{y})}(\boldsymbol{N}) \gtrsim n^{-\tilde{D}}+\varepsilon t_{l}\right) \lesssim \mathbb{P}\left(\sup _{\boldsymbol{y} \in D_{2}^{p}} \tilde{F}_{\pi_{l}(\boldsymbol{y}), \pi_{l \backslash(l-1)}(\boldsymbol{y})}(\boldsymbol{N}) \gtrsim n^{-\tilde{D}}+\varepsilon t_{l}\right)+n^{-D}
$$

Denote

$$
\Pi_{l}=\left\{\pi_{l}(\boldsymbol{y}): \boldsymbol{y} \in D_{2}^{p}\right\}, \quad \Pi_{l \backslash(l-1)}=\left\{\pi_{l \backslash(l-1)}(\boldsymbol{y}): \boldsymbol{y} \in D_{2}^{p}\right\}, \quad 0 \leq l \leq K+3
$$

Clearly, $\sup _{\boldsymbol{y} \in D_{2}^{p}} \tilde{F}_{\pi_{l}(\boldsymbol{y}), \pi_{l \backslash(l-1)}(\boldsymbol{y})}(\boldsymbol{N}) \leq \sup _{\boldsymbol{x} \in \Pi_{l \backslash(l-1)}, \boldsymbol{x} \in \Pi_{l}} \tilde{F}_{\boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{x}}(\boldsymbol{N})$. By Lemma C.10, $\left|\Pi_{l \backslash(l-1)}\right| \leq$ $\left|\Pi_{l}\right| \leq \exp \left(C(K+4-l) 2^{l}\right)$. Consequently, using a union bound, we bound the first term in the r.h.s. of (C.9) as

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{P}\left(\sup _{\boldsymbol{x} \in \Pi_{l \backslash(l-1)}, \boldsymbol{x} \in \Pi_{l}} \tilde{F}_{\boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{x}}(\boldsymbol{N}) \gtrsim n^{-\tilde{D}}+\varepsilon t_{l}\right) & \leq\left|\Pi_{l \backslash(l-1)}\right|\left|\Pi_{l}\right| \sup _{\boldsymbol{x} \in \Pi_{l \backslash(l-1)}, \boldsymbol{x} \in \Pi_{l}} \mathbb{P}\left(\tilde{F}_{\boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{x}}(\boldsymbol{N}) \gtrsim n^{-\tilde{D}}+\varepsilon t_{l}\right) \\
& \lesssim e^{2 C(K+4-l) 2^{l}} \sup _{\boldsymbol{x} \in \Pi_{l \backslash(l-1)}, \boldsymbol{x} \in \Pi_{l}} \exp \left(-\frac{\sqrt{p}}{\|\boldsymbol{x}\|_{\infty}} t_{l}^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Using $\|\boldsymbol{x}\|_{\infty}=2^{-l / 2}$ and $t_{l}^{2}=c_{0}(K+4-l) 2^{l / 2} \frac{1}{\sqrt{p}}$, the above is $\lesssim e^{\left(2 C-c_{0}\right)(K+4-l) 2^{l}}$. Choosing $c_{0}$ sufficiently large but constant, so that $c_{1}:=c_{0}-2 C$ is large, we can guarantee that $e^{-c_{1}(K+4-l) 2^{l}} \leq$ $e^{-c_{1}\left(\log _{2} p+4-l\right) 2^{l}}$ is smaller than $p^{-C}$ for any pre-specified $C>0$. Finally taking a union bound over all $0 \leq l \leq K+3 \lesssim \log p$

$$
\mathbb{P}\left(\max _{0 \leq l \leq K+3} \sup _{\boldsymbol{y} \in D_{2}^{p}} F_{\pi_{l}(\boldsymbol{y}), \pi_{l \backslash(l-1)}(\boldsymbol{y})}(\boldsymbol{N}) \gtrsim n^{-\tilde{D}}+\varepsilon t_{l}\right) \leq(K+3) p^{-C}+n^{-\tilde{D}} \asymp n^{-\tilde{D}^{\prime}}
$$

As explained before, Theorem C. 2 now follows using Lemma C.9.

# C. 1 Proof of Lemma C. 1 

The proof is an adaption of that of Theorem 1.4 in [26], with an additional smoothing step. The latter is necessary because $f^{\prime}$ is not assumed to be continuous as in [26].

For $\eta \in(0,1)$, let $T_{\eta}: L^{2}(\phi) \rightarrow L^{2}(\phi)$ be the Gaussian smoothing operator,

$$
T_{\eta}[f](x):=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \pi} \eta} \int f(y) e^{-(x-y)^{2} /\left(2 \eta^{2}\right)} d y
$$

Note that under the conditions of Lemma C.1, $T_{\eta}[f]$ is odd and everywhere twice-differentiable, with $\left(T_{\eta}[f]\right)^{\prime}=T_{\eta}\left[f^{\prime}\right],\left(T_{\eta}[f]\right)^{\prime \prime}=T_{\eta}\left[f^{\prime \prime}\right]$ and $\left|T_{\eta}[f](x)\right|,\left|T_{\eta}\left[f^{\prime}\right](x)\right|,\left|T_{\eta}\left[f^{\prime \prime}\right](x)\right| \lesssim e^{c_{1}|x|}$. We shall show that (1) $T_{\eta}\left[f^{\prime}\right]$ approximates $f^{\prime}$ well away from its discontinuity points; and (2) $T_{\eta}\left[f^{\prime}\right]$ is uniformly approximated by a polynomial. We note that the second step, which relies on the differentiability of $T_{\eta}\left[f^{\prime}\right]$, follows from [26] immediately.

We next show that $T_{\eta}\left[f^{\prime}\right]$ approximates $f^{\prime}$ uniformly on $\mathbb{R} \backslash \Omega_{\varepsilon}$. Note that on $\Omega_{\varepsilon} \backslash\left\{x_{i}\right\}_{1 \leq i \leq N}$, we already have $\left|f^{\prime}(x)-T_{\eta}\left[f^{\prime}\right](x)\right| \lesssim e^{c_{1}|x|}$. Define $\delta_{\varepsilon}:=\varepsilon / k$. Let $x \in \mathbb{R} \backslash \Omega_{\varepsilon}$. By definition, $f^{\prime}, f^{\prime \prime}$ exist on $I_{x, \varepsilon}:=\left(x-\delta_{\varepsilon}, x+\delta_{\varepsilon}\right)$. By the mean value theorem, for $y \in I_{x, \varepsilon}$,

$$
\left|f^{\prime}(y)-f^{\prime}(x)\right| \leq \max _{z \in(x, y)}\left|f^{\prime \prime}(z)\right||x-y| \lesssim e^{C \max \{|x|,|y|\}}|x-y| \lesssim|x-y| e^{C|x|+C|x-y|}
$$

Decompose

$$
f^{\prime}(x)-T_{\eta}\left[f^{\prime} \mid(x)=\mathbb{E}\left[\left(f^{\prime}(x)-f^{\prime}(x+\eta G)\right) \mathbf{1}_{\left[G \mid \leq \delta_{\varepsilon} / \eta\right]}+\mathbb{E}\left[\left(f^{\prime}(x)-f^{\prime}(x+\eta G)\right) \mathbf{1}_{\left[G \mid>\delta_{\varepsilon} / \eta\right]}\right.\right.
$$

Using (C.11), the first term satisfies

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|\mathbb{E}\left[\left(f^{\prime}(x)-f^{\prime}(x+\eta G)\right) \mathbf{1}_{\left[G \mid \leq \delta_{\varepsilon} / \eta\right]}\right]\right| \lesssim e^{C|x|} \mathbb{E}\left[e^{C \eta|G|}|\eta G| \mathbf{1}_{\left[G \mid \leq \delta_{\varepsilon} / \eta\right]}\right. & \leq e^{C|x|} \delta_{\varepsilon} e^{C \delta_{\varepsilon}} \mathbb{E}\left[\mathbf{1}_{\left[G \mid \leq \delta_{\varepsilon} / \eta\right]}\right. \\
& \lesssim e^{C|x|} \delta_{\varepsilon} \asymp e^{C|x|} \varepsilon
\end{aligned}
$$

where we used that $\delta_{\varepsilon} \asymp \varepsilon \lesssim 1$. For the second term,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|\mathbb{E}\left[\left(f^{\prime}(x)-f^{\prime}(x+\eta G)\right) \mathbf{1}_{\left[G \mid>\delta_{\varepsilon} / \eta\right]}\right]\right| & \lesssim e^{2 C|x|} \mathbb{E}\left[e^{C \eta|G|} \mathbf{1}_{\left[G \mid>\delta_{\varepsilon} / \eta\right]}\right. \\
& \leq e^{2 C|x|}\left(\mathbb{E}\left[e^{2 C \eta|G|}\right]\right)^{1 / 2}\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\mathbf{1}_{\left[G \mid>\delta_{\varepsilon} / \eta\right]}\right]\right)^{1 / 2} \\
& \lesssim e^{C_{1}|x|} e^{C_{2} \eta^{2}} e^{-C_{3}\left(\delta_{\varepsilon} / \eta\right)^{2}} \lesssim e^{C_{1}|x|} e^{-C_{4}(\varepsilon / \eta)^{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

where the second inequality follows from the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality and the final two inequalities follow from $\eta \lesssim 1,=$ and the Gaussian tail behavior. Choosing $\eta=\eta_{\varepsilon} \asymp \varepsilon / \sqrt{\log (1 / \varepsilon)}$, which is $\leq 1$ for small $\varepsilon>0$, implies that the above is $\lesssim e^{C_{1}|x|} \varepsilon$. Combining our bounds for the two terms

above, we deduce that for any $x \in \mathbb{R} \backslash \Omega_{\varepsilon},\left|f^{\prime}(x)-T_{\eta_{\varepsilon}}[f](x)\right| \lesssim e^{c_{1}|x|} \varepsilon$. Combining with the coarse bound we had before for $x \in \Omega_{\varepsilon}$,

$$
\left|f^{\prime}(x)-T_{\eta_{\varepsilon}}\left[f^{\prime}\right](x)\right| \lesssim e^{C|x|} \varepsilon+e^{C|x|} \mathbf{1}_{\Omega_{\varepsilon}}(x)
$$

for appropriate $C>0$.
The final step is to approximate $T_{\eta_{\varepsilon}}[f]$ by a polynomial uniformly. This follows from the argument of [26, Proof of Theorem 1.4], which yields a polynomial $q_{\varepsilon}$ such that $\kappa_{1}(x)=T_{\eta}[f](x)-$ $q_{\varepsilon}(x)$ satisfies $\left|\kappa_{1}^{\prime}(x)\right| \lesssim \varepsilon e^{C|x|}$ for all $x \in \mathbb{R}$. The residual $\kappa(x)=f(x)-q_{\varepsilon}(x)$ therefore satisfies

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|\kappa^{\prime}(x)\right| & \leq\left|f^{\prime}(x)-\left(T_{\eta}[f]\right)^{\prime}(x)\right|+\left|\kappa_{1}^{\prime}(x)\right| \\
& \lesssim e^{C|x|} \varepsilon+e^{C|x|} \mathbf{1}_{x \in \Omega_{\varepsilon}}
\end{aligned}
$$

for all $x \neq x_{1}, \ldots, x_{k}$, completing proof.

# C. 2 Proof of Lemma C. 3 

Let $\boldsymbol{N}_{1}, \ldots, \boldsymbol{N}_{p} \in \mathbb{R}^{n}$ denote the columns of $\boldsymbol{N}$. Recall that $\boldsymbol{K}(\kappa)_{i, i}=0$ and for $i \neq j$,

$$
(\boldsymbol{K}(\kappa))_{i j}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{n}} \kappa\left(\sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{Y}_{i j}\right)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{n}} \kappa\left(\sqrt{n}(\lambda-1)\|\xi\|^{2} v_{i} v_{j}+\boldsymbol{A}_{i j}\right)
$$

where $\boldsymbol{A}_{i j}=\sqrt{n}\left(\sqrt{\lambda-1} v_{i} \boldsymbol{N}_{j}^{\top} \boldsymbol{\xi}+\sqrt{\lambda-1} v_{j} \boldsymbol{N}_{i}^{\top} \boldsymbol{\xi}+\boldsymbol{N}_{i}^{\top} \boldsymbol{N}_{j}\right)$.
Recall that $\kappa$ is continuous and piecewise differentiable, hence the fundamental theorem of calculus holds. For brevity, denote $\eta_{i, j}:=\sqrt{n}(\lambda-1)\|\xi\|^{2} v_{i} v_{j}$, so that $\sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{Y}_{i j}=\boldsymbol{A}_{i j}+\eta_{i, j}$. Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
\kappa\left(\sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{Y}_{i j}\right)-\kappa\left(\boldsymbol{A}_{i j}\right) & =\int_{\left[0, \eta_{i, j}\right]} \kappa^{\prime}\left(\boldsymbol{A}_{i j}+t\right) d t \\
& =\int_{\left[0, \eta_{i, j}\right] \cap\left(\Omega_{\varepsilon}-\boldsymbol{A}_{i j}\right)} \kappa^{\prime}\left(\boldsymbol{A}_{i j}+t\right) d t+\int_{\left[0, \eta_{i, j}\right] \backslash\left(\Omega_{\varepsilon}-\boldsymbol{A}_{i j}\right)} \kappa^{\prime}\left(\boldsymbol{A}_{i j}+t\right) d t
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\Omega_{\varepsilon}$ is the set from Lemma C.1. We can bound each term using (C.1). Indeed,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|\int_{\left[0, \eta_{i, j}\right] \cap\left(\Omega_{\varepsilon}-\boldsymbol{A}_{i j}\right)} \kappa^{\prime}\left(\boldsymbol{A}_{i j}+t\right) d t\right| & \leq\left|\left[0, \eta_{i, j}\right] \cap \Omega_{\varepsilon}\right| \cdot \max _{t \in\left[0, \eta_{i, j}\right] \cap\left(\Omega_{\varepsilon}-\boldsymbol{A}_{i j}\right)}\left|\kappa^{\prime}\left(\boldsymbol{A}_{i j}+t\right)\right| \\
& \lesssim \varepsilon \cdot e^{c_{1}\left|\eta_{i, j}\right|} e^{c_{1}\left|\boldsymbol{A}_{i j}\right|} \cdot \lesssim e^{c_{1}\left|\boldsymbol{A}_{i j}\right|} \varepsilon
\end{aligned}
$$

where we used that $\eta_{i, j} \lesssim 1$ (thinking of $\lambda$ as constant), since $\left|v_{i} v_{j}\right| \in\{0,1 / \sqrt{n}\}$. As for the other term,

$$
\left|\int_{\left[0, \eta_{i, j}\right] \backslash\left(\Omega_{\varepsilon}-\boldsymbol{A}_{i j}\right)} \kappa^{\prime}\left(\boldsymbol{A}_{i j}+t\right) d t\right| \lesssim \int_{\left[0, \eta_{i, j}\right]}\left(e^{c_{1}\left|\boldsymbol{A}_{i j}+t\right|} \varepsilon\right) d t \lesssim e^{c_{1}\left|\boldsymbol{A}_{i j}\right|} \varepsilon
$$

It is straightforward to verify that $\mathbb{E}\left[e^{c_{1}\left|A_{i, j}\right|}\right] \lesssim 1$ (again, thinking of $\lambda$ as constant). For completeness' sake, let us verify this for the heavier-tailed term $\mathbb{E}\left[e^{c_{1} \sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{N}_{i}^{\top} \boldsymbol{N}_{j}}\right]$. Conditioned on $\boldsymbol{N}_{i}$, $\sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{N}_{i}^{\top} \boldsymbol{N}_{j} \sim \mathcal{N}\left(0,\left\|\boldsymbol{N}_{i}\right\|^{2}\right)$. Thus,

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[e^{c_{1} \sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{N}_{i}^{\top} \boldsymbol{N}_{j}}\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[e^{c_{1}^{2}\left\|\boldsymbol{N}_{i}\right\|^{2} / 2}\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[e^{c_{1}^{2} \chi^{2}(n) /(2 n)}\right]=\left(1-c_{1}^{2} / n\right)^{-n / 2} \approx e^{-c_{1}^{2} / 2}
$$

where $\chi^{2}(n)$ denotes a chi-squared random variable with $n$ degrees of freedom (note that $\sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{N}_{i}^{\top} \boldsymbol{N}_{j}$ tends to a $\mathcal{N}(0,1)$ random variable.)

Now, note that $\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{A}_{i j}\right]=0$, since $\boldsymbol{A}_{i j}$ has a symmetric distribution. Thus,

$$
\left|\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{K}_{i, j}\right]\right|=\frac{1}{\sqrt{n}}\left|\mathbb{E} \kappa\left(\sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{Y}_{i j}\right)-\mathbb{E} \kappa\left(\boldsymbol{A}_{i j}\right)\right| \lesssim \frac{\varepsilon}{\sqrt{n}} \mathbb{E}\left[e^{c_{1}\left|\boldsymbol{A}_{i j}\right|}\right] \lesssim \frac{\varepsilon}{\sqrt{n}}
$$

Also note that $\sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{Y}_{i j}$ differs from $\boldsymbol{A}_{i j}$ only when $i, j \in \operatorname{supp}(v)$; accordingly, $\mathbb{E}[\boldsymbol{K}]$ has at most $m^{2} \asymp n$ nonzero entries. Thus,

$$
\|\mathbb{E} \boldsymbol{K}\|_{2} \leq\|\mathbb{E} \boldsymbol{K}\|_{F} \lesssim m \cdot \frac{1}{\sqrt{n}} \varepsilon \lesssim \varepsilon
$$

# C. 3 Proof of Lemma C. 4 

As in the previous section, denote by $\boldsymbol{N}_{1}, \ldots, \boldsymbol{N}_{p} \in \mathbb{R}^{n}$ the columns of $\boldsymbol{N}$.
The gradient of an entry $(i \neq j)$ with respect to $\boldsymbol{N}_{\ell}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\nabla_{\boldsymbol{N}_{\ell}}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{i, j}\right)= & \nabla_{\boldsymbol{N}_{\ell}} \frac{1}{\sqrt{n}} \kappa\left((\lambda-1)\|\boldsymbol{\xi}\|^{2} \sqrt{n} v_{i} v_{j}+\sqrt{\lambda-1} \sqrt{n} v_{i}\left\langle\boldsymbol{N}_{j}, \boldsymbol{\xi}\right\rangle\right. \\
& \left.+\sqrt{\lambda-1} \sqrt{n} v_{j}\left\langle\boldsymbol{N}_{i}, \boldsymbol{\xi}\right\rangle+\sqrt{n}\left\langle\boldsymbol{N}_{i}, \boldsymbol{N}_{j}\right\rangle\right) \\
= & \kappa^{\prime}\left(\sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{Y}_{i j}\right)\left(\sqrt{\lambda-1} v_{i} \boldsymbol{\xi} \mathbf{1}_{j=\ell}+\sqrt{\lambda-1} v_{j} \boldsymbol{\xi} \mathbf{1}_{i=\ell}+\boldsymbol{N}_{i} \mathbf{1}_{j=\ell}+\boldsymbol{N}_{j} \mathbf{1}_{i=\ell}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Denote the following vectors $\boldsymbol{a}_{i j}^{(\ell)}, \boldsymbol{b}_{i j}^{(\ell)} \in \mathbb{R}^{n}, 1 \leq i, j, \ell \leq p$, so that $\nabla_{\boldsymbol{N}_{\ell}} \boldsymbol{K}_{i, j}=\boldsymbol{a}_{i j}^{(\ell)}+\boldsymbol{b}_{i j}^{(\ell)}$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
