\boldsymbol{a}_{i j}^{(\ell)} & =\sqrt{\lambda-1} \kappa^{\prime}\left(\sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{Y}_{i j}\right) \cdot\left(v_{i} \boldsymbol{\xi} \mathbf{1}_{j=\ell}+v_{j} \boldsymbol{\xi} \mathbf{1}_{i=\ell}\right) \\
\boldsymbol{b}_{i j}^{(\ell)} & =\kappa^{\prime}\left(\sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{Y}_{i j}\right) \cdot\left(\boldsymbol{N}_{i} \mathbf{1}_{j=\ell}+\boldsymbol{N}_{j} \mathbf{1}_{i=\ell}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

We have $\nabla_{\boldsymbol{N}_{\ell}} F_{\boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{y}}(\boldsymbol{N})=\sum_{1 \leq i, j \leq p} x_{i} y_{i} \nabla_{\boldsymbol{N}_{\ell}}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{i, j}\right) \in \mathbb{R}^{n}$. The total gradient of $F_{\boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{y}}$ with respect to $\boldsymbol{N}$ satisfies

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\|\nabla_{\boldsymbol{N}} F_{\boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{y}}(\boldsymbol{N})\right\|^{2} & =\sum_{\ell=1}^{p}\left\|\nabla_{\boldsymbol{N}_{\ell}} F_{\boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{y}}(\boldsymbol{N})\right\|^{2}=\sum_{\ell=1}^{p}\left\|\sum_{1 \leq i, j \leq p} x_{i} y_{i} \nabla_{\boldsymbol{N}_{\ell}}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{i, j}\right)\right\|^{2} \\
& \leq 2 \sum_{\ell=1}^{p}\left\|\sum_{1 \leq i, j \leq p} x_{i} y_{i} \boldsymbol{a}_{i j}^{(\ell)}\right\|^{2}+2 \sum_{\ell=1}^{p}\left\|\sum_{1 \leq i, j \leq p} x_{i} y_{i} \boldsymbol{b}_{i j}^{(\ell)}\right\|^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

Note that the vectors $\boldsymbol{b}_{i j}^{(\ell)}$ depend on the spike only through $\kappa^{\prime}\left(\boldsymbol{Y}_{i j}\right)$. To bound the second term, we apply (10) in [26]:

$$
\sum_{\ell=1}^{p}\left\|\sum_{1 \leq i, j \leq p} x_{i} y_{j} \boldsymbol{b}_{i, j}^{(\ell)}\right\|^{2} \leq 4\|\boldsymbol{N}\|^{2}\|\boldsymbol{y}\|_{\infty} \max _{1 \leq \ell \leq p}\left(\sum_{i \neq \ell}\left(\kappa^{\prime}\left(\sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{Y}_{i \ell}\right)^{4}\right)^{1 / 2}\right.
$$

As for the first term, by the definition of $\boldsymbol{a}_{i j}^{(\ell)}$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sum_{\ell=1}^{p}\left\|\sum_{1 \leq i, j, \leq p} x_{i} y_{j} \boldsymbol{a}_{i j}^{(\ell)}\right\|^{2}= & (\lambda-1)\|\boldsymbol{\xi}\|^{2} \sum_{\ell=1}^{p}\left[y_{\ell} \sum_{i=1, i \neq \ell}^{p} \kappa^{\prime}\left(\sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{Y}_{i \ell}\right) x_{i} v_{i}+x_{\ell} \sum_{j=1, j \neq \ell}^{p} \kappa^{\prime}\left(\sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{Y}_{j \ell}\right) y_{j} v_{j}\right]^{2} \\
\leq & 2(\lambda-1)\|\boldsymbol{\xi}\|^{2} \sum_{\ell=1}^{p} y_{\ell}^{2}\left(\sum_{i=1, i \neq \ell}^{p} \kappa^{\prime}\left(\sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{Y}_{i \ell}\right) x_{i} v_{i}\right)^{2} \\
& +2 \tau^{2}\|\boldsymbol{\xi}\|^{2} \sum_{\ell=1}^{p} x_{\ell}^{2}\left(\sum_{j=1, i \neq \ell}^{p} \kappa^{\prime}\left(\sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{Y}_{j \ell}\right) y_{j} v_{j}\right)^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

Using the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality and $\|\boldsymbol{x}\|,\|\boldsymbol{y}\| \leq 1$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sum_{\ell=1}^{p} y_{\ell}^{2}\left(\sum_{i=1, i \neq \ell}^{p} \kappa^{\prime}\left(\sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{Y}_{i \ell}\right) x_{i} v_{i}\right)^{2} & \leq \sum_{\ell=1}^{p} y_{\ell}^{2}\left(\sum_{i=1, i \neq \ell}^{p} x_{i}^{2}\right)\left(\sum_{i=1, i \neq \ell}^{p}\left|\kappa^{\prime}\left(\sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{Y}_{i \ell}\right)\right|^{2} v_{\ell}^{2}\right) \\
& \leq\|\boldsymbol{v}\|_{\infty}^{2} \max _{1 \leq \ell \leq p} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{S} \backslash\{\ell\}}\left|\kappa^{\prime}\left(\sqrt{n} \boldsymbol{Y}_{i \ell}\right)\right|^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

Combining the above bounds yields the lemma.

abstract:
This work studies estimation of sparse principal components in high
dimensions. Specifically, we consider a class of estimators based on kernel
PCA, generalizing the covariance thresholding algorithm proposed by Krauthgamer
et al. (2015). Focusing on Johnstone's spiked covariance model, we investigate
the "critical" sparsity regime, where the sparsity level $m$, sample size $n$,
and dimension $p$ each diverge and $m/\sqrt{n} \rightarrow \beta$, $p/n
\rightarrow \gamma$.
  Within this framework, we develop a fine-grained understanding of signal
detection and recovery. Our results establish a detectability phase transition,
analogous to the Baik--Ben Arous--P\'ech\'e (BBP) transition: above a certain
threshold -- depending on the kernel function, $\gamma$, and $\beta$ -- kernel
PCA is informative. Conversely, below the threshold, kernel principal
components are asymptotically orthogonal to the signal. Notably, above this
detection threshold, we find that consistent support recovery is possible with
high probability. Sparsity plays a key role in our analysis, and results in
more nuanced phenomena than in related studies of kernel PCA with delocalized
(dense) components. Finally, we identify optimal kernel functions for detection
-- and consequently, support recovery -- and numerical calculations suggest
that soft thresholding is nearly optimal.
